text: Text: 'Paying for Trash Some people think families should pay for each bag of trash they make. This idea sounds good for the environment and money, but it might not be. In many places, trash is picked up for free. Families pay for this with local taxes. But a family with a lot of trash pays the same as a family with little trash. More trash means more workers and trucks are needed, and this costs more money. If trash pickup is free, people might make too much trash. One idea is to make families pay for each bag of trash. This might make them throw away less and recycle more. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found this idea has problems. They studied towns in America where people pay for trash. People buy stickers for their trash bags. Only bags with stickers are picked up. In Charlottesville, Virginia, people paid 80 cents for each bag. The number of bags went down by 37%. But people just put more trash in each bag. The weight of trash went down by only 14%. In other towns without this system, trash went down by 3.5% anyway. Some people also dumped trash illegally. This might be 30-40% of the trash reduction. One good thing was a 15% increase in recycling. But many people were already recycling. In another study, the economists found that higher prices for trash stickers only reduced trash a little. A 10% price increase cut trash by only 0.3%. People would need to buy less of everything to make a big change. Other things like income and education might also affect how much trash people make. Richer towns make more trash and have less time to recycle. Charging for trash is not a bad idea, but it is complicated. Simple ideas can have complex results.'

Text: 'Work Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life can change. Do you feel respected at work? Success in a job is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special. Now, you need to think about how your job affects you as a person. This is important. If your job makes you boring or too busy, no money or status can make up for it. I want to find out how work can make us happy and help us grow. Work should not just be about making money. It should help us live better and meet new people. Even jobs like doctors and accountants are not as good as they used to be. Many people are stressed and unhappy. Companies are getting smaller, and workers do not feel connected to their jobs. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel their values match their company's values. I am looking at different jobs to see how they affect people. I want to find better ways to work. Many people work hard but do not feel alive at work. They feel like they have no choice. For example, hotel workers often have low pay and long hours. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep. They could be places where people meet and learn from each other. But hotels focus only on making money. Work is a relationship. People want to be independent and choose their jobs and coworkers. They need to talk and understand each other. Good conversation can change the world a little bit each time.'

**Broadcasting: The Story of TV and Radio**

Broadcasting started as a word for planting seeds by hand. It means spreading things widely. This idea fits with how TV and radio work. They send out shows from one place to many homes.

In the 1930s, people tried different ways to use TV. Some wanted TV to be like a phone, where people could talk back and forth. In Britain, hobbyists built their own TV sets. But big companies set rules that made it hard for these hobbyists to continue.

TV was mostly watched in public places, like theaters, in the early days. This was true in the USA, Britain, and Germany. But soon, people wanted TVs in their homes. As more people could afford TVs, they became a part of everyday life.

Broadcasting helped governments share important news with everyone. It also helped people feel connected to their country. Broadcasting was important for democracy because it gave everyone access to information.

Today, broadcasting is changing. The way we use TV and radio might be different in the future. But the idea of spreading information widely will always be important.

**Clutter**

Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you have, you never feel safe. It is normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes wanting more things can get out of control. Modern ads are made to make us feel like we need more. They tell us, "If you don't have this, you are not good enough." Try not to look at any ads next time you walk down the street. Ads are everywhere—on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet—all telling us to buy more.

**Caves**

People around the world study caves. They want to know where caves come from, how water moves in them, and what lives in them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and we want to learn more about them. Many people study caves, both professionals and people who visit caves for fun. Studying caves can be hard because you need to be able to move well to get inside them.

**Weather Watch**

A long time ago, people watched the weather with just their eyes. This helped start the study of weather, called meteorology. Today, we use satellites and computers to learn about the weather. Computers can do math very fast, faster than people can. Weather science uses big words, but simple weather knowledge is still important. Human experience helps turn computer data into weather forecasts. People can still see things that help weather experts understand the weather better.

**Music and Theatre**

I used to think opera was mostly theatre. But now I know music is more important in opera. I come from the theatre world, where words and actors are very important. In theatre, the audience and actors usually speak the same language. 

In music performances, like concerts or opera, many people don't know much about music. They might feel embarrassed about this. But they admire the skill of the musicians. Watching a great musician is like watching athletes. We know they are doing something amazing.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They don't always understand an actor's skill. They might not be impressed by a long speech. But they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" Theatre audiences and performers meet on more equal terms.

Can music learn from theatre? I think yes. Music is full of emotion and can be like theatre. But music often feels formal, with dress codes and respect for conductors. Sometimes, audiences clap at the wrong time, which can interrupt the music.

Many people are trying to make music more welcoming. I remember a special event, a community opera, where the audience moved with the action. It was a great musical experience and changed many people's lives.

I want music to take more risks, like theatre. Sometimes, using new places for music can surprise everyone. It might be uncomfortable, but theatre audiences are used to this. I believe music can change and become more exciting. I love both theatre and music and want more people to enjoy them.

**Sand**

I do not like sand very much. Sand can become glass and concrete, which is useful. But on the beach, sand is a problem. It blows in your face and gets in your food. It hides things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove. But when you step on a towel or get in a car, sand falls off. For days, you find sand in your shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a long time. I do not want sand.

**Lock and Key**

People want their homes to be safe and private. Long ago, people used a beam to lock the door. Now, we have electronic locks with many combinations. But people still like using a key. Some companies tried using smart cards for locks. But people prefer turning a key at home. So, one company made an electronic lock with a metal key.

**Modern Art**

I was nervous to visit the new Tate Modern gallery. I do not understand modern art. I like some things, like furry art and neon lights. I do not know much about art, so I do not have many opinions. Art should talk to you, but it does not work for me. The new gallery helps visitors understand art. The labels explain what the art is about. This helps me understand the pictures better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

When books become movies, many parts are cut or changed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see new things. When I worked on a movie script, I saw that I could remove a lot of the book's dialogue and description, but still keep the main idea. This doesn't mean the book's words were not needed. It's about how each type of story, book or movie, needs different things. In books, we often see repeated details about characters or who is speaking. This helps us understand better. In plays, which are mostly talking, the extra words make it feel like real speech. Some modern plays use a lot of extra words, so we don't always know what is being said.

**Watching Movies**

When we watch movies, we can feel like we are in a different world. For a short time, we forget about real life. But when the movie ends, we come back to the real world. Some people used to think movies were just for fun, not art. They liked watching them but didn't think they were important.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios had many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around. There were three main entrances, but only one took you where you wanted to go. It was confusing for new people, but the workers knew their way. These workers made movies that brought excitement and adventure to people.

**Film-makers**

Many people want to make movies. There are books and classes on how to do it. Some people, like Robert Rodriguez, made movies with little money and became famous. He made his first big movie when he was young. In the past, movie makers took more time to learn. They worked on small projects first. Now, without big studios to help, new film-makers have to be different and creative.

Text: 'A long time ago, many houses were on the west side of the city. They were small and not very nice. In summer, a factory nearby made the air smell bad. In the morning, a paperboy would hold his nose because of the smell. I don't remember much from when I was young. But I do remember sitting by a window and looking at the houses. I also remember my mother. She was often angry, and I didn't know why. She liked things to be very clean and proper. She didn't like people going into other people's gardens or making noise. My mother had some friends. They talked about the weather and their children. Growing up in West Earlham was the same for everyone. Before you were five, you stayed at home. After that, you went to school. Some kids went on bikes with their mothers. I went with other kids. I remember summer holidays. We saw new things outside West Earlham. Once, we went to a charity event, but my mother didn't like it. She thought people wanted money. My mother didn't trust politicians. She thought they took people's money. But she cared about my education. Sometimes, we went to the museum. My mother liked looking at the paintings. Once, she made a joke about a painting of a soldier.'

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue. It was getting dark, and the air was wet. I felt like I was hiding. I knew this street well. My neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards. Han Kieffer had a grocery store here. My friends lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. I used to play with them. The houses were special to me. I remembered the little paths in the cement where rainwater flowed. I used to skate or ride my scooter over them.

As I walked, I noticed the houses changed. The porches were lower, and the yards were smaller. Over time, wooden porches became iron ones. Some houses became stores, and some stores became houses again. I wondered how people lived in these old store spaces.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has big doors and brick walls. He didn't want an open space. He wanted separate areas for work and living. He used a big plastic sheet to make a hallway and hide his office. The kitchen is in the middle. He wanted it to be a place for both work and friends. He used light wood for the floors and mixed modern and old furniture.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His first book, "In Patagonia," was very special. It was a travel book that felt like a story. He sometimes changed facts to make the story better. He believed travel could help us find exciting histories.

**Swimming**

One summer, it rained a lot. I swam in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles in the water. I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea. Swimming felt free, like walking or cycling. It helped me see the world in a new way.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying had no clear purpose. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps mothers and children bond. Many people think children cry because they feel helpless. But why do adults cry? It is not easy to explain. The sound of crying is less important than seeing someone cry. Crying might have helped early humans trust each other and feel connected. We can cry for other reasons too. We might cry when we feel sorry for someone. Sometimes, we cry without wanting to, like when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, especially with other people. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**

Global warming is making the Earth warmer. We know it will change the weather everywhere, but we are not sure how. The weather changes will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food and build cities. Changes in these resources are important.

In the last 100 years, humans have put more gases into the air. These gases make the Earth warmer. Scientists think this is not natural and is because of human pollution. They use computers to try to predict the future weather. These predictions are not perfect, but they help us understand what might happen.

Scientists think the Earth's temperature will go up by 1°C to 3.5°C by the year 2100. The sea level might rise by 15-95 cm. There might be more heatwaves, floods, and droughts. These changes can affect where plants and animals live and how much food we can grow.

Some changes might be good. For example, in Australia, warmer weather has helped grow more wheat. But many changes might be bad. Less water might be available, especially in dry areas. The Mediterranean region is already seeing less rain in some parts.

Ice in the Arctic might melt completely. This could make it easier to transport goods by sea, but it also increases the danger from icebergs. The biggest change might be the rise in sea levels. This could cause flooding in cities like London, New York, and Tokyo. Many people might lose their homes, and some small islands might disappear completely.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong and healthy. This is the plan of millionaire Dennis Tito. He wants to send a capsule to Mars on 5 January 2018. The capsule will go 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars's gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. This is important because the next chance to go to Mars is in 2031. New technology is needed for this mission. If everything is ready in time, the spacecraft might go. Even if it does not go, the work will help future missions.'

**Art and Experience**

Art is often seen as something separate from everyday life. People think of art as a painting, a building, or a statue. But art is more than just these objects. Art is about what these objects make us feel and think.

Sometimes, famous art pieces are so admired that they become hard to understand. They seem far away from the real world. When this happens, art feels like it is in a special place, not connected to normal life.

To understand art better, we need to connect it back to everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our daily experiences. To learn about art, we should look at the simple things around us that we enjoy, like movies, music, and comics. These are also forms of art.

Many people enjoy these everyday arts without realizing they are art. They think art only belongs in museums. But real art is everywhere, in the things we see and hear every day. When we see art as part of our daily life, we can enjoy and understand it more.

**Observing Lions**

Lions are big cats that hunt together. People often think lions work well as a team. They imagine lions hiding and then jumping out to catch their food. Lions seem to be good at working together. But after watching lions for many years, we learned something different. We started studying lions in 1978. We wanted to know why lions hunt together and take care of their babies together. We thought we would find answers in two or three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. It took us a long time to learn about them. Lions can live up to 18 years, so we are only now finding answers to our questions.

**Advertising in the 1990s**

In the early 1990s, people working in advertising had a hard time. The economy was bad, and many people lost their jobs. In Britain, in 1991, the economy went down, interest rates were high, and many people stopped buying things. Over 500,000 people lost their jobs, and 75,000 homes were taken back by banks. Many businesses, like car and building companies, lost a lot of money.

Advertising workers felt a lot of pressure. They had to do more work with less money. Even though it was hard, marketing became more important. Companies started to focus on making products that people wanted. This helped marketing people, but also made their jobs harder.

In the 1980s, advertising was very successful. But in the 1990s, it was difficult. The bad economy made companies think more about how they spent money on advertising. They wanted to know if advertising was really helping them. Many companies wanted better advertising strategies and creativity.

Advertising people had to find ways to do more with less money. The recession made it hard to take risks, which are often needed for good advertising. Other challenges included changes in the population, the power of big stores, and new laws about advertising. Some companies also had to learn how to advertise in other countries.

Because of these challenges, advertising people had to work hard to make sure their ads were effective. There was not much help available for them. Companies and advertising agencies were busy dealing with these problems and did not share their successful strategies. Books and seminars on advertising did not always provide useful information.

Text: 'The Kitchen Dream When I was at university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice. Cooking is hard work, with long hours and low pay. But I did not mind. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and I did not enjoy the social life. Being a chef seemed better. It felt serious and honest. I first wanted to cook after eating at a famous restaurant in London. The food was amazing. I wanted to learn how to cook like that. I started reading cookbooks and making special meals. Swimming Lessons The swimming teacher was a small, strong man with tattoos. He taught me how to dive. First, I sat on the pool's edge and rolled into the water. Then, I stood and dived from the edge. The teacher was strict. He told me to look up and keep my legs straight. Next, I tried diving from the high board. It was very high, and I was scared. I jumped and felt like I was flying. I did not dive well, but I was happy. I felt free like a bird. The Traveller Some people like to travel in dangerous places. They climb high mountains and sail in big seas. They eat strange food and live in the unknown. These people are different. They live outside our normal world. We like our safe homes and easy lives. Sailing Jonathan Raban is scared of the sea, but he spends a lot of time on it. He is a good sailor. He likes to write about sailing. His boat has a tool that shows his exact place on the sea. He likes this tool but thinks other tools make sailing less special. He believes sailors should watch the sea, not just follow a compass. This is why he has time to look at the waves.'

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two big joys: going on holiday and reading books. These joys are connected. Books help us feel at home in the world. We see our own experiences in stories from faraway places or long ago. Authors write about feelings we thought were only ours. They use words we cannot find. We feel thankful to these writers for helping us understand ourselves. Reading and travel help us see new things. When we are in a new place, our eyes are open. A good book can also show us things we did not notice before. We start to see the sky, people's faces, or feelings we did not know we had.

**Author's Note**

These travel stories were in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I made small changes, but not many. I fixed some mistakes. In one story about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong. A year later, it fell. I did not change the story because it was written at that time. Like other travelers, I was there, not knowing what would happen next. This is the story of travel: seeing the world with just a ticket. I believe travelers can see things, even in a postcard.

**Ecotourism**

'Ecotourism' is a popular word in travel. It started in the 1980s when people cared more about the environment. Tourists wanted to travel without harming nature. Now, 'ecotourism' can mean many things, like living with tribes or a short boat trip. It includes culture, nature, and adventure. The idea was good, but without rules, travelers can get confused.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my Transylvania travel notes for 50 years. I found them by luck. They helped me write about that time. In Transylvania, I stayed in nice houses for weeks. I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to say. When I moved, I wrote notes, not full stories. I worried about the order of events, but then I decided to let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**

Fashion is not just a new thing. It has been around for a long time. Many people think fashion started in the 1800s and 1900s, but it is older. Historians say fashion began in the 1500s and 1600s when trade and markets grew. As societies grew bigger and more complex, people made more types of clothes. This made the meaning of clothes more complex too. Today, it is hard to say what any piece of clothing really means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people.

**Writer**

Many people think all writers are rich and famous, but this is not true for most. Some writers have other jobs and write in their free time. Others, like me, do different small jobs to make money. I teach, do workshops, and write articles. I have heard of fun jobs, like writing for a chocolate factory, but I have not had one. Still, with part-time jobs and help from friends, I can write my book.

**Sudden Fame**

Our small shows were selling out, and more security was needed because of the many fans. We had to use secret ways to enter places to avoid the crowds. On days off, it was hard to go out without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Fans watched us, and our managers took care of us. Even though I was shy, I felt more confident, but it was still hard for me to handle.

**Music and Technology**

Technology is changing our lives. Susan Hallam talks about how it changes music in Britain. In the late 20th century, people had more ways to listen to music. They used radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, there were fewer live music shows and jobs for musicians. Music is important for people and events. It helps us in many ways. Music will be in the 21st century, but it might change. People might still want to learn instruments. The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain. Musical skills are important for jobs, especially in media.

Playing music can help people learn other skills. In the USA, research shows music can help with intelligence. In Europe, group music lessons help kids with social skills and focus. Playing an instrument might help with good study habits and being on time.

In the future, music might change in two ways. First, people will listen to many types of music. New music styles will mix different kinds. Second, technology will help people make and play music. This might mean fewer live shows. More people of all ages will want to make music. These activities will be in communities and show their music traditions.

To prepare for the future, music teaching needs to change. More people should learn to play instruments. Music lessons will need to change to stay important. Musicians will need new skills to teach and work with different groups. They will need to inspire and teach people of all ages. They will also need skills for community work. This is different from how things were before. Music education should show its high quality.

Finally, we need to make music more important. Music is a big part of our lives, but we often forget it. People in the music world need to work together to change this.

**Actors and Their Work**

Sometimes, people make fun of actors. This happens when actors talk too much about their work in interviews. They should be like the dancer Pavlova. When someone asked her what her dance meant, she said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." But actors often say things that sound silly or are just gossip. 

Paul Scofield, a famous actor, said something important. He wrote in a letter that acting is interesting only when you do it. Talking about it makes it seem empty. Acting has no rules, except maybe being loud enough to hear. With every new play, actors start fresh, learning and growing with the story. When the play ends, they feel empty until the next one.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester plays Hamlet. His acting is simple and strong. He is very good with the words and his body. He plays a young man who is sometimes angry but also funny. His acting is very good, even if it looks easy. 

**A Director's Way of Rehearsing**

This director has a special way to practice plays. The actors look at the script on a screen. They think about the words and what they mean. When it's their turn, they speak the words with feeling. They imagine scenes and find reasons to say their lines. The director says not to plan too much. Just be open and trust that something will happen.

**The Perfect Theatre**

A good theatre makes you feel important. Going to a play is special, and the staff should know that too. The theatre should make a connection between the actors and the audience. Everyone should see and hear well. The theatre should fit the human voice and body. Old theatres often feel right because they have history. You can't please everyone with a play. People want to see something new and surprising.

Text: 'Paul Simon Rock and roll in the 1950s was music for young people. But it was also important for older people. It changed music forever. It helped new rock stars to start. Paul Simon, like other young people in the US, listened to this new music on the radio. Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party, played this music. Many young people listened to it. John Lennon, in Liverpool, also listened to rock and roll on the radio. Paul Simon loved the music from Freed's show. He wanted to make his own music. Snow I could not see a path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me. I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke. I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow was like a roof over the hole. I climbed out, feeling scared. I thought about what I would do if the hole was deeper. I sat by a pine tree to think. In one hour, I walked about half a mile. I knew I had to change my plan. Qualitative Research There are many books about qualitative research. These books talk about collecting data. But they do not talk much about how to look at the data. Many people do not know how researchers study their data. We asked social scientists to talk about how they study data. We wanted to understand the process better. This is not easy. We let our contributors show their work in different ways, like stories or formal writing.'

**Screen Learning**

My six-year-old son was eating noodles in a funny way. He said, "I'm a little dinosaur," because he saw it on TV. I asked him what he learned about dinosaurs, and he didn't remember much. Many people like learning on computers and the internet, but is it the best way? One father tried an interactive program with his son. The father read the words, but the son only looked at the pictures. The father thought his son might learn more from a book. TV can give ideas, but real learning happens when talking with teachers or parents. New technology is good, but schools are still important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most movies were made in Hollywood. People in Los Angeles didn't like the movie makers at first. But they accepted them because movies made a lot of money. Hollywood became famous like New York, Rome, or Paris. It changed a lot; it used to have orange trees. People in Hollywood talk about movies, money, and famous people. Many successful people want to work in Hollywood but live somewhere else. Still, many people in show-business go to Hollywood.

**Photography**

Photography started in the 1800s. Artists wanted to keep real images of what they saw. They used light, lenses, and chemicals to make pictures. These pictures were more real and detailed than paintings. Some people said photography was not art because it used machines. But photographers knew it was a new way to show the world. They used cameras like artists use brushes to show nature and people.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, all children's books had pictures. Even books for older kids had pictures, but this changed over time. Many children's books were made cheaply, so some pictures were not very good. But some artists always did their best work. Old black-and-white book pictures are interesting to look at. Some are not good, but some are treasures. People are starting to show these pictures again in books and exhibitions. Maybe publishers will make new books with these old pictures.

Text: 'Blogging: Sharing with the World

A while ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone where you are online. It said that when you say, "Hey, I'm here," you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know. This made people think that sharing too much online can be bad. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting because we might become famous or rich. So, we share our stories and photos online. But sometimes, we realize too late that it can be dangerous.

In the past, some people started sharing their lives online. They were the first bloggers. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and became famous before social media existed. These bloggers learned many lessons that we can learn from today.

In 1994, a student named Justin Hall started sharing his life on the internet. He wrote about everything and shared photos. People loved reading about his life. But one day, he had to stop because it caused problems in his personal life. He learned that sharing too much can make people not trust you.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong wrote about her job on her blog. Someone at her work shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. But Heather's story ended well. She got married, started blogging again about her family, and became successful.

The lesson is: we can say anything online, but we should be careful about what we share.'

Text: 'Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired. In busy countries, people often do not sleep enough. In the USA, 40 million people have sleep problems. In Britain, some books talk about people who cannot sleep. People are interested in sleep and why it is important. A sleep expert says, 'People need more sleep. They wake up early to avoid traffic.' One researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they slept about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep. In Europe, a university in England studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, noise affects sleep, and driving when tired. They ask students to help with the research. Students get paid and change their sleep for the study. Dr. Louise Reyner says some people worry because they put wires on their heads, but they only study physical things. In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. People come at 2pm after little sleep. They drive and answer questions. The road looks endless, and the room is warm. Some people try not to sleep, but they do. Dr. Reyner says coffee can help. Two cups can make you a safe driver for a short time. She also suggests energy drinks and gum. Scientists know some things about sleep. People sleep in cycles, like other animals. There are four stages of sleep. Dreams happen in light sleep. The brain stops the body from moving during dreams. Scientists think sleep helps the body and brain, but they are not sure. Women sleep a bit longer than men, and older people need less sleep. In the past, people slept differently. A professor found that from 1500 to 1850, people had 'first sleep' and 'morning sleep'. They woke up in the night for an hour. This was a quiet time. As light became common, people started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer, so they slept less. In some places, people still sleep in short times. They wake up at night because of noise or danger. Many people around the world need more sleep.'

Text: 'I am talking about big boots. Really big boots. I stood in my expensive cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. I wore a cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. I looked at the Arizona mountains and knew I was not at home. I flew from Denver in the morning and thought I might look like a cowboy. But when I saw a real cowboy at the airport, I knew I was not. He wore a dirty shirt and carried a bag. He looked at my new boots and left without a word. 

I used to be a racing driver. I loved driving racing cars. But I don't do it anymore. I thought about what to do next. Maybe I could talk about races on TV? But many other drivers want to do that too. Maybe I could sell old cars? But nobody was buying them. Being an 'ex' racing driver is hard. People don't want to hear about 'almost' winning. Even if I was a champion, people would only listen for a short time. 

I miss driving fast cars. I miss the excitement and the people. I was a little famous. People wanted my autograph. Now, I don't drive anymore. My phone doesn't ring much. I have a lot of free time. 

I looked at the sky. There were no big birds, but small birds were singing. I realized I have a lot to learn.'

**Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people walk on the city streets. If you walk with them, you can hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver because it has a mild climate, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, and it is clean and safe. There are also good schools and jobs. Some people complain about new buildings, but the new people and tourists have helped the city grow. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Now, it is more of a gateway than ever.

**Writing Letters**

Journalists like me are not good at writing letters. Some say it is because we do not get paid for letters, but I do not think that is true. In our work, we try to make a big impact, so writing a simple letter is hard for us. Real artists do not have this problem. They know how to make their words special. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he did not think about why they were good. He just wrote them.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A famous person would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open every day, so famous people are not needed. Last week, at a new Superbuy store, people did not care who opened it. They just wanted to be first inside. The first five men got a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women got flowers. People at the front of the line felt happy, and those who came late felt jealous.

**Citizen Kane**

The movie *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941. At first, it was not a big success in theaters. People were worried because the movie was about a man like William Randolph Hearst, a powerful newspaper owner. But later, television made the movie popular. Many people who make movies today say *Citizen Kane* inspired them. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first movie. Welles said he did not know what he could or could not do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland and writer Herman J. Mankiewicz. Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a movie about a newspaper owner like Hearst. Welles was excited to direct and act in the movie.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot thought Carmel was acting strange that morning. He told her he might be late because he wanted to stop at the golf club. Carmel just nodded and seemed not to listen. Dermot asked her what she would do that day. Carmel said she had nothing to do, so she would walk around town and look at shops. Dermot said she should enjoy herself and not worry about making dinner if he was late. Carmel agreed.

**Title Race**

A study showed that job titles can make people jealous at work. Many workers and bosses say titles cause problems. Some workers even want a better job title more than a pay raise. People do not like being called a lower position. New job titles focus on skills but are often just nicer names.

Text: 'I was in Vienna to take photos. Photos were very important to me. I loved how light looked on things. One photo could show a whole city or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo. I used to work for newspapers, but now I work for myself. I was in Vienna because another photographer left the job. I took photos for a book about four cities: London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I was happy to go to Vienna. Things at home were not good. I stayed at a hotel in the city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but this time was different. I wanted to take great photos. The first day, I rode trams to see the city. I wanted to make Vienna my own. A photo is a moment, and I waited for the right moment. The next morning, I went out early. The snow made the city look beautiful. I wanted to take a photo of the big cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one picture. Photography is magical. You can watch a photo appear on paper. Even when you know how it works, it still feels like magic. That morning in Vienna, something special happened.'

**Kinetic Art Exhibition**

A new exhibition in London shows kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or shows movement. The exhibition is at the Hayward Gallery. It is not a big, expensive show. It is a simple and interesting look at art from the last 60 years. The exhibition has paintings, drawings, documents, and films. Guy Brett, the curator, has studied kinetic art for a long time. There are no long texts to read. Visitors can enjoy and learn by looking at the art.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney is a popular artist. Many people like his art. His art is easy to understand. It shows fun and relaxing things. Some people like Hockney because he is funny and interesting. Some critics say he is not a great artist. Hockney knows he is not the best. He thinks only time will tell if he is a great artist.

**Window-shopping - an Art Exhibition**

A curator made an art show called "Window-shopping." It was in an empty warehouse. Seven artists showed their work. The art pieces were very different. For example, Sam Cole made knitted cats that moved on a toy train track. Matthew Crawley used a video camera to make art. The art did not have a common theme. The curator wanted to show that art can be different and still be interesting.

**Art History**

Some people like to look at paintings but do not want to study them. They think studying art can ruin the fun. Art historians study art and its history. They think knowing more about art can make it more enjoyable. Our likes and dislikes in art can change over time. They are influenced by the society we live in. Enjoying art is important, but learning about it can also be interesting.

**Metals**

A long time ago, people found metals. They liked shiny things. Maybe they found gold in a river. Gold is soft and easy to shape. People wanted it. They also found copper. Copper is good for making tools. People learned how to get copper from rocks. This was important for them.

**St Ives**

We walked with our bags down a small street. It was very windy and cold. The sea waves were big and hit the road. No one was outside. The houses were closed. We came to St Ives by train. The sky was grey. Visiting Cornwall without a car was not a good idea. I told my friend we would walk by the sea and sit by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is hard because it is gone. People from long ago are not here. We do not know why they lived in some places. Archaeology gives us some ideas, but we cannot test them. But now, we can use computers. Computers help us make old places and people. We can see how they lived. We can change things like rain or people and see what happens.

**Vervet Monkeys**

One day, a group of vervet monkeys saw a new male monkey near their trees. The new monkey wanted to join their group. The leader monkey did not want this. He made a smart plan. When the new monkey tried to come closer, the leader monkey made a loud noise. This noise means "leopard is near!" The new monkey got scared and ran back to his trees. This happened many times. But then, the leader monkey made a mistake. He made the noise while he was walking calmly. 

**What Cats Catch**

In a village in England, people counted what their cats caught. In one year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. A professor thought that all cats in Britain might catch 100 million birds and small animals each year. But this is not true. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals. The important question is: are there still enough birds? The answer is yes. People feed birds in winter, and birds have places to live in gardens. Cats catch many animals, but they do not harm the bird population too much.

**Buffalo's Day**

Buffaloes are very important to marsh people. Every morning, buffaloes leave their sleeping place slowly. They make tired noises and move to the water. They stand at the edge, making noises about the hard day ahead. Finally, the leader buffalo moves into the water. They stay in the water, looking tired. Slowly, they swim away, just their noses above water. They spend the day eating plants in the water.

**Picasso's Painting**

In 1940, Picasso painted fish while he was in a fishing town. The painting shows a fish table with a crab and some fish. The fish look alive. The painting is flat and calm, like underwater. But there is a feeling of a fight coming. The fish show their teeth, and the crab has open claws. The painting has a feeling of danger.

Photography

For about 150 years, photography has helped us see and remember many parts of life. It lets us see things that are far away or very small. We can see pictures from far places on Earth and even from space. Photography shows us the world and helps us understand life.

Long ago, people made pictures on cave walls. We don't know why they made them, but pictures have always been important to people. When photography was invented in the 1800s, it changed how we see the world. People thought photos showed the truth because they looked like what we see with our eyes.

Photos are like a special language. Some people thought everyone could understand photos, no matter where they are from. But, photos can mean different things to different people, just like words.

Photography has changed a lot since it was invented in 1839. Photos used to help us remember things, but now they also tell us about history. Photos can show us what life was like in the past.

Photography is not just about taking pictures. It can help change the world by showing us new ideas and helping us see things differently.

**How to Write Poetry**

Writing poetry is not easy. Everyone has their own way. Some people need to feel safe to write a poem. Others write when they are sad. Some people write every day. Others wait for a special idea. All ways are good if you listen to your own voice. 

**The Short Story**

A short story should not have too many characters or long parts. Flashbacks should be short and help the story. Dialogue, or talking between characters, is important. It can show different sides of a story quickly. Every word in a short story is important.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. At first, you might not know what will happen next. But with practice, you see the whole game. You learn about strategy and patterns. The more you write, the better you understand.

**Looking at Writing**

Speaking is natural for humans, but writing is not. All children learn to speak without lessons. Writing systems were created by a few old societies. Many children find writing hard. Speaking is natural, but writing needs to be learned. We need to understand how writing works and how children learn it.

Text: 'I have never started a book with more worry. I call it a book because I don't know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and I do not end with a death or a marriage. I leave my reader unsure. This book is about my memories of a man I met only sometimes, and I do not know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up things to fill the gaps, but I do not want to do that. I only want to write what I know. To protect people still alive, I have given them new names, and I have made sure no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. Maybe he never will be. When he dies, he might leave no trace, like a stone in a river. Then my book, if read, will be read for its own interest. But maybe his way of life and his character will influence others, and people will realize he was special. Then it will be clear who I write about, and those who want to know about his early life may find something useful. I think my book will help people who want to write about my friend. I do not say the conversations are exact. I never wrote down what was said, but I remember well. I have put these talks in my own words, but they show what was said. I have not made up anything, but I have added some talks to make the story lively. I want people to read my book, and I think it is okay to make it interesting. The smart reader will know where I have done this and can ignore it. Another reason I worry about this book is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is hard to know people, and I think you can only really know your own countrymen. People are not just themselves; they are also where they were born, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they went to, and the poems they read. These things make them who they are, and you can only know them if you have lived them. You can only know if you are them. Because you cannot know people from another country well, it is hard to make them real in a book. I have only written about my own countrymen, and if I have written about others in short stories, it is because you can describe them briefly. You give the reader a general idea and let them imagine the rest. In this book, I do not say my characters are as they see themselves; they are seen through my eyes.'

**Poetry Recitals**

Today, there are many different types of poetry. Some poets write poems to be read in books, while others like to read their poems out loud to people. This is called a poetry recital. 

In the past 20 years, poetry recitals have become more popular. People can hear poetry in small towns, schools, and festivals. Some poets write simple poems that are easy to understand when you hear them. These poets like to perform their poems for an audience. 

Other poets write more complex poems. These poems have deep thoughts and feelings. They are best read quietly on a page. When these poets read their work out loud, it might be hard for people to understand everything right away. 

Listening to poetry can be fun and helpful. It is good to hear how poets read their own work. Sometimes, music is played with the poetry to make it more enjoyable. This helps people see that poetry can be fun and not just for experts.

**Oral History**

Historians are using more oral evidence, but it has problems. When someone talks about the past, it is not always clear or true. The historian and the person talking can change each other's thoughts. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is shaped by both the historian and the person talking. Memories can also be mixed with things from TV or other people. Sometimes, people remember the past as better or worse than it was. Feelings can make a story seem true, but they might come from later events, not the past.

**Animal Science**

There are two main ways to study animals: looking at how their bodies work and looking at their behavior. Physiologists study how nerves and muscles work together. People who study the whole animal look at how animals act and what affects them. There are two types of whole animal scientists: psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists study how animals learn, often in labs with rats and pigeons. Ethologists study how animals act naturally, often in the wild. These two groups are now working together more. Physiologists think their work is very important, but we also need to study animal behavior. Trying to explain a bird building a nest by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

When students start studying social sciences, they need to learn two things: the content and the methods. They need to know the facts and how to find and organize them. Social sciences are not just common sense. Each social science looks at a different part of social life and uses different methods and ideas. These ideas help social scientists understand more than everyday common sense and make each social science different.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used some Greek words for these ideas. Utility and function were not part of his definition, but he did talk about the best ways to build for different uses. The focus was on beauty and art. Classical architecture started from simple huts in Greece and Italy. These huts were not artistic but gave basic forms that later became part of classical architecture. A classical temple is like a simple, single-room hut.

Text: 'Lily and her sister kept her driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily drove around the area, going over a small bridge with a bump. Chen found out but was amused. 'You can really drive, Lily? Well done!' he said. Mui thought Chen should be upset, but he was happy and planned a trip with Lily. They chose a Monday next month, leaving early and coming back by midday. Lily practiced driving more. Mui bought a road map with a discount, which impressed Chen. Lily felt a bit hurt by Mui's lack of trust in her driving. They soon reached the English Channel. Lily drove well. Even Mui, who was ready to give directions, agreed. Lily passed some slow cars, and Chen clapped. They drove through a seaside town and parked. Lily was unsure about parking rules, so she paid a fee to be safe. She locked the van carefully. Chen joked, 'No one will want that old van.' Lily and Mui were annoyed. Chen took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. Chen thought about Man Kee's future. He wanted him to have a good education and own many restaurants. The sea made Chen feel thoughtful. He saw a ship with a telescope. He showed it to Man Kee and said it would take them home one day. Lily and Mui joined them. Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope. When Lily looked, the ship was gone, and she saw seagulls instead.'

Text: 'THE WELL I read that if you look from a deep hole, you can see stars in the day. I asked you to help me try this. You watched as I got into the well bucket. I told you to let me down. The bucket was heavy, and you were not strong enough. You tried to hold the handle but then let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. I saw strange lights, like stars in cartoons. I was scared and then angry at you for letting me fall. You asked if I was okay. I stayed quiet and watched you leave to get help. I climbed out of the well and hid. I saw water drops on the ground from my wet clothes. Mother and Father came with you and Arthur. Mother was very upset. Father looked into the well with a flashlight. I was scared they would find me. I came out of hiding and pretended to be hurt. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat. Father asked me to repeat my story. I said the tunnel fell in after me. Father did not believe me. He said, "Don't be ridiculous, boy," and walked away. Arthur looked at me sadly. He knew I was lying and worried about me. I felt bad for lying and knew I was in trouble.'

**Moving Day**

Susan is a widow. Her children are grown up. She has to leave her family home. A van is outside. It says "Removers of Distinction." Fred is the removal man. He is packing things in boxes. His fingers are big but gentle. His helpers are not so gentle.

Susan's house is nice. It has four floors and looks at a small harbour. She remembers her children growing up there. Robert, her son, is helping. He does not want her to talk about the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is careful with the piano.

Fred says, "She doesn't look like she's going to cry." Susan asks, "Do people cry?" Fred says, "Yes, they cry when the house is empty. But they are okay at the new place."

Susan remembers when they moved in. The piano got stuck on the stairs. Her husband, Peter, fixed the problem. They used a crane to bring the piano in through a window. It cost a lot of money.

Now, Susan is older. The children are busy. She finds it hard to climb stairs. She thinks about the piano. The banister is not straight from before. She should have told the movers. But it is too late.

Fred says, "It's just the piano to come now." Susan is nervous. Robert and Francesca watch. The piano comes down the stairs. Fred and his team carry it out. They put it behind the van.

Robert laughs first. Then Susan and Francesca laugh too. They are happy it is over. They walk down the path together, laughing. Susan only cries tears of laughter.

Text: 'Online Book Reviews for Everyone

The Internet lets everyone share their ideas. Before, only some people could write book reviews. But with Amazon.com, anyone can write a review. On Amazon, you can say what you think about a book and give it up to five stars. This helps other people know if they might like the book.

Amazon is a big online bookstore. Many people write reviews there. Sometimes, people try to trick others with fake reviews. For example, some writers write good reviews for their own books using fake names. One writer, Lev Grossman, did this because he got bad reviews. He wrote good ones to make his book look better. But when he told people about it, Amazon removed his fake reviews.

Authors can also write messages about their books on Amazon. They can say they hope people like their book. But sometimes, people pretend to be famous authors and write fake messages. Amazon checks these messages, especially if the author is famous.

Sometimes, people write bad reviews if they are upset with a book. For example, people in a book about cheerleaders wrote angry reviews because they didn't like how they were shown in the book. Amazon removed these reviews.

Most people write honest reviews. They help others decide if a book is good. Writing reviews is a way for everyone to share their thoughts about books.'

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last 200 years, people think artists must be different from others. We like art that is new and surprising. We admire artists whose work was not liked 100 years ago. But today, we sometimes say an artist has gone too far. The media often say this, and we agree. We think art should be new, so we do not see the old ideas in it. We want artists to be special and different from us. In the past, people asked artists to make art for them. Today, artists work alone, and we get upset if they try to be like everyone else.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and ask a question. An artist picks a text from an art book. The text talks about different pictures. The artist asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter writes the text on the canvas in simple black letters. My question is: Is this a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery, London until 26th June

Artists often stick to one style to be successful. People like to see the same kind of art from them. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, change styles and succeed. Eric Rimmington is trying something new. He is known for still life paintings but now paints the London Underground. He likes railways and has made 40 paintings and drawings of the Underground. These show the interesting world below the city.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers say only a sick person would come here to rebuild. I am here to heal myself. A woman from the village comes to clean the house, but I am alone. I am not happy or sad. I think about memories. Art is not useless. It helps us see the important parts of life. Artists use imagination to find meaning in life. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

Text: 'Family Business'

"My Dad said, 'Look here, it's no good!' We were in the car going back to London. My father and my brother Maurice had just picked me up from my school. I had won two prizes: one for Latin and one for doing well in exams. My father talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.

'What isn't good?' I asked. I knew he was thinking about something important because he was quiet. He usually talked a lot. 'You will do what you want now,' he said. 'You have many certificates. They say you will get a scholarship to Oxford.'

'So?' I said. 'Isn't that good?'

'I hear you want to be a barrister,' he said. 'A barrister!'

'I just said that,' I replied. 'I didn't know what else to say!'

'They say you have the right personality. You can understand things quickly, you talk well, and you like performing.'

'I don't know about that,' I said. 'I only know what I see on TV.'

'Anyway,' he said, 'I think you won't want to join the family business now. You will go to Oxford, and then you won't want it.'

I felt trapped by family expectations. I wanted to try other things, but I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't scared of him like Maurice was, but I respected him.

'It's too soon to know,' I said.

'You won't want to join us,' my father said. 'It's a pity because you have the brains and vision.'

'There's still Maurice,' I said.

My father snorted. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business.

'You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford,' my father said. 'Then you can decide. It will give you pocket money and help me.'

'OK,' I said, happy to avoid making a decision now.

So, I helped during holidays, never more than twice a year. I became a smart student with a little house, a nice car, and designer clothes.

In my last term, my father visited me. He said he needed me for one last important job for the family business. It was the biggest job ever.

'But Dad,' I said, 'I have my final exams soon. I need to focus on them.'

I knew he wouldn't understand. He might think I was betraying him. But I saw how focused and smart he was. He was a genius in his work. I respected that.

'All right,' I said. 'I'll do it.'"

Simon Costello knew buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake after a year. They couldn't really afford it. At first, it seemed like a good idea. Simon had many successful cases, and Lois got a raise at her job, making thirty-five thousand. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family. They needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found this in a cheaper area, but Lois wanted a better address. She thought Mornington Mansions wasn't good enough for them. Lois decided one of them should use public transport to save money. Her job was far, so Simon had to take the crowded tube. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he felt relaxed and cared for. But times had changed. Lois made it clear her career was as important as his. They needed both salaries for their lifestyle.

Now, their life could be ruined by Venetia. She came to their office angry. Someone upset her. She accused Simon of knowing a client, Brian Cartwright, bribed a jury four years ago. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty. Venetia didn't believe him. He wished he had said Cartwright lied to him after the trial. But he didn't, and now he was in trouble. If people heard about this, even as a rumor, his career could be over.

Text: I chose this place to live because I thought people here wouldn't care about broken houses and messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to know you. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were loved once. Usually, I stay inside, but tonight, I am watching birds fly. I cut some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms are scratched. It is a small London garden. My neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She writes books that are not published. I have her latest book. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask about your work so much,' she says. 'I'll bring a drink down,' she adds. I don't want Jaz in the garden, but she comes. She sits on a chair and says, 'Cheers. I should've been a teacher. Writers don't have holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach.' 'So, what plans for the holidays?' she asks. I feel worried about the school year ending. Empty days. Hot streets. The park with its fountain, and feeling lonely. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask. 'Of course,' Jaz says. 'Where will you stay?' 'With my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun,' I say. It's not true, but I deal with stories all the time. 'What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks. Her book, The Cruelty of Red Vans, is on my desk. I like the title and tell her. I say, 'Try writing about nice people.' 'Teachers!' Jaz says. 'I keep a journal and write something good about each day,' I say. 'Get a life, Ann,' Jaz replies. I have a life. I work, and I go out sometimes. When we go inside, I remember my school teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who said, 'I've had my moments.' We laughed.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people with the past. We often know about our grandparents and their stories. But, we also need to learn about our past to understand our future. Heritage helps us feel part of history. Just like we get our genes from our family, we also get culture from them. Sometimes, there are parts of our heritage we may not like, but it is still ours. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our well-being. It affects our customs and traditions. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. Now, we learn from places and buildings. It is important to keep these places safe to remember our ancestors.

**The Fens**

I wrote a book called "Waterland" about a place in England called the Fens. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, but I found out they are not. The Fens are a special part of England, different from other places. They are both empty and full, wild and cultivated, open and mysterious. I did not visit many places in the Fens while writing my book. I like to imagine places instead of just seeing them. The Fens are not just a place; they are a feeling.

**Museums**

Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, museums just put things in cases with long labels. Now, museums should make displays fun and interesting. Museums should also share their collections with many people. For example, they can lend objects to schools or help elderly people with memory problems. Museums show real things from the past, not copies. This makes them different from theme parks or books. Museums that make their displays exciting will help people want to learn more about history.

**Architecture and Environment**

People have always wanted to keep things from the past. But now, towns change quickly, and this affects us. Some people want to keep everything the same, while others think about how towns should look in the future. People who lived through big events like wars want to keep things stable. If people need to keep things the same, planners should think about this. Change is not bad if we know how to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in our society, like how many people live there and what they need.

Text: 'Einstein If you ask someone to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used to sell smart things like computers and books. Many people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he made some theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and having strange ideas. Einstein helped change how we think about science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to understand the universe better by studying matter and forces. Einstein looked at time, space, matter, and energy in a new way. Before, people thought like Isaac Newton, who said stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein said time and space are not fixed but change depending on other things. Young Readers When we were kids, Lydia and I did not like prize-winning books because we thought they were boring. Our mom did not like this, but our dad would give us money to read good books. He also gave us some books as gifts, saying they were not just stories. We thought most of these books were for boys, but we did read some short stories and poems. Language In 1851, Jacob Grimm said the start of human language is a big mystery. Many people have strange ideas about it. In 1928, Charles Caller said early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. Some people thought these sounds became words like "malaria" for "fever" or "mors" for "death". Because of these strange ideas, many people did not talk about language origins. But now, it is an important research area. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was used mainly for being friendly and in power struggles, not just for sharing information.'

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Reviews are short articles about books, movies, or other things. They are usually in newspapers or magazines. Reviews do not last long. They are only important for a short time, like a day or a week. People often think writing reviews is not a serious job. Some writers do it because they need money or because they cannot work on big projects all the time. But writing reviews is a skill. It is not easy to write a good review. A reviewer must think about who will read the review. Some people read quickly, and others want more details. A reviewer must know a lot about many things and write clearly. Many reviewers also write other things, like books. For example, the American writer John Updike writes reviews when he is not writing novels. He collects his reviews in books. Some people think reviews are not important, but others like to keep them. Frank Kermode is a professor. He writes books and reviews. In English-speaking countries, it is normal for professors to write reviews. This is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It is also good for professors because it helps them communicate with people who are not professors. Writing reviews is not the main job for most people. It is something they do along with other work.'

Ralph opened the door to his apartment. It was dark and quiet inside. Even after three years, he sometimes felt strange when he came home alone. When he first bought the apartment, he was excited to come home. He wondered what the apartment was like when he was not there. It felt like a safe place for him. He thought he should worry about things like burglars or broken pipes, but the apartment was always there, waiting for him. Sometimes it was tidy, sometimes not.

Ralph started to see the apartment as part of himself. He wanted it to change, but it stayed the same. Sometimes there were letters by the door or messages on the answering machine. He was glad nothing was broken or stolen. From his boring office, Ralph looked forward to being home alone. But when he got home, he felt empty and lonely. He thought his job was changing him, making him forget who he was.

At night, he read or listened to music, but he wondered why he did these things. He felt lost and confused. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and thought he could have done something different with his life. After university, he wanted to make a plan for himself, but he just wanted to survive. He applied for jobs his friends talked about and followed their paths. He went to one job interview for a local newspaper. He was happy to have a nice talk with Neil, his boss. Neil gave him the job because he was the only graduate who applied. Ralph thought this was a compliment.

**Goat Racing**

I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many people, ice-cream vans, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving to the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. A place was marked for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides to watch. Some people tried to keep the goats in order. It was hard because goats like to eat everything.

**Canoe Trip**

As it got dark, I was scared about the night. The canoe was too wet to sleep in. We did not see any villages or huts all day. In the moonlight, we used a torch to see the cliffs. The torch batteries were low, so we put in new ones, but they did not work. We could not find a place to camp. Later, Lesley saw a light, and we were happy. But it was just moonlight on the water. We heard loud water, but we could not see it. We kept moving.

**How to be Good at Presentations**

I am not good at making presentations. But as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and shareholders. How can I get better and more confident? You are not alone. Presenting is different from running a company. To convince others, you must believe in what you say. Show your passion and enthusiasm. Do your homework. Test your ideas before. Ask colleagues about hard questions the audience might ask. Start with something everyone agrees on and build to your conclusion.

Text: 'Some things take time. You can hurry to a meeting, but you cannot hurry everything. If you add oil too fast to mayonnaise, it will not work. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot gets tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things we can do fast, like solving puzzles. But some things need time, like making mayonnaise. If we rush, they do not work well. We think and learn in different ways. Sometimes we need to think fast, like when we are in danger. Other times, we need to think slowly, like when we are solving a big problem. Fast thinking is like our 'wits'. Slow thinking is like being creative or wise. We need both fast and slow thinking. Slow thinking helps with difficult problems. Scientists are learning more about slow thinking. It helps us understand complex things. It is important to give our mind time to think slowly.'

**Living in a New Place**

I am living in a new place. People are very nice to me. It is a small camp with many things we need. The camp is far away from other places. There are about forty people here. They are scientists, students, and other workers. Everyone helps each other. I can speak a little French, but not very well. I cannot make jokes or talk a lot. I miss some words, and my book of phrases does not help at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt shy. I was scared to eat with others. I did not know where to sit. I was nervous when people were quiet after I talked. I felt like I was back in school. I still smile a lot or get nervous when people talk to me. I think I feel sad sometimes because I cannot talk as much as I want. I like to talk a lot, but here I cannot.

**Meeting Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was a new writer. He did not notice me. But he always remembered people. When we met again, he was friendly but did not want to be friends. If I saw him at a show, he was with important people and did not see me. But then I became a successful writer. Elliot started to like me more. One day, he asked me to have lunch with him. I thought he wanted to know me better. After that, I saw him more often because I had many new friends.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

Alfred Hitchcock was a movie director. He said he did not care about the story or acting in his movies. He cared about the pictures and sounds. He thought movies should make people feel something, no matter where they are from. If a movie is made well, people from Japan and India will feel scared at the same time. Hitchcock was very smart and knew what he wanted. He liked to make people feel scared. He did not like to guess or think too much about his movie characters. He wanted to make movies that were just movies, with the best pictures and sounds to make people feel something.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. 30 years ago, there were not many charts or books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good. Now, you can buy many different telescopes and equipment. Computers help make charts and study stars. This is a great time for amateur astronomers. But, some things are not as good. You might need to travel far to see a clear sky. Airplanes make trails in the sky that can turn into clouds. This makes it hard to see the sun and stars.

**Too Much Choice**

Today, there are too many choices. There are many new products and services. Technology makes things change fast. This can be stressful and confusing. People want simple things in a complex world. But, it is hard to live simply when there are so many options. There are many types of soap and cereal, and many phone plans. It is hard to keep track of everything.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we stay for two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother. The hotel is special to us. The people who stay there are old-fashioned. We like good manners and privacy. We know each other's names but only say hello. It is hard to find this respect in hotels today.

**Othello**

A special show of Shakespeare's play "Othello" moved from Stratford to London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the show started last spring. I said Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello and I was wrong about his acting. I still think Othello should be older than Desdemona, but Mr. Fearon's acting is great. The whole cast is great. Some scenes are very memorable. One scene shows Cassio playing games with other young officers, and it gets out of control. Another scene shows Iago losing control and trying to calm down. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very sad. The show is exciting and full of tension. Don't miss it!

**Lake Vostok**

In the middle of Antarctica, there is a big lake called Lake Vostok. It is under almost 4 kilometers of ice. The water in the lake has not seen air or sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are very excited to study the lake and find out what lives there. They have been planning for two years to explore the lake. In the next few years, we will learn a lot about Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was something interesting on the radio last week. Some scientists are talking about why they want to be scientists. They want to know why we want to learn about things like atoms and black holes. They think it is more important to know if what scientists do is right. Science is a tool, and we should decide how to use it.

**Food**

Food is important and makes us happy. Many people like cooking. You don't need a special day or a fancy dish to cook. You can make a tasty soup with carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs in water. This is better than buying soup in a packet or can. You can also make a nice chocolate dessert in five minutes. Cooking shows care and love. We eat together at parties like birthdays and weddings. We don't eat takeaway food at weddings!

**In the Elevator**

Alistair tried to clean his office, but it was still messy. Papers were everywhere. He had many books and journals. He was going to meet Mallory. She was always on time and liked things neat. Alistair wondered what she would think of the mess. Mrs. Wilson, the cleaning lady, came to clean his apartment, but not his office. She thought Alistair was from a different place.

**Karen**

Karen wanted to be different from her mother. When she was twelve, her brother hit her eye with a golf club. She thought she was blind, but she was okay. The doctor said she was lucky. Karen felt she was saved for a reason.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty was walking on the grass. She was happy and sad. She learned something new in her small village. Dr. Bailey, her doctor, was not well. He was kind and listened to his patients. Miss Fogerty liked him very much. The village loved Dr. Bailey because he cared for everyone.

**Joanna's Lessons**

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She also writes books for children learning the piano. Joanna is very good at playing the piano. She plays many types of music like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for kids, a boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna played it and made the boy happy.

Joanna cares about how children learn the piano. She wrote a book called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World" for young learners.
