She is very busy with concerts and other projects, but she still wrote the book. Joanna thinks the first piano lessons are very important. She wants music to be fun and for everyone to enjoy.

When Joanna was young, her mother taught piano to many children. Joanna learned that music is for everyone, not just for very talented people. She believes everyone should try to learn the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French.

Some children learn piano quickly, but others take more time. Joanna is interested in helping all children enjoy music. She thinks some children stop learning because they feel too much pressure to be perfect.

Joanna's book is colorful and fun. It has a story and CDs with music. She wants learning to be fun. She says children should play all over the keyboard and use the pedals. As children learn more, they need to practice reading music. Joanna thinks practice is very important. She practices a lot every day. She says practice is more important than performing.

Joanna has tips for practice: know what you want to do, play the whole piece even with mistakes, and mix hard and easy pieces.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson said, "Easy writing is not fun to read." Good writing is hard. When I look at my old school essays, I see few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. Writing by hand was hard, so I wrote carefully. Computers make writing easy, but also sloppy. Writers spend a lot of time fixing computer drafts. Emails are not like handwritten letters. They are less personal. Many people write love emails now. This is good, but emails can be too strong and lose meaning. Handwriting has more care and character.

**The CD**

I looked at the CD. It was shiny. Mr. Warriston said, "They are amazing, right?" I agreed. He put the CD in the machine. "Some say they sound bad, but I like them," he said. I asked, "Do you turn them over like records?" He said, "No, you play one side." He thought and said, "Good question. You could have two sides." He smiled and said, "Let's find the best place to listen."

**Books versus Electronic Text**

Malcolm Bradbury said if matches came after lighters, we would think they are better. People say electronic text is like the invention of printing. But changes take time. In 1979, a book said books would disappear in the 1980s. This was wrong. Reading on a screen is hard, so people don't do it much. Computers make people read in small parts. But many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from start to finish. Computers don't help with reading everything.

**The Office**

Charles walked into a tidy office. The carpet was clean, and the desk was nice. Kathleen was organizing files. She said, "You need computers, Charles. This is too much." Charles liked the room but did not want computers. They talked about this many times. Kathleen was good with computers and helped Charles write a paper about them. She could make software do anything.

Text: "You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She was not really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She sometimes forgot because he was not supposed to be there. But now he was there all the time. He found that staying away caused problems. Lancelot thought about how he went from being an important advisor to someone always trying to fix problems. He had no place to park when he arrived at work. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder. "From that man in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see "A First Draft." Lancelot had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one. Ian Cuthbert got a lot of money in advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, but he was not easy to work with. Lancelot read the synopsis. It was not new. He closed the folder. Ian's manuscript was not coming soon. The synopsis was not brilliant. Lancelot remembered a famous author who was paid for each chapter. But Ian got a big advance. Lancelot studied modern languages at Oxford. He remembered when Ian was a big talent at Cambridge. Ian's friends took over British theatre quickly. Ian was very talented but did not use his talent. He was hard to work with. He was supposed to edit a big arts magazine, but it never came out. He had a contract with a fashion magazine but did not produce much. At meetings, Ian was clever but critical. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot thought "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the start.

Text: 'Breakfast in England

Breakfast is important for health, say experts. But in history, breakfast is new in England. In medieval times, people did not often talk about breakfast. Some travelers ate early before long trips, and sick people ate breakfast for health. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles. 

In the 1500s, breakfast became normal for everyone. Some say this is because there was more food. But there were also big social changes. People started working set hours, often very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary, not just for rich people.'

**Photography**

When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show. This choice depends on their skills, ideas, and culture. In this book, we will see how these things change the style and meaning of a photo. We will also see how people look at and feel about photos. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they see photos. But we can ask if the photo shows the real scene or the photographer's view. Is the moment in the photo important, or is the photo a symbol of something in the world?

**More than a Game**

For me, sport is more than just playing. The best people in sport believe in themselves. You need to focus if you want to be the best. Sport is hard, and you have to do it yourself. Sport teaches discipline and working with a team. My sport lets you be good alone, but it is also a team game. Like in life, you can do well alone, but remember others are there too. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has shown me new things and places. But you also have to give up a lot for these good things.

**Tuning In**

Some memories stay clear in our minds. For me, one special time was in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a bird singing in a tree. I don't have trouble sleeping, but the bird's song was beautiful. The bird's music reminded me of jazz and Indian music. It felt like the bird was making up the song as it went. I listened and enjoyed the music until I fell asleep.

Text: People have always talked about birds. What does this say about us? Paul Evans writes about a wren, a small bird, hitting the glass of a greenhouse. Is it a message or just a bird stuck? It could be both. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people watched wrens to see if they would have good or bad luck. Today, we still see wrens in pictures and decorations in homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, we still like wrens. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because birds are important in stories and culture. Our view of birds can change over time. For example, red kites were once common in London and seen as helpful. Later, they were seen as pests and almost disappeared, except in Wales. Now, they are protected and are a symbol of nature conservation. Our connection with birds is very old. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connect us to dreams. We like birds because they can fly and sing. They show us freedom. Some people think these feelings are old and not needed now, but they are still part of us. Birds show us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because we lose not only birds but also culture. Birds like the skylark and turtle dove are in poems and stories. Losing them is losing part of our culture. Stories and legends about birds are important. They help us feel connected to birds. Watching birds is exciting and not just about science. Birds are special, and the stories we tell help us understand them. The wren in the greenhouse makes us think about the past and the future.

**Maps**

A map shows where things are on Earth. It uses distance and direction. Long ago, people used time to say how far things were, like "a day's walk" or "a day's boat trip." This told more about how easy it was to travel than the real distance. 

Direction was not very important for travelers. They wanted to know, "Where do I go?" and "How far is it?" So, written directions were used instead of maps for a long time. Even today, some maps, like train maps, do not show true directions.

Early maps used signs to show important places. These signs were different in size to show how important they were. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and where they were made. To understand old maps, we need to know the signs they used.

Making maps better has been about showing distance and direction more accurately. Science helped map-making. For example, the magnetic compass helped find direction. New tools helped measure angles better. Learning about the world and the shape of the Earth also helped make better maps.

Maps became important for more people, like soldiers and scientists. Soldiers needed maps to show land features for battles. Scientists needed maps for studying history, geography, and more. Today, maps show many things, like weather and land use.

Map-making has changed a lot over time. Sometimes it moved forward, sometimes it did not. Old ideas stayed with new ones. Map-makers needed better tools to use new ideas. Old maps were often copied, so new ideas took time to be used. 

Maps are important for learning about the past. They show how people thought and worked. This makes studying old maps interesting and helpful.

Text: 'TIM RICE I went into a young man's nice room. The rest of the house was messy. The room had many records and a stereo player. The young man was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He was going to study history at Oxford, but he had nine months free. He wanted to be a famous composer like Richard Rodgers. I wanted to be a pop star for women, money, and fame. Andrew wanted me to write lyrics like Oscar Hammerstein. He played me some of his music, and I liked it. We decided to work together. I was still interested in pop music, but I thought Andrew was very talented. I was training to be a lawyer, but I wanted to try writing with Andrew. Andrew had an idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, who helped orphans. I wasn't sure about the idea, but Andrew's music was good. I started writing lyrics for the musical. I missed a day at the office to write. I didn't know it then, but I had changed my career.'

**Language**

People can talk to each other. Language is very important for humans. It is hard to think about life without language. If you see two or more people, they will probably talk. When people are alone, they talk to themselves, their pets, or even plants. Language is like an 'instinct'. This means people know how to talk like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not learn to make webs from school or special training.

**Climate and Weather**

Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They affect where animals and plants live. Climate can change how places look. For example, warm and wet places have many plants and animals, like in tropical jungles. Cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather changes every day and makes the climate. Air moves because the earth spins and because of the sun.

**Coffee**

I worked in a restaurant and had to make coffee. In Melbourne, a restaurant's coffee is very important. I learned a lot about making coffee and using the espresso machine. Making a good cup of coffee is not easy. I thought I would have to do other jobs, like cleaning ash-trays. But my boss was patient. He said, "Making coffee is both an art and a science," and it takes time to learn.

**Art on TV**

Why does TV often fail with art shows? Painting and sculpture are good for the camera. The camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in on details. But few TV shows make art interesting and fun to watch. One example is Robert Hughes's show, "American Visions." Hughes is a good critic. He has a strong personality and talks about American art. I thought the show would focus on great art. Instead, it talks about American history and culture in art and buildings.

**Dealing in Metals**

I worked as a metals dealer for 20 years. I took risks and made money. Metals are not controlled like other markets. With luck and knowledge, you can earn a lot. Risk is normal in this business. But now, more minerals are taken, and raw material costs are going down. Prices of most metals are half of what they were 20 years ago. I was asked to check claims against a big company using cheap materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its small islands are part of the Bahamas. There are 700 islands from Florida to Cuba. Each island is different and special. To travel in Abaco, you need a boat. If your room does not include a boat, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. You can also rent a boat. Sailing is very popular here. Abaco is called "The Sailing Capital of the World." The waters are great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands have beaches that stretch for 200 miles. At night, the lights of restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Text: 'Make Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK

At the Bamboo Bike Club, you can build your own bike. Engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan run this club. You get a custom bike frame and a fun weekend of building. 

It's Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is busy. You can hear machines working. This is the only place in the UK where you can build a bamboo bike. 

Bamboo bikes are becoming popular. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire make them. But they are expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame costs a lot of money. 

James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes cheaper. They worked in a shed in Wales for years. They wanted to sell frames, but then they had a new idea. They wanted to share the fun of making a bike. 

The Bamboo Bike Club is more like a community. James and Ian have other jobs too. James makes wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They run monthly courses. You get a custom bike frame and a fun weekend for a good price. 

On the first day, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You glue the tubes together. You use alloy tubes for parts that need to be very strong, like the handlebars. 

James and Ian help you with every step. They make sure everything is right. If you make a mistake, you can try again. Bamboo is good for this because you can use another piece. 

On Sunday, you wrap the joints with hemp and glue them. This makes the bike strong. You add a coating to make it waterproof. Then, you can add wheels, brakes, and other parts. 

The bike is strong and good for long rides. Ian rides his bike to work every day. James tested his bike off-road for three months. 

Bamboo bikes look different from metal bikes. They have a unique style. James and Ian say this is the point. 

Bamboo bikes are light and smooth to ride. They are fun and easy to ride. The price is less than £500.'

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York. She found a book by Dr. John Gray, a pop psychologist. She thought it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people talk better with each other. Many people in America like self-help books. These books are very popular and help the publishing business in New York. In Britain, many self-help books are also sold. But not all books are good. Many are not published because they are too similar to others. Editors look for books that can sell well. Dione Reverend says a good title is very important.

**Autobiographies**

An autobiography is a book about a person's life, written by that person. The writer should tell the truth, but sometimes they do not. They might leave out things that are too personal or not important. Some writers think they can show the truth better by making up stories. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. This is not always done to trick people.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Detective stories became popular in the late 1800s and early 1900s. These stories show the problems in society. A crime in the story shows human desires like greed. Solving the crime helps society work well again. In Hammett's stories, society is not perfect. The detective and the criminal are similar. The detective understands the criminal. He is both a good guy and a bit of a bad guy. This makes his job complicated.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. He says that to write well about science, you need to understand the culture of science. Only scientists can explain science well. Gould believes you should not make things too simple for readers. You can use simple words, but the ideas should stay the same. If readers feel you are talking down to them, they will not like your writing.

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym in London, it is very cold inside. The gym uses a lot of air-conditioning because it is very hot outside this summer. Sometimes, the gym feels as cold as the Arctic. Many places use too much air-conditioning. Instead, they could use other ways to stay cool. For example, they could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls to keep the heat out. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun. A long time ago, people used sundials to keep their clocks on time. But then, clocks and watches got better, and sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are interested in sundials again. David Harber, who makes sundials, says they are special because they connect us to the planets. When a sundial starts working, it feels magical. Sundials are calm and remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

I once saw older women painting china cups with flowers. They were very good at it, and their hands were steady. I thought only very talented people could do this. But when I went to a china-painting class, it was different. The people there just wanted to have fun. Even the teacher did not want to paint quickly like a machine. Everyone was there to enjoy painting.

Text: Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they booked the trip, the travel agent said they would be with a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss in Switzerland. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane. When they arrived, a woman said, "The coach will take us on." But the coach stopped at a hotel. Keith thought it was just an overnight stop. They were tired and didn't ask questions. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. Keith told the receptionist there was a mistake. They were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist said they were booked for twelve nights in Switzerland. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, said there are many holidays with similar tickets. She laughed and said they couldn't end up in a wildlife park. Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left them standing there. An old man named Nottage talked to them. He and his wife had a good night's sleep. Keith and Dawne walked outside. They didn't say it, but they knew it was ironic. They wanted a holiday away from elderly people, but ended up on a tour with them.

Text: 'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are learning from the explorer Ernest Shackleton. Most people in Britain know who Shackleton was. In America, he is becoming popular now. Books and movies about his life are being made. The American Museum of Natural History is having a big exhibition about him. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his leadership and communication skills. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, thinks Shackleton is a good example for handling business problems. Shackleton was a strong leader. He made tough decisions, like turning back from the South Pole to save his team. His ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice and sank, but he kept his team safe. Shackleton planned well, listened to his team, and was flexible. He believed in being optimistic and patient. He showed care for his team, like giving his gloves to a team member. People today admire Shackleton for his bravery and leadership.'

Text: 'Finding Food in Madagascar In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. It lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insects in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak and long tongue. The aye-aye uses its teeth and a long, thin finger. Scientists have studied how the aye-aye finds insects. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and Annabelle. He gave them logs with holes. Some holes had food, and some did not. The aye-ayes found the food without seeing or smelling it. Dr. Erickson thinks the aye-aye taps the wood with its finger and listens with its big ears. It can hear if there is a space inside the wood. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker and also like a bat because it uses sound to find food. It is also like a squirrel because its teeth grow all the time. The aye-aye can open nuts with its teeth and finger to eat the inside.'

Text: 'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we know what their lives were like? We often want to write things down about our lives, but we don't do it. Hannah Renier has an idea: she writes books about other people's lives. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary people. Hannah started this because she talked to her family and saw that many stories were disappearing. People like to tell their stories. They do it for their children and for the future. One man, 62 years old, shared his life story. He talked about his divorce and other things that were hard for him. He wants his family to learn from his life, but he hasn't let his children read it yet. He thinks they can read it after he is gone. Hannah sees that many people repeat patterns from their childhood. They marry people their parents like or do the opposite. People still have problems from their youth even when they are older. Hannah listens to people and writes their stories. She doesn't judge them. People can choose what to keep in the book. It's not about showing off. It's about remembering the past. Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. The book is special and costs about £3,000. Hannah gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost is high for many people. She thought more people would want this, but mostly people with money are interested.'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**

The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over 600 sculptures here. Remember, none of them are real. They are all copies made from the originals. Most were made in the late 1800s and early 1900s. The museum is in a special building with good natural light. The plaster casts let us see sculptures that are now in different museums together. You can see many famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**

Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has darkrooms and a gallery with different photo exhibitions. We have courses for everyone, like a Beginner's Course and Master Classes. Members can use the darkrooms. We help young photographers (ages 12 to 16) with our Young Members scheme. We sell photo books and materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**

The Sedgwick Museum has a big collection of fossils, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection from Dr. John Woodward. There are nearly 10,000 rare items in old cabinets. Adam Sedgwick added many things to the museum. The collection is arranged by age to show changes in life on Earth. The new Whewell Gallery has beautiful minerals and gems with labels explaining them.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**

This collection has over 400,000 air photos taken by university staff over 45 years. The university has its own plane at Cambridge Airport. The photos show the landscape and human activity from old times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall. You cannot borrow the photos, but you can buy copies. They take about a month to make.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**

The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is a unique tourist attraction. You can make wall hangings by rubbing over 100 brass plates from medieval tombs. The centre has copies of the plates to protect the originals. Brass plates were used as memorials in medieval Europe. Most original brasses were destroyed, but many are still in Britain. You can see many examples at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had small children for 35 years. I love being a father. I fed the baby this morning, and it made me happy. My children and I like the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. We are close, and now they are grown up, we are friends. I don't believe in hitting children. I have done it before, but I don't think it's right. I try to be there for my children if they need me. I don't call them to ask why they haven't called me. My parents did that, and I don't want to do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was 25 when my children were born. It was hard, but it also kept me young. As they grew up, they showed me new music and clothes. This helped me in my job. I missed some things when they were young, like concerts and sports days, because I was busy with work. But now, I can take them on holidays. They like to come to parties and events with us. They think my job is interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born when I started my job in politics. My wife and I wanted to spend time with them, but my job is busy. I try to take my children with me to work events on weekends. This way, they know what I do. I see more people bringing their kids to work now. We all want to include our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when my children, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I tried hard to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I lived next to each other for a while, but it was confusing for the kids. Kate says I was always there, but I think I treated them like adults too soon. I wish I had more rules and order. I still worry about my children, even the older ones.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids at 30. My wife and I had a nice house, so we decided to have a child. Having my daughter Betty made me think about who I am. Being a parent is special, but it also makes you like other parents. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but when I see her smile, it makes me happy. A baby's smile is very powerful.

**THEATRE SHOWS**

**A. Tamburlaine the Great**  
This play is about a strong warrior. The director, Terry Hands, makes it exciting and fast. Antony Sher plays the main role and does amazing stunts. You can watch it at the Swan Theatre in Stratford-upon-Avon. Call 01789 295623 for tickets.

**B. Women Laughing**  
This play is about two married couples. It starts happy but becomes serious. It talks about illness. The writer, Michael Wall, died young. You can see it at the Royal Court Theatre in London. Call 0207 730 1745 for tickets.

**C. Amphibians**  
This play is by Billy Roche. It is about fishing in Ireland. The play is funny and emotional. It ends with a big surprise. You can watch it at the Barbican 3 Pit Theatre in London. Call 0207 638 8891 for tickets.

**D. Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a thriller about a 'perfect murder'. Two writers want to kill each other. It has many surprises. You can see it at the Whitehall Theatre in London. Call 0207 867 1119 for tickets.

**E. The Alchemist**  
This comedy is about tricksters in the 17th century. The director, Sam Mendes, makes it very funny. You can watch it at the Barbican Theatre in London. Call 0207 638 8891 for tickets.

**F. The Madras House**  
This play is about fashion and women in the past. It was popular at the Edinburgh Festival. You can see it at the Lyric Theatre in London. Call 0208 741 2311 for tickets.

**G. Dreams from a Summer House**  
This is a musical about love. It is like Beauty and the Beast but set in London. The music is by John Pattison. You can watch it at the Stephen Joseph Theatre in Scarborough. Call 01 723 370541 for tickets.

**H. The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
This is a comedy by Shakespeare. Some parts are not very good, but the actors Ron Cook and Anton Lesser are funny. You can see it at the Shakespeare Theatre in Stratford-upon-Avon. Call 01789 295623 for tickets.

**I. The Voysey Inheritance**  
This play is about a lawyer who leaves a bad financial problem to his son. It is a great play. You can watch it at the Apollo Theatre in Oxford. Call 01865 244544 for tickets.

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game. They watch a strange bookshop. Emma sees her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into doing bad things. He tries to make her leave her friends. When Emma is in danger, the story becomes exciting. She is locked in a dark house. This book shows family life and friendship. It also warns that adults are not always good.

**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together. Their families were part of a train accident in 1915. Eight people died. They look at maps and stories to find out what happened. This book is clever and needs careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer is a girl who loves her dad's pigeons. Her dad leaves to find work, and Mary takes care of the pigeons. She wins prizes. The story is set in 1930. It shows that there are different ways to be smart. Readers will enjoy this story.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
Rose rents a house in the countryside with her two children. A scary cat and strange things in the house show why the last person left. The local people do not like Rose and her family. They are in danger. The story is exciting and a bit scary.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam is a boy who talks a lot. His cousin Lisa is cool and from a rich family. When Lisa's life changes, Sam helps her. They learn about family and reality. The story is slow in some parts but has gentle humor. Both boys and girls might like it.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Robbie works in Stanley's garden. At first, she likes him, but then she finds him strange. She discovers what he keeps in his aquarium. The story becomes a thriller. It is set in New Zealand and is interesting.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
Mick has problems at home and school. The story is told through letters and notes. Mick feels bad about himself. He finds confidence in a school play and with a kind teacher. The story is sad but very good.

**Title: Flying Without Gravity**

Tom Mumford, a journalist, joined students on a special flight to test ideas in weightlessness. The plane looked normal from the outside. It was a Boeing KC-135, made in 1964. Inside, it was different. It was like a long white tunnel with lights on the walls. Most seats were gone, except a few at the back. Thirteen students from Europe and America sat there. They had worked hard for a year to be on this flight. The European Space Agency asked students to think of fun experiments to do without gravity. The best ideas got a spot on this flight.

The plane flew like a big bird going up and down. At the top of each curve, the plane and everything inside became weightless for a few seconds. The students felt like they were closer to the moon than Earth. The plane took off smoothly, but soon it climbed steeply. The engines were loud, and we felt strange. Then, the engines stopped, and we floated. It was like dancing in silence. We couldn't tell which way was up or down.

After a few seconds, gravity came back, and we landed on the floor. Some students felt sick, but they had 30 curves to do their experiments. Dutch students studied a robotic cat to see how cats land on their feet. A German team looked at how metal joins work without gravity. Students from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films. They hope these sails can use the sun's light like a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours, we felt dizzy, but mostly excited. One student said, "It was unforgettable. I want to be an astronaut even more now."

Text: 'With the trees, I planted my stake in New Zealand JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER Jonathon Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology'. I had a time in my life when I didn't have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer here, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, 'If you plant trees, you can have it.' This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand. My father grew up there. They found land 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was okay for planting trees. I like land and was excited about planting trees. I worked in Australia on farms before, so I liked the idea. I started planting in 1968, and by 1972, we planted all 70 acres. In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. It was a happy time, even though it rained almost every day. I was very wet and cold. Every morning, I got ready to plant more trees. I had a helper who knew how to plant trees, which was good because I was new to it. You carry a bag with trees around your neck. When the bag is full, it is heavy, but it gets easier as it gets lighter. The hardest part was making straight lines. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then use poles to make straight lines. Once in line, you plant all the way down, turn around, and come back. I like hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you get used to planting and find a rhythm. You dig a hole, put the tree in, stamp it down, and move on. While working, I thought a lot about life and nature. I have been back to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow. It makes me happy to see them. I worry when I read about bad weather in New Zealand. But the trees are now 20 years old and doing well. In 1984, I took time off from teaching and went back alone for three months. I wrote my first book, Seeing Green, there. There is a small cabin on the land with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. I feel a strong connection to that place. It is where I feel most connected to the earth.

Text: 'CARING FOR BADGERS' "What now?" I thought when a helper gave me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset. We help orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs. They were about eight inches long. Their fur was soft, and they had black-and-white striped heads. Most badger cubs are born between January and March. They live underground and can die if orphaned. These cubs were found by builders. They accidentally broke into the badger home. The mother was dead, and the cubs were cold and hungry. I cleaned them and put them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. I fed them with a syringe and wiped them with a warm cloth to help them go to the toilet. For the first days, they ate every four hours. Soon, they drank from a bottle and moved around. They seemed happy. But after three weeks, Willow was sick. He died from a lung infection. I was sad but continued to care for the others. Then, a farmer brought another male cub. We named him Willow II. He was hard to feed but eventually learned. By April, the females ate creamed rice and other foods. Willow II was messy with his food. He liked sausages and then tried other foods. At five months, they ate cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, and small animals. By August, the cubs were active at night. We walked with them in the orchard. They played and chased each other. Sometimes they nipped us playfully. Other badgers came to our field looking for food. We protected our cubs with metal sheets. The local press took pictures of us with the badgers. We started a project to build a home for them. We made a sett with tunnels and a gate. It had three rooms, one with a glass side to see inside. The badgers explored it and moved in. A bus company helped with costs, and local firms gave materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they moved in. Now, I don't walk with them as much. They wake up late. Primrose joined another group, but Bluebell and Willow II still visit. This is their home now.

Text: 'Looking for True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass changes. Anjana Ahuja writes. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But he also did important work on compass changes, called 'declination'. Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors could not use their compasses correctly to find their way at sea. Halley was one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time. He sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the Atlantic Ocean. The first trip stopped early because of problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, Halley published a map showing compass changes in the oceans. This map helped sailors for over 100 years until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate. Dr. Clark, who likes sailing, wants to celebrate Halley's work by following his route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip. Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led a big expedition in Antarctica, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica, where he read about him. 'Halley had an amazing life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a scientist and explorer. He helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.' Dr. Clark's trip, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. He will take new measurements with better tools because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. This data will help improve the model of Earth's magnetic field. Dr. Clark says, 'We need to know true north to measure the magnetic field direction. We can use satellites for this.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also take similar measurements. Dr. Clark hopes his work will fill any gaps in the satellite's data. Halley's journey was the first scientific sea expedition, and he was the first civilian naval captain for this purpose. Dr. Clark has the experience for this trip. He spent two years in Antarctica and has sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the trip in four parts with different crews. Is Dr. Clark as dedicated as Halley? 'I am ready to spend eight months on this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I need a good reason to sail across the Atlantic again. Halley and his life give me that reason.'

Text: 'PEACOCKS AND THEIR TAILS

Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show their big, colorful tails to the female peacocks, called hens. This is a mystery that Charles Darwin, a famous scientist, thought about a lot. He wondered why peacocks have such big tails when it seems like they would make life harder.

Darwin said animals change over time through evolution. The best animals survive and have babies. But he thought peacocks' tails were different. He called it 'sexual selection' because he thought hens liked the tails just because they were pretty.

Another scientist, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought the tails showed that the peacocks were strong or healthy, even if people couldn't see it.

Today, scientists like Marion Petrie study the peacocks at Whipsnade. They want to know if hens really choose the peacocks with the biggest tails and if those peacocks are better in other ways.

They found that hens like peacocks with more eye-spots on their tails. But they are still checking if these peacocks are healthier or have better babies.

Another idea is from R A Fisher, who said that if a hen likes a peacock with a long tail, their children will also like long tails. This could make tails longer over time, just because they are pretty.

Scientists are still learning about why peacocks have such big tails.'

Text: 'THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS Tom Cunliffe talks about his dream boat, 'The Westerman'. He likes boats that mix old and new ideas. This week, there is a big boat show in London with many new boats. These boats have new technology. My boat is different. It is on a quiet river. It looks like it is 100 years old, but it was made last year. I like old boat designs, but I also use new technology. New technology helps make boats, but sometimes it makes sailing too easy. I think sailing should have some challenges. For example, I like to have a coal stove for warmth and a nice place to sleep. But I also think sailors should sometimes work with the sails. I do not like boats that feel like a house. My old boat, Hirta, had no electricity, no fridge, and no electronics, but it was a good boat. When I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I could not find a new boat I liked, so I built 'The Westerman'. The designer, Nigel Irens, first drew the boat on a napkin. Then he used a computer to make the design better. The boat is made of wood and is very strong. It has crossed the North Atlantic and won races. It looks old but is very good at sea. It shows that old ideas can still work well. The boat is made with special glue, so it does not let water in. It is like a modern boat but feels like an old one.'

Text: 'RELAX AND ENJOY Many hotels with spa services are very popular now. We asked five writers to visit some of these places. A. HENLOW GRANGE I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed rest. My room in the big old house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body exercises. The teachers were very good. I felt better every day. They have many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff were very nice and professional. Henlow will add a new swimming pool and a special diet room this year. You can also ride bicycles or walk in the garden. I felt great and full of energy after my stay. I want to go back. This is a great place for a busy woman to relax. Marcella D'Argy Smith B. SHRUBLAND HALL This place is very calm and relaxing. When I arrived, I had a medical check-up. They checked my weight and blood pressure. I was called a patient, which was strange because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem and helped me with exercises. Everyone gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and had a headache on the second day. My meals were simple, like grapefruit for breakfast and salads for lunch. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. Liz Gregory C. CAREYS MANOR Careys is not a health farm. It is a nice old manor with a gym and pool. The food is very tasty, but not for people counting calories. There is a spa bath, steam room, and sauna. They also have a sports injury clinic. I got advice for my shoulder pain. Careys is comfortable and relaxing. You can also explore the countryside. Beverly D'Silva D. CLIVEDEN Cliveden is a big country home and a five-star hotel. It has health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a pool, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. I enjoyed a great meal and then used the gym to burn calories. I also had a facial and massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options. Kay Letch E. SPRINGS HYDRO The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is delicious but has many calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I slept well after it. The place is modern and has many treatments. There are many guests, from football teams to friends. I would like to visit every month. Eve Cameron'

**Natural Talents**

Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means that the things that make us different from animals are new. Our ability to make art and do other human things comes from a small part of our genes. 

Animals and humans are not so different. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. 

The first human art we know about is from 35,000 years ago. This includes cave paintings and statues. People say human art is special because it is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive.

1. **Not Useful**: Human art does not help us survive or have babies. For example, birds sing to find a mate, but human art is different.

2. **For Beauty**: Humans make art for pleasure. We do not know if birds enjoy their songs, but they sing mostly in the breeding season, so it might not be for pleasure.

3. **Learned**: Human art is learned. People in different places have different art styles. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Birds, however, are born knowing their songs.

Human art changes quickly. For example, paintings from the 20th century look different from the Mona Lisa. But some chimpanzees, like Congo and Betsy, also made paintings. Congo made many paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in an art show in London in 1957, and many were sold.

These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal activities is not clear. Like human art, the ape paintings were not made for a specific purpose but for the painter's satisfaction. Some human art was also made for personal satisfaction, not to communicate with others.

Text: 'A Big Adventure The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories had brave explorers. These explorers had sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance. Today, you do not find such people in stories or real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore. Blackmore's big adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home. The team had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous. The team wanted to cross 1,200 kilometers of desert. Charles Blackmore wrote about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He started the expedition for fun and to learn more about himself. 'I always thought I would stay in the Army. I got a promotion, but I wanted to know who I was outside the Army. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was worried because nobody had done that route before. We went into it without knowing what to expect. It took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was kind to us.' When you read about the crossing, you might wonder why he said 'kind'. The team had many problems: sickness, very hot and cold temperatures, thirst, and losing some water. 'But', Blackmore said, 'when we were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some. We did not have the desert's big sandstorms. And we did not have the very cold weather that could stop us. But we had many problems. The sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels. Sometimes the camels fell on us. 'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. No planes flew over us. Once we were in the sand, we were alone. 'I knew I was mentally strong, but I was scared about my physical strength. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" I was very scared.' If it was like that at the start, how did they feel at the end? 'When you have walked 1,000 kilometers, you do not give up. You have gone through so much. We were very thin but strong. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything.' In the book, Blackmore talked about lying in the desert looking at the moon and thinking of his family. How did he feel about what his family went through? 'Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I doubt myself, I think of the desert and how we did it. I am proud of that expedition. But for a lifetime achievement, I think of my family and our happiness. The desert does not compare to that.' Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I want the challenge and open spaces. We had a purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of modern life.''

Text: Susan Harr is tired of technology. She turns off her gadgets and enjoys doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. But Susan thinks we depend too much on it. She had a problem with her word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her question if gadgets are worth it. Susan is letting her old gadgets stop working and not replacing them. She wonders if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets. 

Susan got rid of her color TV and now watches a small black-and-white one. This makes her think more about what she watches. She spends more time walking her dog, reading, and talking with family. Susan also enjoys sewing by hand now. Her old sewing machine is just a plant table. She finds sewing by hand relaxing and can listen to the radio or talk with friends while doing it. 

Susan likes the slow pace of hand sewing. She feels less rushed and enjoys simple tasks like washing dishes. She wonders if she really needs things like a freezer or microwave. She thinks she could save money by using fewer gadgets.

Text: 'Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker. He makes furniture like cupboards, tables, and bookcases. His workshop is in East London. It is under a railway arch. When I meet him, he seems busy and in a hurry. His workshop is full of wood and half-made furniture. Charles has been making furniture for ten years. He is very good at it. Many people want him to make furniture for them. He does not need to advertise because people talk about his good work. Charles likes to make simple and beautiful furniture. He does not like furniture that is made quickly and not well. He thinks some furniture today is not good. Charles learned to make furniture by himself. He asked questions and learned. Most of his work is for people who want special furniture. Some people ask him to make many things for their homes. He likes when people know what they want. Charles thinks some people try to make art with furniture, but he believes furniture should be useful. He is confident but also humble. He says, 'I am only making furniture.'

Text: 'Why do we sleep? People sleep for about one-third of their lives. Sleep is very important, but we are not sure why. Scientists have three main ideas. The first idea is that sleep helps our body stay healthy. When we sleep, our body fixes itself and gets ready for the next day. The second idea is that sleep helps us learn. When we sleep, our brain works on the things we learned during the day. Without sleep, we might not learn well. The third idea is that sleep gives us energy. We sleep to get more energy for the next day.'

Text: 'ECCENTRICS An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have small, unusual habits. It could be entering contests, collecting things, or writing letters to newspapers. Eccentricity means being unique. Inside us, there are two forces: one wants to be different, and the other wants to fit in. Most people want to fit in because they want to be liked and accepted. People with unusual hobbies or ideas often find others like them. They make clubs and have meetings to share their interests. They feel better in a group, even a small one. We all feel a pull between being different and fitting in. Sometimes, we want to show we are unique. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as I am." We can choose to be more unique. Some people become famous by being different, like Bob Dylan, a singer. He said, "When you know what you want and go for it, people might not understand." But being unique is not the same as being eccentric. If a singer wears strange clothes for attention, that is not eccentricity. But if they always act this way and cannot change, they might be eccentric. Eccentrics do not try to be different; they just are. They do not care what others think. They are not like people who play jokes, want attention, or hide from others. These people care about what others think. Eccentrics just live their lives in their own way.'

Text: 'Natural Books We asked four nature experts to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most. A Geoffrey Lean Choosing the author was easy. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in the field. None was more important than Barbara Ward. She was very involved in environmental issues in Europe after World War II. Her book, The Home of Man, is about the fast growth of cities and the need for sustainable development. It is the best book I have read on this topic. B Linda Bennett When I read Signals for Survival by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a gull colony. This book explains how animals communicate. After reading it, watching a gull colony becomes more interesting. You can see which birds are partners and where their boundaries are. Niko Tinbergen wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with artist Eric Ennion, who painted birds beautifully. This book is great for anyone who loves wildlife. C Lee Durrell My Family and Other Animals by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a great husband and a career in conservation. I read it while doing research in Madagascar. The book made me feel happy and inspired. It shows animals and people living together in harmony. This is a world worth saving. Gerald Durrell looked at all living things as a family. This is an important idea for everyone. D Bruce Pearson I found The Shell Bird Book by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. I loved the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already liked bird books and learned to identify birds. This book had more to offer, like chapters on bird migration and birds in art. It helped me appreciate birds and nature more. The book showed me that my emotional response to nature is as important as a scientific one. I realized I could combine my love for art with my interest in nature.'

Text: 'DO REVIEWS HELP SELL BOOKS? We asked five big British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said. Publisher A Reviews are very important for publishers. Many people buy books because of reviews. Authors and publishers feel sad if there are no reviews. Bad reviews are not so bad for publishers because they can still make people curious to read the book. Publisher B Publishers and newspapers both like book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain readers, and publishers want good reviews for their books. Reviews are better now than 40 years ago. Reviews help people know about books and authors. A good review can help sell books. Publisher C Reviews are very important for us. We publish books by authors who are not very famous, so we need reviews. Good reviews are better than advertisements. They help sell books. But reviews alone are not enough. We also need people to talk about the book and good marketing. Publisher D In the US, one review can make a book popular. In Britain, it is different. Sometimes, books with bad reviews sell well. It is hard to predict. Non-fiction reviews often talk more about the subject than the book. Publisher E Publishers and writers want good reviews. But do they sell books? I published a book with great reviews, but it did not sell well. People thought they knew the book from the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more. Now, a surprising reviewer or a fun review can make people want to buy the book.'

Text: 'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill. It started in early Egyptian times. Today, Graham Smith makes weathervanes by hand in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who do this. Graham makes special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique gift,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.' The most common weathervane design is a cockerel. But the first weathervane Graham made was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I saw that I could make many different designs,' he says. Graham decided to start a weathervane business. He used to work as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed roles. She went to work, and he stayed home to look after the children and build the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is fun and creative,' he says. 'I love designing.' Graham has made over 100 original designs. He works with fine detail and always asks the customer to approve the design before cutting it. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They want something different.' Graham does not want to expand his business. He wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs, and I enjoy making them,' he says. 'For a long time, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want special things for their homes. This helps my business.' Graham is very busy now. He sends flat-packed weathervanes to customers all over the world. American and Danish buyers are very interested. 'The price,' he says, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can make a special gift.'

Text: 'Beginner Takes All

Before it was published, The Horse Whisperer was a very popular book. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans. He talks about his inspiration and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was not happy. A film project he worked on for months failed. He was worried because he had not earned money for two years. He could have gone back to his old job, but he decided to write a book instead. He went to America for three months to learn about horses for his book.

The idea for the story came from a man he met in Dartmoor. The man told him about a horse that became wild. A gypsy talked to the horse and made it calm. These men are called 'horse whisperers'. Evans wanted to write a film script, but he decided to write a book instead.

In spring, he traveled across the US, learning about horses. He felt alone and worried about money. By August, he wrote half of the book. He showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent said it was "fine" and thought Evans might get $30,000 for it.

In October, they sent the first part of the book to publishers. Soon, his agent said they got an offer of $75,000. Evans was surprised. The book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. It was a record for a first novel. Hollywood studios also wanted it.

Evans did not want to write the film script. He wanted to stay away from the film business. He thought about writing another novel instead.

Text: 'Bobby Fischer and Chess Bobby Fischer is trying to play chess again after 20 years away. Chess is now a game for young people. Bobby Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky. Bobby won the first game, but he is not as strong as he was in 1972. He is 49 years old and not in good shape. Boris Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in 20 years. Now, chess is more about winning than about art or science. Players need to be strong and smart. They use a chess clock to make sure they play fast. If they don't, they lose the game. Games are longer now, and players don't take breaks. Young players have an advantage. Most top players are under 30 years old. Computers are important in chess now. They help players prepare for games. A computer can show many games and help find mistakes. Players work hard before a game to be ready. Chess games can last up to eight hours. Players must focus all the time. If they lose focus, they can lose the game. The chess clock makes the game tense. At the end, players must move fast. Winning feels great, but losing is very hard. Chess tournaments last many days. Players play every day. World championship matches are even harder. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov stopped because they were too tired. Bobby Fischer once said, "All I want to do is play chess." He left chess in 1972, which was surprising. Now, he is back. If he wins, he will get a lot of money. But if he wants to be the best again, it might be very difficult.'

**Fame and Success**

**A. Nick Grosso**  
Nick Grosso is a writer in his early 30s. He wrote three plays that people liked a lot. Now, he is making his first play, "Peaches," into a movie. He says, "It's a small movie, but we don't know how small. It won't cost more than 30 million pounds, but it could be as cheap as 30 pounds." Nick never read or saw a play before he wrote "Peaches." He says, "I didn't think it would be shown. It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because it's hard to film. I knew nothing then." Nick left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing school, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He says, "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted people to hear my writing because of the rhythm and rhyme. I was with people who liked the same things. It was the first time I enjoyed learning."

**B. Simon Pegg**  
Simon Pegg is a comedian, 28 years old. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a TV comedy series and finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon worked hard, even at university, performing in comedy clubs. He says, "University was very theoretical. It made me realize I liked comedy more than acting. People think comedy is hard, but if you have courage and good jokes, it's great to make people laugh." He worked with a comedy group called Funny Business. His work with Steve Coogan was very successful. Simon says, "Steve saw my show. I was a big fan of his, and he could see me copying him."

**C. Ciaran McMenamin**  
Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous as the lead in the TV series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." People liked it a lot, and now he can choose his work. He just finished school, but he was always good at acting. His mother encouraged him, and he acted in school plays and the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. Ciaran says, "I used acting to avoid homework, but then I wanted to do it because I was good at it and loved it." Now, he waits for praise but says, "When you're 18, you think you'll love fame, but it's not about that. It's about respect for good work."

**D. Neil Taylor**  
Neil Taylor is 25 years old and the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They signed a deal for three albums with Domino Records. Neil and Rick Brown, the other half of Matrix, are expected to be big stars when their song "Chimera" comes out. Neil says, "The record company wants a big hit, but I don't know. If two people buy it, I'll be happy." Neil worked hard for success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music. He says, "I played student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino. It was perfect timing. I was often sad and in bad bands, but I hope it was worth it."

**E. Stephen Richards**  
Stephen Richards is a 27-year-old poet and author. He won many prizes and awards. He is known in the poetry world and has been reading his poems for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. He says, "It's about obsessive love. I couldn't write it as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but didn't like education later. He didn't go to university at first but decided to when he got bored with his job. After university, he published a children's book in 1992. He says, "My parents thought I'd be a reader because I read a lot as a child." Moving from poetry to novels is brave for him. He says, "Poetry has a structure, so it's harder to make mistakes. Novels can be long, so there are more chances for bad words. I don't want to write without caring about quality."

A. Isabel is an art student. She is 31 years old. She likes historical romance books. Isabel wants to find Mr. Right. She worries about her knees. But she is hopeful. This helps her and others in the story. The book is fun and exciting.

B. This story is about a radio station in America. A boy named Francis works there. The station is called WLT Radio. It started to help sell sandwiches. The story is funny and takes us back to the 1940s and 1950s.

C. In this story, people talk to their partner's exes. Richard is a professor. He likes a Russian poet. She writes bad poems. She wants help for her brother. The story is funny and smart.

D. Two women and two men are best friends. They meet in London in the 1960s. One man, James, starts a newspaper. His friend Richard helps him. They both loved a woman who died. The story has love, ambition, and jealousy.

E. Ian Bedloe is in this story. He feels guilty about something. He takes care of his brother's three children. Ian is 40 years old. He becomes close to the youngest child, Daphne. The story is warm and funny.

Text: 'Volunteer tourism Four people talk about international volunteer work. A. Volunteer tourists help build homes or schools. They pay money to do this work. This money could help the local community more if given directly. Many young people volunteer during their gap year. They may not have special skills. Some people think they volunteer to help their careers, not just to help others. But, volunteering can help people learn to act kindly in their lives. B. Volunteering can help people from different countries understand each other better. It can help solve problems and make people work together. Volunteers and local communities can both benefit. But, if only rich people volunteer, it may not help poor communities much. Rich volunteers might use volunteering to help their own careers. C. Sometimes, volunteering can be more about helping the volunteer than the community. But, it can also help share skills and knowledge. Volunteering can make people care about fixing problems like poverty and unfairness. D. Volunteer tourism is about helping others. It can be a good thing. But, it might not change big problems in poor areas. Some people think it is just simple charity. Volunteer tourism should not be seen as the only way to help poor countries. It is important to understand the big reasons for poverty.'

Text: 'Choosing a Clock Radio Stuart Harris reports Many people listen to the radio in the morning and need an alarm to wake up. A clock radio can help. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios. One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. It also has a cassette player, which is nice for listening to tapes. The radio quality is good, but it is big. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case. This model was the best-looking and the winner. Paul Bridges loved it, but the clock sometimes stopped at 16.00. I liked the digital display. The snooze button is easy to find. It has a power back-up, so you don't have to reset it if the power goes out. But it is hard to set up. Tom Granger said another model with a lamp was 'tacky'. The lamp is hard to use, and the clock was difficult to set. The radio was hard to tune, and the buzzer was very loud. This model is popular with young people because of its bright colors. Tom Granger liked it because it was easy to set up. But the alarm can be 10 minutes early or late. Paul Bridges did not like this. The simplest and cheapest model was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning. Tom Granger liked this because it was easy to set up. The radio quality was fine, and the buzzer worked well.'

Text: 'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many places in the world, but not in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a ball when they are scared. This helps them because their spines point out. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They might try to run away first and roll into a ball if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They sleep under bushes or in holes. All hedgehogs can sleep through the winter, but some do not. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.'

Text: 'Great Sports Women Winning Women in Sports It is hard to be good at sports. Women have to work very hard. They train a lot and have little time for other things. But they are doing well and winning. Here, we talk to some great British sportswomen. A. Jill, 27, skier "I love skiing. It feels great to fly in the air and land well. But it can be scary. Sometimes the weather is bad, but I keep going. We train for ten months a year, so it is hard to have another job. I miss my friends, but I chose this. There are six men and three women in our team. We all compete together." B. Caroline, 22, cyclist "Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race. I won because I was the fastest! Now, I am a professional cyclist. I train for four hours every day and do other exercises too. My boyfriend is a cyclist, so he understands. I focus on cycling, not money." C. Annabel, 26, rower "Rowing is hard for girls because not many schools have it. Most girls start late, so it is hard to be good at it. Coaches do not stay long, so it is not well organized. But I love it and being fit. There is also a good social life." D. Ffyona, 24, long-distance walker "At 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I did not know how big it was! Walking in Australia was very hard. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I got the record! Men think women might fail, so it is hard to get sponsors." E. Lisa, 26, car racer "Some men do not like it when I do well in races. They try hard to beat me. Racing is hard, and I do not earn much money. Women have raced for a long time, but people thought they were strange. Now, more women are racing. I love trying to be perfect in each race." F. Alison, 28, triathlete "I wake up at 5.30 to swim three times a week. I need other days to rest. I also cycle or run in the evening. Sometimes I fall asleep at work! Racing is fun and social. Men and women race together, but the news talks more about men. Prize money is not as good for women, but we are working on it."'

Text: 'The Day I Met Picasso Richard Cork remembers meeting the famous artist Picasso when he was 18 years old. Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van before starting university. He ran out of money and got a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, he saw Picasso eating lunch at a restaurant. Richard was surprised because Picasso usually stayed away from people. He was with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Richard was nervous but asked Picasso to sign his sketchbook. Picasso signed it and drew a little picture too. Richard was very happy. Richard's friend told him to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Richard went back to Picasso's table and started drawing him. Picasso made funny faces and moved around, making it hard for Richard to draw. But then Picasso sat still, and Richard could draw him better. Picasso looked strong and young, even though he was almost 84 years old. After Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the drawing. Richard was shy but showed it to him. Picasso liked it and then drew a funny picture of Richard on the same page. Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso said no because he had already signed once. Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and to have his attention.'

Text: 'Shopping Tricks Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use tricks to make you buy more. A. Fresh Look Supermarkets know people like fresh food. They put fruits and vegetables at the front of the store. They might also have a bakery with the smell of fresh bread. The store might use green colors to look fresh. Most things they sell, like frozen food, are not fresh. B. Good Display Where products are in the store is important. Supermarkets know where people look the most. They put expensive or fast-selling items there. Shelves at eye level are popular. Special offers are in 'dump bins'. They put things like salad dressing near salad items. C. Staples Spread Out Supermarkets put things like bread and sugar far from the entrance. You have to pass other things to get them. Stores put popular items far away so you see other things on the way. D. Less is More Some stores show fewer items to look special. Next stores do this. They look like boutiques. Their clothes are not more special, but the store looks nice. E. Price Tricks Shoppers care about the total bill, not each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They might sell some things cheap to get you in the store. They buy in big amounts to get discounts. F. Price Tags In chainstores, people notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 is important. It also helps stop theft because staff must give change. G. Lighting Stores use special lights. Chainstores want natural light so clothes look the same outside. Supermarkets use lights to make food look good. H. Walking Paths Stores use different carpets to guide you. Some shoppers stay on the path. Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths and carpet for sales areas. I. In-store Ads When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of food. In the US, some trolleys have screens with ads. They show ads when you pass certain items. These are for people who buy on impulse.'

Text: 'Chris Bonnington is a famous mountain climber. He climbed Everest in 1985. He also climbed in Britain and the Alps. He wrote books like Quest for Adventure. Robin Knox-Johnston is a sailor. He sailed around the world alone in 1968-9. He broke a record sailing from New York to the Lizard in 10 days. Chris and Robin went to Greenland to sail and climb. They wrote a book about it called Sea, Ice and Rock. Chris met Robin in 1979. They went sailing and climbing together. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat. Chris showed Robin how to climb. Robin showed Chris how to sail. They became good friends. Robin wanted to go to Greenland. Chris found sailing boring. He liked being on land. Robin liked fixing things on the boat. The boat was small for six people. In Greenland, Chris led the climbing. It was hard and dangerous. Robin trusted Chris. They tried to climb Greenland's highest mountain. It was very difficult. They had to stop and try again. Robin was worried about the boat. On the way home, Chris felt Robin did not trust him. But Robin said it was not true. They became closer friends after the trip.'

Text: 'A history of the apple

Apples have been with us for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of this variety.

Prehistoric times 8,000 BC
People have eaten apples since very old times. In Britain, they ate apples and left the seeds. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, people kept apple halves for winter. These were small wild apples, not like the ones we eat today.

Norman times 1000 AD
The French learned to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. British monks worked on making new apples. Many apples today come from these old types.

Medieval times 1200
In the 1200s, some apples became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a dessert apple. The Costard was a cooking apple. But then, fewer apples were grown because of problems like droughts and wars. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent someone to France to learn about apples. This helped grow more apples in Britain.

Settler times 1750
By the 1600s, apples were very popular in Britain. People moving to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples with them. In America, a man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees.

Modern times 1850
In Iowa, a farmer found a new apple and called it 'Delicious'. It became very popular. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith found a new green apple. It was called 'Granny Smith' and became famous.

Today 1950
Apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from just a few types. Many people want more different kinds of apples. We need to keep many types of apples for the future.'

**Explore Worldwide - Small Group Adventures**
