Explore Worldwide offers exciting trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We travel to new and interesting places with special plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures like tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups are small, with about 16 people. This helps you learn more about the places we visit. You can meet local people and see their way of life.

**Different Ways to Travel**

We use many types of transport like buses, trains, boats, and even camels. Sometimes we walk. Each trip is different, depending on the place.

**Who Travels with Us?**

People from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA travel with us. They are usually between 25 and 55 years old. Some are couples, and some travel alone. You need to be healthy and ready for adventure.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique. We have 8 categories of adventures. Here are some examples:

- **Cultural/Adventure**: Trips focus on local cultures and history. We visit places like Egypt, India, and China. We often walk for 2-4 hours to see special sites.

- **Wildlife and Natural History**: Our safaris visit game parks to see animals. In Africa, you can walk in the wild or ride a canoe. We camp or stay in hotels.

- **Ethnic Encounters**: Meet tribal people like the Maya in Mexico or the Huli in Papua New Guinea. We travel in small groups to respect their culture.

- **Easy/Moderate Hiking**: Walk through countryside and stay in villages. We offer these trips in places like Spain, Greece, and Nepal.

- **Major Treks**: For strong walkers, we offer treks in mountains like the Himalayas. We stay with local people or camp.

- **Wilderness Experience**: Explore remote places like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert.

- **Sailtreks/Seatreks**: Travel by boat in places like Egypt and Turkey. Relax and enjoy the sea.

- **Raft and River Journeys**: Enjoy river trips in places like Peru and Nepal. No experience is needed, and safety is important.

Explore Worldwide offers a chance to see the world in a new way. Join us for an adventure!

Text: 'Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He visits a training camp in Kenya. The camp is near Mount Kenya, a big mountain with ice on top. Richard has trained in Kenya before, but this time he trains with Kenyan runners. He also runs his first race in Kenya. The air is thin because the camp is high up. This helps runners get better at using oxygen. Many Kenyan runners are very successful. Richard learns about their training. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet high. The runners live simply, with six people in one room. They run three times a day: in the morning, mid-morning, and afternoon. They run about 40 kilometers each day. On Sundays, they run 20 kilometers. The food is simple: tea, bread, eggs, ugali, stew, and vegetables. After running, they wash in streams. Richard thinks the simple life and hard training help Kenyan runners succeed.'

Text: 'Advertising Problems Today

Advertising is not doing well. This is not just because of the bad economy. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the economy got worse. The problem is bigger and is happening everywhere. Advertising has not changed with the economy. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now there are many brands and media. This means markets are smaller. Big brands should focus on small groups, but they often do not. This is where advertising is wrong.

Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you buy many things. Most are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. In a year, you might buy a few hundred brands. Big items like cars? Maybe one every three years. Clothes? Not many are advertised brands. Even with candy, medicine, and services, you probably buy less than 400 brands a year.

There are 32,500 advertised brands. Let's look at the 9,500 brands that spend a lot on advertising. Most people buy 400 of these, not all because of ads. That is about 4%. So, 96% of advertising might be wasted. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. For most, it is about 1 in 16 (6%). The other 15 (94%) are wasted.

You might think ads do not affect you. Most people think this. But it is not true. People do not buy most brands they see in ads. Waste is part of advertising. Not everyone will buy the brands they see. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest. But advertising can still work. It talks to many people to find the few who will buy. It is a cheap way to reach many people.

Smart targeting can help reduce waste. But advertisers cannot know who will respond. Even the best direct mail does not get 100% response. This is different from face-to-face selling. A salesman might sell to everyone he talks to, but media cannot do this. If advertisers knew who would buy, they would not need media. They could talk to people directly.

Any advertiser who gets one million new customers (2% of adults) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million new customers. Any ad campaign that gets 2% of people is very successful. This is a small part of the population. To reach them, mass media is the best way. But advertising needs to focus more on small groups to succeed.'

Text: 'Charles Clover visits Britain's most eco-friendly home. In Southwell, Nottinghamshire, there are two surprises. The first is Southwell Minster, an old cathedral with 'green' men carvings. The second is the 'autonomous house' by Robert and Brenda Vale. They use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with body heat and heat from appliances. The house looks traditional with a clay roof and is near the Minster. It blends with the town's old buildings and was approved by planners. The house is very quiet because it is super-insulated. Inside, it is peaceful. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air. Robert opens windows for air because the house is draught-proof. Even their cats have a special door. The Vales teach architecture and care about the environment. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house with no carbon emissions and no mains water. They use rainwater and have special toilets. Water from washing goes into the garden. They don't use a dishwasher to avoid strong detergents. The house is not medieval, but it has a tall hall. The Vales pay no water bills and use little electricity. They will soon have solar panels to make more electricity. The only heating is a small wood stove. In winter, the house stays warm without it. The house is comfortable because there are no draughts. The house is simple and cheap to build. It uses common materials and local workers. Big building companies do not like this idea.'

Text: 'The camera can lie Arthur Conan Doyle, who made the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, he saw photos of fairies in a garden and believed they were real. He wrote an article and showed the photos, saying fairies were amazing. In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They cut out fairy pictures from a book and put them with flowers. The photos look nice, but they show that cameras can lie. Today, we use computers to change photos, and it is not true that photos were always honest. From the start, photos could be changed.'

Text: 'THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my friends was very angry. 'Why didn't you stop years ago if it was so easy?' she asked. I couldn't explain how I went from smoking a lot every day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It was strange to me too. I went to a stop-smoking session with group therapy and hypnotherapy two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I didn't feel sick, and I thought I was healthier than my friends who didn't smoke. I went to the session in Birmingham to write an article about people trying to stop smoking. I said, 'I won't try to stop because I'm here to write, not to quit.' I liked smoking; it made me happy. The counsellor seemed to know something I didn't. We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. But when they told us to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. The idea of stopping smoking started to feel good. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I do anything? Stopping was easier than I thought. The need for nicotine went away after a few days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't. The hardest part was being at home on weekend mornings. Smoking was something to do when I was bored. I do miss smoking, but not too much. Doing things without smoking, like eating out or waiting for a plane, is new for me.'

Text: Dorothy Hodgkin was a British woman scientist. She won a Nobel prize for chemistry in 1964. She is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel prize. Many people in Britain do not know her name. Dorothy Hodgkin studied crystals. She solved the structure of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin. She was very good at her work. She also had three children and a husband who was often away. Her life shows how she balanced work and family. Scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin have interesting lives. It is important to know about them, just like we know about famous artists or writers.

Margaret and her special skill

Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business to drill wells. They use machines, but to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

Finding water this way is called dowsing. Some people think it is like a 'sixth sense'. There are different ideas about how it works. Some say it is because everything vibrates, and water vibrates more. Dowsers, like Margaret, might feel these vibrations.

Margaret is very busy, especially when there is little rain. She helps farmers, people with holiday homes, and golf-course developers. She looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. It is important to find clean water, away from farm waste. The water is in rocks, and it is clean if brought up straight. They also need electricity for the pump, so the well should be near power supplies.

Margaret starts by looking at a map with a pendulum. The pendulum swings over places with water. Then, she walks with her hazel stick to find the exact spot. When she is over water, she feels something special. The stick moves up when water is below. It is important to drill exactly where the stick shows. If Margaret and her husband do not agree on the spot, they keep looking.

Margaret's skill is not common, but it works well for her business. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This skill helps her find water and keep their business successful.

Text: 'We changed lives for a day! Have you ever wanted to live someone else's life for a day? We helped four people do just that. Read their stories. Amanda (23), a young mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy (30), who works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant. A. Amanda's story I had never been in a place like the restaurant before. It was dark and noisy, with many people. I was nervous! Being a mother is busy, but this was different! I had 15 minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but I dropped the drinks. I was embarrassed, but they laughed and said everyone does it at first. By 11.30 am, people were waiting outside, and I was nervous. I worried about remembering orders, but everything was on a computer. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and the music was loud. I had to say 'Pardon?' a lot, which was embarrassing. By 5 pm, I was very tired and wanted to rest my feet. I couldn't believe it was a 'quiet' day! I thought waitressing was easy, but you need to be friendly and calm. I'm shy, and I don't think I could work on a busy Saturday night. The pay wasn't great, and I didn't get any tips. I was happy to go back to my children. It seems easy after waitressing! B. Cindy's story I was nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but excited too. I thought I could handle the girls, but I was wrong! After Amanda left, I had to dress and feed the girls. I took Sophie to school and Katie to nursery. I thought I would have three hours of peace, but I had to clean the house and do the washing. At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then home for lunch. When Sophie came home, the real trouble started. They jumped on the sofa and screamed loudly! I thought they would get tired, but they didn't. I got them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to come downstairs. It was tiring to keep talking to them. I didn't know how tiring it was to look after two small children. You don't have time for yourself, and the responsibility is big. But I enjoyed the day. Rosemary (42) runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary (30), a teacher at a primary school. C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I wake up at 5.30 am, so waking up at 7 was nice! I didn't know what to wear. I couldn't wear farm clothes! At assembly, I saw about 400 pupils. I hoped I didn't stand out. Then it was time for a maths class. The children worked in groups, which was different from my school days. I helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and wanted a break, but teachers only have five minutes to eat. I went to a meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, there was a reading lesson and a French lesson. The children wanted to practice French with me, which showed my French was not good. Then we went to the hall for Physical Education. I was tired, but the children had lots of energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class. Teachers have more holidays, but I think I'll stay with farming! D. Hilary's story I arrived at the farm at 8.30 am, but Rosemary had been up for three hours! The farm has 100 cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. Rosemary also makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream. I spent the morning in the ice-cream shop, putting milk in bottles and ice-cream in cartons. It was hard not to taste the ice-cream! At lunchtime, I checked the sheep. I picked up a sheep that had fallen over. If they stay down for more than 12 hours, they could die. After feeding the calves, I started milking. It took two-and-a-half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day! I found it lonely. I missed the children. The worst part is not being able to leave work. The cows need milking every day, so it's hard to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days' holiday a year. Farming seems nice, but it's different in reality. The income is not regular, and the weather is a problem.'

Text: "A trumpet is not just for Christmas. Many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is one of them. He is from southern Sweden. His parents do not play music, but they gave him a trumpet for Christmas when he was eight. His father liked Louis Armstrong and bought a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a teacher for him. The teacher was Bo Nilsson from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra. Bo saw that Hakan had talent. Hakan is now a famous trumpet player. He plays new and old music. He likes to play alone, not in an orchestra. He studied in Paris with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra is like digging in the garden. Hakan entered a competition at 17. He did not win first prize, but he learned he could connect with people through music. Hakan does not like to explain why he can do this. He thinks it might ruin the magic of music."

**New Books in Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special story about people, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows the author's deep understanding of people.

B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with a husband who is an architect. She has her own business. Sheila is a working-class woman who takes care of her father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, both boys do not talk about what happened. Harriet is very worried about her son, and Sheila feels guilty. They meet and become friends. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives.

C. This book was nominated for a big prize. It tells the story of a small island in Scotland and its people. The main character, Throfinn Ragnarson, dreams about Scottish history. He leaves the island but comes back after World War II, learning to love the simple life of his ancestors.

D. The author wrote a new book after a big success. It is about Aurora Greenway, who is almost seventy. She lives with her friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is charming and kind, and she likes to have fun with her friends. By the end of the book, Aurora sees that time is passing and a new generation is coming. The author shows the sadness in everyday life.

E. Six different people go on a boat trip in the South Pacific with millionaire Logan Urquhart. The author describes their personal journeys. They learn about themselves and return home changed by their time on the sea. The author uses strong images to show themes of memory and awareness.

Text: 'Five Jobs Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and their normal workday. A. THE BRAIN SURGEON Name: Anne Age: 34 ANNE'S DAY "I wake up at 6.30am, go to the gym at 7am, and start work at 8am. I start surgery at 8.30am. I do surgery all day on Monday and Wednesday, and some Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some take all day. Sometimes I work ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. Deciding when to do surgery can be stressful. I don't feel stressed during surgery, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is a last option for patients, but when it works, it's great. From 10am to 1pm, I talk to patients about their surgeries. I like this and find it easy to talk to them. If they are upset, I try to comfort them, but I don't always have time. I leave work between 6pm and 8pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call and carry my pager. On holidays, I worry about my patients and dream about surgery. I find it hard to relax." B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER Name: Marita Age: 31 MARITA'S DAY "I wake up at 7.45am, leave home by 8.20am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9.15am. At 10.30am on Monday, we have a meeting to talk about our work and any problems. We work in teams. My team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. I spend three or four weeks designing and planning a project. Then I show my ideas to the client. If they like it, we plan the budget and hire photographers and illustrators. I talk to the printers and make sure everything is on time. I manage people and need to communicate well. Lunch is at 1pm for an hour. We try to go out, but sometimes I eat sandwiches and work. It's great when a client likes your work, but disappointing if they don't. I get home at 7.30pm or later. I find it hard to relax after work." C. THE CHAUFFEUR Name: Linda Age: 42 LINDA'S DAY "I wake up at 7am most days, but sometimes at 4.30am or 5am to meet flights. At 10.30 or 11am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. I have to watch my diet and exercise because my job is sitting down a lot. I have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People ask me about restaurants and shops, so I need to know the area well. Most jobs are booked in advance, so I can plan my route. Not everyone is polite, but most people are nice. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to sleep by 11pm." D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER Name: Tracy Age: 27 TRACY'S DAY "I wake up at 7am, leave home at 7.30am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I take care of gardens we designed. We work mostly in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At 11am, we have a big breakfast at a cafe. In summer, I work until 10pm; in winter, until 4.30pm. I listen to messages and return calls when I get home. If someone wants a garden, I meet them in the evening. We use old materials to make gardens look old. It's hard to relax because I hear the phone ring. I sleep well because the work is physical and tiring. It's a tough job, but it lets me be creative." E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER Name: Zena Age: 27 ZENA'S DAY "I arrive at the site by 8.30am. I help build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. I check that workers follow the plan and are safe. I solve problems and talk to the team. Workers start at 6am, so I ask what happened since I left. I look at paperwork and answer questions. Lunch is usually at 2pm for half an hour. I eat while working. I check the site when workers are on break. I leave the site at 6pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Work Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and go to the office by 7.30 am. I help our credit card users and work on the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I talk to card users and partner companies. I start my day by organizing and checking emails. I also manage advertising and meet with marketing staff. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different places in Europe once or twice a week. In London, I leave work around 6.30 pm or 7.00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10.00 am and check the mail. I listen to music tapes and talk to producers. I have meetings about artists and their projects. I help choose songs and musicians for albums. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7.00 pm and often go to music shows. I sometimes visit artists in the studio. I get home around 1.00 am and listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**
I get up at 8.00 am and arrive at work by 9.30 am. I check the diary and meet clients. I enjoy selling furniture. We sell antiques and sometimes need to fix them. I work with restorers and read about the antiques business. I do the accounts once a month. I go home at 5.30 pm and relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work in shifts. On early shifts, I leave home at 6.00 am. I start work at 7.00 am and control planes with a team. We work in turns and manage many flights, especially in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I read about new rules. The job is stressful, and I want to become a manager one day.

**E. Shop Manager**
On early shifts, I leave home by 8.00 am. I set up the sales system and help customers find books. I talk to publishers about new books. I decide how many books to order. The early shift ends at 5.45 pm. On late shifts, I close the shop and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7.00 am and go to work by 8.45 am. I talk to reporters and check for risks in other countries. I write news updates and forecasts. I meet with editors and send my reports. I travel to Africa three times a year. I leave work at 6.00 pm and find it hard to relax.

Text: 'Career Power: Be a Leader at Work

A. What makes a good leader? A leader is someone who inspires and helps others. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says leadership is about 'making things happen with people who are as excited as you are'. A good leader should speak clearly and with confidence. Dixon says, 'It's about saying "I believe" instead of "I think".'

B. John van Maurik, a teacher of leadership, says, 'Many people can be leaders, but they don't know it. Becoming a leader is about finding and using your hidden talents.' We are all born with the ability to lead, but we need the right chance to show it. We can see leaders like Mahatma Gandhi or Richard Branson, but it can be hard to see leadership in our own jobs. Still, being a leader is very important for good management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might both be good at planning and meeting goals. But how did they do it? The best leader made you feel motivated and supported. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first one led well; the second one just managed badly.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within rules. Leaders make new paths. 'A good manager can keep a company running,' says Michael Shea, who wrote about leadership. 'But a good leader can change a company or team for the better.'

E. Whether you are the boss or not, you can learn to be a better leader. Here are some tips:

* Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find what you care about. When you feel ready to lead, use that energy and take action.
* Think of yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is strong. Know it.
* Working with others is good, but sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their views, try leading. See how things change.

F. * Leadership takes practice. You learn by leading, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to share tasks and motivate others.
* Your way of leading might not work for everyone. Keep improving your communication skills. You don't have to be liked, but your ideas should be.
* Be visible and easy to reach for those who matter. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.'

**Films on Video**

Film critic Nick James talks about some new films.

**A. Abyss**

Before Titanic, director James Cameron made this exciting movie. It is about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a submarine deep underwater. The leader, Bud, and his team are brave and funny. The special effects are very good, but the story is simple.

**B. The Thin Red Line**

This movie is about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is based on a book by James Jones. The director, Andrew Marton, made a traditional war movie. It focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. The movie has some good parts, like a dream about the soldier's wife.

**C. On Guard**

This movie is based on a book from 1875. It is a fun adventure with swords and action. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, and Daniel Auteuil is a serious swordsman. The movie is full of exciting costumes and action.

**D. Character**

This story takes place in old Rotterdam. The movie looks like a museum with its detailed costumes and sets. Jan Decleir plays a strict man named Dreverhaven. He is not nice to his son. The movie focuses a lot on the time period.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**

This is a famous Western movie. The sound is very clear, and the music is exciting. The story is about three men: the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach). They are all looking for treasure.

**F. The Longest Day**

This is a long war movie with many stars. It shows the planning of a big invasion. The movie is impressive but better on a big screen. On video, it is not as exciting.

**BOOK A**  
Steve Martin's "Compelling Evidence" is a great story. A lawyer starts a new job after leaving a big law firm. He must defend his boss's wife, who is on trial for her husband's murder. The trial is exciting, with a surprise ending. This is a great first book.

**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" starts with action. Sigismondo, a problem-solver for rich people in Italy, faces politics and murder. We know he will find the guilty people. The story is a bit long, but still very good.

**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" is by new writer Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector. She starts investigating when a man dies near her. She faces many challenges but is strong and smart. Leah is a great character.

**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker is about Spenser, a private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to stop drug dealers in Boston. The story has fast talking and some action. It is fun to read.

**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They look into a crime at a famous actress's daughter's house. The writing is easy to read and interesting.

**BOOK F**  
Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock wrote "Blood Red, Snow White" together. It is about a lawyer and his female client. The story is outside the courtroom. It has romance, money, and action. It is a good suspense story.

**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw is about actor Philip Fletcher. He is in a movie about Robin Hood. The characters are funny, but the story is not as good as usual.

**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" by Lawrence Gough is about Canadian police. They look for a smart bank robber who targets women. The story is exciting and better than most detective books.

Text: Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his job to go backpacking. He wants to travel in South East Asia for a year. Tim is nervous because he is older now. After university, he traveled in North and South America for two years. Then, he got a job, bought a flat, and earned a salary. But he felt he was losing his happiness for money. When he quit his job, he felt free. Many of his friends are married with children. They have responsibilities, but Tim does not. He is not in a relationship and has no big career plans. He wants to enjoy his freedom.

Tim is nervous about renting his flat and planning his trip. He is also worried about living simply again and meeting younger backpackers. But many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel. They want to leave their jobs and explore the world. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says people now know they can have adventures if they are brave and organized.

Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, are traveling for a year. Danny says he is ready to risk his job for the trip. Matt, who was in the Army, traveled for a year to change his way of thinking. Many people travel to think about their lives and find happiness.

Some companies let people take breaks from work to travel. Dan Hiscocks from Travellerseye says more people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. They want to find what makes them happy. Ben, a 32-year-old, is going to Central America. He is not running away but looking for something new. He is nervous about leaving his routine.

Tim is excited about his trip. He wants to enjoy life and have new experiences. Many people like Tim want to travel and find happiness.

Text: 'Working from Home Georgina McGuiness stopped working as a journalist for a long time. She felt she didn't know much about new technology. Here, she tells how she changed her home into a good place to work. Two years ago, at Christmas, I turned 37. I thought it was time to start my career in journalism again. My skills were old. I used to work with a typewriter. Now, many jobs wanted people who knew how to use computers. I didn't know how to use a computer. I was afraid of technology. I didn't even know how to use a calculator or the timer on the video. I needed to learn quickly. I entered a competition in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer package. We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We started learning about the Internet and using words like cyberspace and surfing. We talked to people around the world on the Internet. The children stopped watching TV. I made a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem. I could work from home and still take the children to school. The children were good with computers because they learned at school. I was scared I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I learned the basic skills. It was easy and made sense. I started writing for a magazine, about two articles a month. I felt happy because I could work and be with my family. The computer helped me be organized. I used to lose important papers. Now, I use spreadsheets to keep track of money. I save time with pre-made invoices and letterheads. The Internet helps me find information for my stories. I can talk to other journalists online. But working from home can be lonely. There are distractions, like housework. The children and I sometimes argue about who can use the computer. Many people now have computers at home. They like not having to travel to work. A report says the average computer user is 38 years old and well-educated. Most have a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM and modem. I am doing well with my computer skills. Maybe one day, I will send my work to a newspaper in Melbourne or start my own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless.'

Text: 'The Tartan Museum The new Museum of Scotland is in Edinburgh. It has modern buildings that look different from the old city. Sally Varlow visited the museum before it opened. You cannot miss it. The museum is on Chambers Street. It has a big, yellow tower and buildings that look like a piece of cheese. Last winter, people had different opinions about the building. Some liked it and called it a 'masterpiece', while others did not like it. This winter, the museum is almost ready to open. Inside, there are many stories and historic objects. The museum shows Scotland's history with important things like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, says the museum is for everyone, not just experts. He wants people to enjoy their visit. The museum does not use fake scenes from the past. Dr. Clarke believes people should see the truth. The museum uses explanation panels and some computers to tell the stories. Inside, there are many different spaces and galleries. There is a lot of light and room to see everything. The museum also has a Discovery Centre for children. Kids wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a hands-on centre. The Twentieth Century gallery is on the top floor. It shows objects that people in Scotland think are important, like an electric guitar and televisions. Dr. Clarke says objects help us see the past. The modern buildings look good inside, but some people are not sure if they fit in the old city.'

Text: 'The end of print may take some time. Change can be scary for some people. But change can also be nice. Moving from newspapers to online news is not easy. Many people think it will happen soon. Newspaper sales are going down, but more people visit newspaper websites. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian sell fewer papers, but their websites are popular. 

In some places, newspaper sales are not falling much. In Asia, newspaper sales are going up. Magazines are also doing well. They sold 5.4% more last year. Books are interesting too. E-readers like Kindle are selling a lot. But people still buy paper books. 

Young people still read newspapers. In the UK, many young people read national newspapers. In Germany and France, newspaper sales are not falling much. 

In the USA, online ads are not making as much money as before. Many newspapers now charge for online news. They offer deals with both print and online news. Print is still important for selling online news. Print ads make more money than online ads. 

Keeping both print and online news is hard and costs a lot. But newspapers are still well-known in print. Online, it is harder to be noticed.'

**Taking Photos of People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually more interesting than one without. But, taking good photos of people can be hard. You need to think about how they move and their expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act differently.

**A. Group Photos**

When taking group photos, don't make people stand in straight lines. Ask them to stand at different angles or levels. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces.

**B. Posing for Photos**

People often feel stiff in front of the camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. They can fold their hands or put them in their pockets.

**C. Taking the Photo**

Don't pretend you are not taking a photo. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their photo taken. They might feel shy at first, but they usually like it. Help them by giving directions.

**D. Eye Contact**

A photo is strong if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They don't have to smile. Remind them to look just before you take the photo. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.

**E. Looking at Something**

Instead of looking at the camera, the person can look at something else in the photo. This can make the photo interesting. It looks like you are watching them without them knowing.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures show a lot about a person. A laughing child makes us smile. A sad face makes us feel sad too. Look for familiar expressions like winks, anger, or thumbs-up.

**G. Backgrounds**

A background can make a photo more interesting. Make sure the background is not too busy. Focus on the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**

When people talk, argue, or work together, you can take good photos. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Show how one person reacts to another.

**I. People and Places**

Many photos are taken on holiday. To show people with a nice background, use a wide-angle lens. Move back to get the whole scene. Ask people to stand close to the camera. A good photo shows both the people and the place.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you want the photo. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose. But, family photos can be more fun if they are not posed. Candid photos show real moments and are more lively. They help you remember better in the future.

Text: 'Sarah's Art Sarah Janson is an artist. She makes paintings that look real. This style is called trompe-l'oeil. Sarah does not sign her paintings unless someone asks her to. She thinks the art is more important than the artist. Sarah is shy and does not like to talk about herself. She also does not like taking photos. But when she feels comfortable, she is funny and interesting. Sarah has been making trompe-l'oeil art for sixteen years. She studied drawing in art school and worked in a publishing house. She learned a lot about details from illustrating. This helps her in her trompe-l'oeil art. Sarah says you cannot learn trompe-l'oeil from a school. You learn it by looking at things closely. She is always learning and says she is not perfect. For example, she says she cannot paint bread well. Sarah has done many big projects. Her work is very good and different from others. She likes to make art that tricks the eye and makes people think. Sarah enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. She says it is important to listen to what clients want. Many clients become her friends. Sarah is thankful for clients who let her paint on their walls. She is busy because people like her work. Even though she is shy, her art is special and deserves to be known.'

Text: 'Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success Daniel Goleman talks about 'people skills' that are important for success at work. A The rules for work are changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or our training, but also by how we handle ourselves and others. This is important for getting jobs and promotions. These skills can show who will do well and who will not. They are important for future jobs too. These skills are not what we learned in school. Doing well in exams is not important here. It is about social skills and personal qualities like being able to start things, understand others, adapt, and persuade. These are called emotional intelligence. B Today, job security is not guaranteed, so personal qualities are important at work. These have been called 'character', 'personality', or 'soft skills'. Now, they are called 'emotional intelligence'. This means knowing and controlling our own and others' feelings, and using them to think and act. At work, it includes self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. Some think it means 'being nice', but sometimes it means telling the truth even if it is hard. It is not about showing all feelings, but managing them well to work together towards a goal. C More businesses see that emotional intelligence is important for management. The harder the job, the more it matters. Lack of these skills can make it hard to use technical skills. Some people succeed without emotional intelligence, but as work gets more complex, companies where people work well together do better. In today's workplace, teamwork and customer focus make emotional skills important for success everywhere. D IQ changes little, but emotional intelligence grows as we learn from life. We can get better at handling emotions, motivating ourselves, and understanding others. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence and add these skills to help us. This is important when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if ignored, other things do not work as well.'

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and phones make it easy to take pictures of news events. Social media has changed how people share these pictures. Some journalists use social media to find pictures of news events. But sometimes, they use these pictures without asking. There is a rule that says they can use pictures without asking if it is very important. But people still talk about if this is right or wrong. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures of a news event. This means these pictures are important for the media. To keep a good relationship with people, the media should make sure to ask for permission and give rewards for these pictures.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

**Acupuncture is very old.**  
Acupuncture is 2,000 years old. It comes from China. It is part of Chinese medicine. This includes herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used for many health problems. In the West, it is mostly used for pain. Some doctors, nurses, and therapists use it for pain relief.

**What is acupuncture?**  
Chinese medicine says health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. Energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), moves in the body along lines called meridians. There are 12 main meridians. Each is linked to an organ. If Qi is blocked, the body is not in balance. This can cause illness. An acupuncturist checks your wrist pulse, tongue, and appearance. They ask about your health, mood, and habits. They use thin needles in the skin. They may also use heat or pressure to help Qi flow.

**Acupuncture points**  
Acupuncture points are on meridians. They may not be near the pain. People feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This shows the needle has reached the Qi. There are over 300 main points.

**How does it work?**  
Doctors in the West think acupuncture can help with pain. They have scientific ideas about how it works. It may block pain signals to the brain. It may also release natural painkillers in the body.

**What pain can be treated?**  
People with long-term pain often try acupuncture. It is used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. It may also help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in very sick people.

**Modern use of acupuncture**  
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years. In the 1950s, it started being used instead of anesthesia in surgery. This showed some doctors outside China that acupuncture works. In China, it is used in many surgeries. Needles may be used alone or with electricity or drugs. It is said to reduce pain, but it is different for each person. Acupuncture does not have the side effects of regular anesthesia.

**Is it always effective?**  
It is hard to test acupuncture in studies. But some studies show 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with long-term pain. Acupuncturists say it works for many people. It may take six or seven visits to feel better, but some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.

**A different view of pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just symptoms. They spend time finding out what causes the pain. They ask if the pain is worse in cold, heat, damp, or wind. They also ask if the pain is sharp, dull, or burning. This helps decide how to treat the pain. Western doctors may not ask these questions.

**Traditional or not?**  
Some doctors have traditional acupuncture training. Others use scientific ideas. Traditional acupuncturists believe Chinese medicine can make deep changes for a longer cure. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist. They should send you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She looks like a quiet and strong person. Some people think she could have been a school headmistress. But she is actually a bit shy. She says her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is like her. He likes to solve crimes alone, and so does she. She needs to be alone when she writes. 

P.D. James has written 12 detective novels. Many people around the world read her books. She likes the books of her friend Ruth Rendell, who also writes as Barbara Vine. P.D. James enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also reads books by men like Graham Greene.

P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband, Connor Bantry White, in Cambridge. He was a doctor and became very sick after the Second World War. P.D. James had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped take care of the children.

She worked for the National Health Service and later for the Home Office. She worked with the police and in juvenile crime. She saw many dead bodies but was more interested in writing stories. She liked the challenge of writing crime novels. She wanted to be a writer and thought detective stories were a good start. Writing these stories helped her bring order to chaos. She believes solving a crime shows the importance of life.

Text: 'Handwriting Can Show Who You Are Some people think handwriting can show a person's character. In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might need to give a sample of your handwriting. Companies use handwriting analysis, called graphology, to see if you are right for the job. Graphology is seen as a real science in many places. It can help find illnesses like heart disease and cancer. It can also show how a person feels or if they have emotional problems. Big companies use graphologists to look at handwriting for important jobs. But many doctors do not believe in graphology. Patricia Marne, a graphologist for over 20 years, thinks doctors should take it seriously. She says handwriting can show social class, intelligence, and if a person is honest or not. It can also show if someone might be a criminal. Criminals often have messy handwriting. Ms. Marne says handwriting can show if a person is under stress or has health problems. Changes in handwriting can mean something serious has happened. She also says handwriting can show if a person is creative or a loner. It takes six years to learn how to read handwriting well. Ms. Marne believes more research will make graphology a real science. But some doctors say handwriting only shows how a person was taught to write and nothing more.'

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy, healthy team, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. Our expert team included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple. There is no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and windows open to the street. The team of seven people seems happy and adapts to the seasons by opening doors or using electric heaters. They have created a homely work environment without much outside control.
Ergonomist: The furniture is mixed and often creates bad working positions. Chairs are old and many are broken. However, the team has a varied work schedule, which helps reduce tiredness and boredom.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. The office is the right size for knowing what others are doing but also having personal space. It is attractive and fun, showing efficiency and creativity.

Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable and the air quality is good, helped by a No Smoking policy.
Ergonomist: Chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good, but the office is impersonal with grey walls.
Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for planners and a poster. Staff relationships are okay, but the office could be better if desks were arranged for easier information sharing.

Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: The office feels like a glass case. Despite smokers, the air is not stale.
Ergonomist: The office is standard and uninspiring. Desks are just adequate, and some chairs do not meet requirements.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and use technology well. The office is busy, but the wood panels and brown carpet make it look dull.

Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: The air-conditioning is poor, and the office is dusty and cluttered.
Ergonomist: The furniture is not suitable for a high-tech office. Chairs are old and not adjustable.
Occupational Psychologist: The office is dirty and needs cleaning. There is little conversation, and everyone seems stressed. The company should encourage teamwork.'

Chewing Gum Culture

Chewing gum is popular, and Americans chew 12 million pieces every day. It has less than ten calories per piece. Chewing gum is a type of food, so it must follow the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration. 

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and make it chewy. But in the past, it was different. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found in Greece and Turkey. Greek women used it to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. 

In America, colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States sold spruce gum, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, growing sapodilla trees for chicle has not been successful. As the gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were created.

Today, a few chicle gatherers, called chicleros, still work in difficult conditions. They travel long distances in hot, humid forests to collect chicle. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicleros climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry to a camp to boil and make into bricks. Life at the camp is hard, with simple food and local alcohol.

The chicleros worry about their jobs. The United States used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but now only 200 tonnes are collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales increase, manufacturers use synthetic materials to save money and meet demand.

Gum producers are finding new ways to sell their products. They say gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces tooth decay. Chewing gum for 20 minutes can increase saliva, which helps protect teeth. Research continues on new textures and flavors. Glycerine and vegetable oils are used in gum, and most new flavors are artificial. However, some flavors still need natural ingredients. In America, 137 square kilometers are used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**Remote Hotels**

**A. India - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel is simple, with hot water in buckets, but this makes it special.

**B. New Zealand - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. It is in beautiful countryside, high up in the mountains. After a long climb, you can relax in luxury with music playing.

**C. Mauritius - Beachcomber Paradis Hotel**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in Mauritius. The road to the hotel passes empty beaches. The hotel is big, but you can find peace on its long private beach. In the evening, the beach feels far away from everything.

**D. St Lucia - Ladera Hotel, St Lucia**  
The Ladera Hotel is in a quiet place in St Lucia. It is 1,000 feet high, with rooms open to the view of the Caribbean Sea. The style is colonial, with wooden furniture and netted beds.

**E. Turkey - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, near Istanbul. There are no cars, only horse carriages. The hotel is a white wooden building with red domes. It is a little old now but still charming.

**F. France - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
In the village of Etoges, there is a 17th-century chateau. It has a moat with swans and 20 different rooms. Some rooms have four-poster beds. There are special weekend offers with breakfast, dinner, and champagne.

**G. Kenya - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Nairobi. It is a good stop for travelers. The hotel has gardens and is away from the busy city. Guests enjoy watching the sunset and having a nice dinner.

**H. Italy - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Hotel Splendido in Portofino was first visited by the Duke of Windsor. Many famous people have stayed here. The hotel is an old monastery and is very beautiful. The restaurant serves simple, delicious food.

**The Hotel Inspector**

Sue Brown works as a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. 

Sue visits the Globe Hotel for an inspection. Right away, there are problems. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue. Sue says, "Very poor." This is a common mistake she sees in hotels.

The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the top hotels. But Sue is not happy. The entrance from the car park is not welcoming. There is a long, empty corridor to the hotel door. Sue says, "Not what I expected."

Things get worse. The receptionist cannot find Sue's booking. Most rooms are empty, but the room Sue gets is not nice. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall.

Sue is known for being tough. People called her "The Woman in Black," but she says she is not too tough. The next morning, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He looks worried. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that room.

Sue also says good things. She likes Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress. Dinner is good, and the hotel keeps its two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks how to get three rosettes. Sue says, "Not serve a pudding that collapses."

Sue's job is to tell hotels what is wrong. Sometimes people get upset. Once, a woman said Sue got her son fired because he served apple pie with his fingers. Sue writes a report for the hotel. They pay for her advice.

The good news for the Globe Hotel is they keep their red stars. But another inspector will come in two months to check again. Greaves says, "Good," but he does not look happy.

Text: 'Doug Scott is a mountain climber. He climbed the highest mountain on each continent, called the Seven Summits. Here are some of his stories:

A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m) Doug and his friend Dougal were close to the top of Mt. Everest. They were in a snow cave. Dougal started talking to someone who was not there. Doug thought it was because of the lack of oxygen. Doug was worried about his feet getting too cold. He remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes. Doug felt calm because Dougal was a good partner. They reached the top.

B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m) In April 1976, Doug and Dougal went to climb Mt. McKinley. They carried their own food and equipment. The mountain was very hard to climb. The air felt thinner than it should have. They were very tired but reached the top.

C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m) In September 1976, Doug and Paul went to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up climbing Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle. They found a trail and followed it. They reached the top using the Umbwe route.

D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m) In January 1992, Doug and his wife Sharu went to climb Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil. They decided to take an easier path because of time. They reached the top and met other climbers at the base camp.

E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m) In November 1992, Doug went to climb Vinson Massif. The weather was very cold and windy. They reached the top in 8 hours, but it was hard to see because of the storm.

F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m) In 1994, Doug and his team went to climb Elbrus. They used a cableway to go up part of the mountain. They thought they reached the top but had to walk more. They went back to the refuge and then down the mountain.

G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m) Doug and his team wanted to climb Carstensz Pyramid and meet the local Dani people. They were warned about bandits but continued. They reached the top, and Doug completed his goal of climbing the Seven Summits.'

Text: 'Style Merchants Style is important in our lives today. It is in clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley talks about fashion trends this year. Ned Ingham: Dress Designer Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says, 'People should choose simple styles, not stiff or frilly dresses.' Ingham started drawing wedding dresses when he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. He also designs long evening dresses with new colors and fabrics. For people who like classic styles, he makes a navy-blue suit. Sally Quail: Jeweller Sally Quail did not study jewellery. She started designing when she could not find an engagement ring she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Many famous people like her jewellery. She uses big stones in gold for necklaces, bracelets, and rings. Now, she also uses diamonds. She says, 'I wanted a diamond, so I started using them.' Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer Lily Grimson started her business four years ago. She only took a short art and design course. Two of her handbags were chosen for a big design show. Her bags are handmade in the UK. They are special and glamorous, made from fine leather or silk. Peter Little: Hairdresser Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people go to him. He says, 'Women want hair that looks real and is easy to manage.' His style looks natural, not like you just left a salon. It costs PS250 for the first visit, and there is a long waiting list. He also sells hairdryers and styling tools. Penny Pratt: Florist Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop. She also helps supermarkets and restaurants with flowers. She was a teacher but changed jobs 10 years ago. Her simple and modern flower designs win many prizes. She started her own London Flower School. She gives talks in Japan and the USA. She says, 'Keep flower arrangements simple and strong. Use the same type of flowers for wedding bouquets.'

**The Merrion Hotel: A New Luxury Experience**

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests.

The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps give special service to guests who come back. It cost a lot of money, but MacCann says it will be worth it. For example, if a guest likes certain music, the hotel will have it ready for their next visit.

Guests can also control the temperature in their rooms. They can change it a little, or ask the front desk to change it more. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for future technology changes too.

The rooms are big, comfortable, and have modern equipment. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, restaurants, and a garden. The food is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the hotel. This is good for both him and the hotel.

With great technology and staff, the Merrion Hotel is ready to be successful.

**Susan Shepherd and Her Flower Paintings**

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She paints flowers. Her house has a big garden. She finds many flowers for her paintings there. She likes tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden looks nice because the people who lived there before loved gardening. They left many plants for Susan. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but he understood when she said she wanted to paint them.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She sometimes paints a group of flowers, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. She paints it for a few days, then picks another flower. It can take years to finish one painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times because many flowers bloom then. She likes to watch how flowers change. For example, tulips change shape in water. They look boring at first, but then they twist and turn.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied them in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers before. She thought they looked fake. She liked wild flowers because they grew in hard places. Now, her garden has plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas. She lets the garden grow freely, like a kind aunt with children. Susan is busy with two art shows, so she hired another gardener. But she still likes to work in the garden because it helps her with her paintings.

**Text: The Storm and the Walnut Tree**

In March, there was a big storm in Brackham. Many trees fell down. In the town, two big lime trees fell in the market square. This changed how the town looked. Some people were not happy about this.

Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham was usually one of those people. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and chest pain. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor. Pelham thought he was too important to leave work, so he did not listen to her.

Pelham's friend, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. The doctor gave him medicine. Molly took him home, and he went to bed.

On Thursday, Molly told Pelham that the storm knocked down the walnut tree in their garden. Pelham was too sick to care. On Saturday, he felt better and got out of bed. He saw that the walnut tree was gone. This made the living room very bright. The old furniture looked bad in the bright light.

Before, the walnut tree made nice patterns of light and shade in the room. Now, Pelham could see the house next door. It was tall and had purple bricks. Pelham did not like the view.

Pelham said to Molly, "Doesn't it look terrible?" But Molly was happy. She said, "We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Text: 'Film Critic Mark Adams talks about his last ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I wrote reviews for other newspapers, magazines, and radio. That's how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. He also wrote for radio and TV. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist. At first, he wanted a team of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to write about, and there would be guests to make it fun. It felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of it. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed. I even thought a millionaire was pretending to hire me. I had little confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and saw my review, I didn't know what to do. Tom's idea for a team of critics didn't work out. It was a good idea, but we didn't meet as planned, so we talked by phone. People preferred a reviewer to focus on one subject, so I chose film. Thanks to Tom, I now write a long piece each week, usually about one film. This way of working is good for me. I wouldn't like the usual film critic's job, which means reviewing every film. That would make me bored quickly. I would soon be saying, 'What boring film must I watch now?' I like having space to write more or to be creative when there isn't much to say. But what is my job for the public? I think people choose films because of the stars, the ads, or the director. People usually stick to the types of films they like. It's rare for someone who hates westerns to watch one because of a review, or for a romance fan to skip a love story because of a review. So, if a film review isn't a guide, what is it? I don't feel I have to be 'right' about a movie. I don't think there should be a set number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. I just need to share my opinion. I'm not a judge, and I don't want to be.'

Text: Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager Melanie Sears loves triathlons. She is looking for a training partner who likes running, swimming, and cycling long distances. The triathlon is a popular sport. People watch athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and run 10km without stopping. Melanie is 17 years old and very good at school. She started triathlons at 14 and won her first race. But in another race, she got lost and cycled too far. She cried but did not give up. Melanie works very hard. Her coach, Steve Trew, says she never stops, even when tired. Melanie was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She is good at swimming and running but wants to get better at cycling. Her parents support her, and she wants a new bike for races. Melanie trains a lot and does not have much time for friends. She talks to her team about race times. She has tried shorter races but wants to do harder ones. She wishes she had someone her age to train with.

Text: 'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about the things she collects and why many people like this hobby. I love collecting, and many adults do too. Collecting is fun and exciting. But remember, only collect things you love. People have always liked to collect. Long ago, people collected pretty stones. They wore them as necklaces. Even today, children collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful. I have collected many things in my life, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a faraway place in England. It was cold and windy. My parents took me to a museum there. It had many old things collected by people. I loved looking at them. Many adults like collecting too. Some people collect because it makes them feel in control. I collect because I enjoy it. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with many interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You don't need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I once got a special tulip from another collector, but it was later stolen. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I found them all over the USA. But my collection was lost in a house fire. I was very sad. Collections often change owners. A silver spoon from a king or poet is special. As things become popular to collect, their price goes up. Toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, but only if you kept the original boxes. I threw mine away!'

Text: 'My Job Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa - Exhibition Organiser, Science Museum I make temporary exhibitions. I plan and design them. I also promote them. I read about the exhibition subject and talk to important people. I decide what objects and pictures to show. I make sure people understand the exhibition. I plan interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I work with engineers and electricians to keep it safe. Before it opens, I help with brochures and leaflets. Janet - Teacher for London Taxi Drivers I start work at 7.30 a.m. I check the accounts. I make new maps and documents for taxi-driver tests. By midday, 50 students are in school. They learn the best routes. I help when they disagree. I give them routes to test them. I make them think. Sarah - Marine Conservationist I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, make educational resources, and set up training. I work with schools and study centres. I take people out to sea in a boat. This helps them understand sea life. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. But I work for a charity, so I need more money and resources. Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher My work is varied. I make sure our books match market needs. We have 300 books. We have high standards. We get letters from readers about international boundaries. I talk about projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with a great team. The bad part is too much administration. It leaves less time for fun tasks like product development and design.'

Text: 'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. The four of us spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, own the house. They made the house bigger, but it still looks nice. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. We went on holiday together the summer before, but the hotel was not good because the food was bad. The four of us have played cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling when we arrived. She always knows when guests are coming and waits in the hall that smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' These are the names of our rooms. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of numbers. In winter, she does things like that, and her husband does repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he said in an Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and we felt our holiday had started. Nothing changed at Glencorn, all was well. Kitty from the dining room came to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur took our luggage to the rooms. After dinner, we played cards but not for long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full. From the window, we saw some people walking on the lawns and others going to the seashore. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. We knew this because we did it every year. We loved the beautiful landscape.'

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She works in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah is 24 years old and from West Sussex. She cooks and cleans for people who come to ski. They stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah finished university last summer. She studied French and History of Art. Being a chalet girl is not a career, she says, but it is fun for a year or two. 'I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live in the chalet. She walks to work at 7 a.m. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast and then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans the rooms or makes afternoon tea. She finishes by 11 a.m. and goes skiing. She skis until 4.30 p.m. Sarah goes back to the chalet to make dinner. Dinner is at 8 p.m. and has three courses. Coffee is ready by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans the kitchen after dinner. Sometimes she talks with the guests. Other times, they want to be alone. Sarah meets her friends at 11 p.m. They go out to places like Bananas and Dick's T-Bar. But she does not stay out late on Saturday. Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work early. Breakfast is ready by 7 a.m. for guests who leave. After they go, Sarah cleans everything. She also shops for the week. New guests arrive at 4.30 p.m. Sarah makes tea for them. She helps them with boots or skis. Then she makes dinner again. Sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.

A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's class. Years ago, Marie's class came to see how Seymour made gloves. Marie loved the laying-off table, where men shaped and pressed gloves on hot brass hands. Marie called them 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.

Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She took notes and asked more questions. Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained that the tannery is a contractor. They buy the material and make it ready for work. Seymour's grandfather and father worked in the tannery, and so did he for six months. He asked Rita if she had ever been inside a tannery. She said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered to arrange a visit for her.

Seymour told Rita that tanning is an old industry, with remains found in Turkey from six thousand years ago. He said his father is the leather expert and could talk about gloves for days. Seymour asked Rita if she had ever seen anything being made. She said she saw her mother make a cake when she was a child. Seymour laughed. Rita reminded him of Marie, who was always eager to learn and remembered everything from school.

Seymour decided to show Rita the whole process of making gloves. He asked her, 'What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it a hard job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi going to the airport. She can't meet tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and likes her boss. But she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour trip to California, I take sleeping pills to calm down,' she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. 'It felt closed in with small windows.' When not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes the diary, attends meetings, and makes travel plans. She got the job by meeting a pop group manager and took secretarial classes at night. Five years later, she became a PA. B. David Brown David Brown was an accountant and a golf caddy, a person who carries a golfer's bags. He liked being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are problems. He gets a small fee and a part of the winnings. He earns between £25,000 and £35,000, but spends a lot on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked for golfer Greg Norman. 'You don't just carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, and now he is a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes golf statistics for TV, magazines, and golfers. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a newspaper. He tries food in top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'If people can pay, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave.' His cooking talent got him a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At that time, he was a creative director at an ad agency, and it was extra money. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant earning 50% less,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job.' He still cooks at home and cycles to keep fit. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. 'Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens and foxes. So I wrote The Fox Busters, my first published story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'It's not easy, I work on them,' he says. 'I usually work in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I type my morning notes with one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy that part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help.'

**Text for A1 Level:**

There was a place by the lake where they cut trees into wood for building. There was an old building with two floors. Around it, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust looked like golden mountains. One afternoon, Michael and his friends climbed to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs over the edge and looked at the lake.
