Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and he jumped onto the sawdust. He laughed and said, "I dare you all!" His friends were scared, but one by one, they jumped and laughed too.

Later, they went back to the roof to jump again. Everyone jumped except Michael. He was scared and stayed on the roof. His friends called him a coward and left. Michael stayed alone on the roof for a long time. The sun was setting, and he was sweating because he was nervous. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped. He fell on the sawdust and lay there for a while. The workers had gone home, and it was quiet.

Michael felt ashamed and walked home. He was late for dinner. His stepmother was not happy and said, "You should come home on time for dinner." She was a kind woman, but Michael was sad. He kept thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy with your job? Do you want to change but don't know how? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people go to a careers adviser for help. You write about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. The adviser gives you a report with career suggestions and training you might need.

I tried Career Analysts, a big company for career advice. The test felt like a school exam. I was with ten people, answering questions quickly. The test had tasks like finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked to an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and advice. I agreed with most of it. I was not good at science and technical tests, so I am glad I did not become a nurse. But I was happy to hear I made the right choice with journalism.

Changing your career doesn't mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to try Career Analysts. She wanted to look at her skills and interests. She found out she was good at design but decided to use her skills in a new job. Now, she works in Public Relations. Career Analysts helped her see what she wanted to do.

Some people need help to make big changes. Juliet Greene, 26, worked at a bank for six years. She was bored and wanted a new challenge. She went to Career Counselling Services. The tests showed she liked sciences. After four meetings, she decided to study geology. She is happier now.

But careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, was a sales representative. She wanted new ideas but didn't like the suggestions. They needed a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. She felt a friend could give similar advice.

Text: 'Fun at the Dentist's? If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dentist office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the wall and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, 'Half of the people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared.' To help with this, he tries to make a place where people are not scared. He does not wear a white coat because people think it means pain. Jerome thinks going to the dentist should be relaxing and fun. This is surprising because many people think going to the dentist means pain. Jerome says, 'If people are relaxed and happy, they will forget bad experiences.' He uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. 'We were the first in Britain to use them, and people like them. Patients watch a film about underwater animals while I check their teeth. Then they see a video of their mouth.' Many patients like this part of the visit. The office smells nice, like oranges, not like a dentist's office. Jerome says, 'I want people to know it is different here. Smell is important. The usual dentist smell can make people scared.' The nice smell is very pleasant. Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, but he is serious about his work. Relaxing is important, but good treatment is the most important. He uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth, not scraping them. It feels strange at first, but it is not painful if you are relaxed. Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. 'I learned that if you make it easy for the patient, it is easy for you too,' he says. He thinks this is the start of a change in British dentistry. A patient comes in. Jerome offers him tea and asks what video he wants to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a regular dentist office.'

**Chocolate: A Sweet Story**

Chocolate comes from South America. Now, it is a big business around the world. At Easter, people in Britain spend over £230 million on chocolate. They buy a lot of chocolate at this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.

The cacao plant is very old. The Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan people in Central America grew it over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant. It grows in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is big like a melon and has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans. We use them to make chocolate. In English, they are often called cocoa beans. This is a mistake from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in their language. The drink had spices and was used for special events. The Spanish liked it with cinnamon and sugar. It took 100 years for the recipe to spread in Europe.

In the late 17th century, people in Europe started to drink chocolate in special chocolate houses. Until the last century, chocolate was a drink made from solid blocks. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands made chocolate powder. This was by taking out most of the cocoa butter from the beans.

In 1847, Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, made the first chocolate bar. They mixed cocoa butter, chocolate liquor, and sugar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.

In 1905, the English company Cadbury made the Dairy Milk bar. They used good advertising to make it popular. Now, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. To sell more, companies make chocolate bars into ice cream, drinks, or desserts.

Cacao farmers had problems when cocoa bean prices went down in the 1980s. Many small farmers had to stop working. Remember them when you eat your next chocolate bar.

Text: 'THE SHELL ARTIST Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He is very good at making art with shells. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But now, he is happy making beautiful things with shells. Peter shows his work in his apartment. He says, "Tell me if I am boring you." But he is not boring. He is very interesting and his work is beautiful. Peter points to shell ornaments above a fireplace. He says, "I don't mind if people don't buy them. I like them very much." He did not plan to sell his work. Five years ago, friends told him to have an exhibition. Many people bought his work. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The prices are high, about £2,000 for some pieces. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition. Prices start at £225 for a shell-flower in a vase. Peter says he does not set the prices. He is happy to talk about them. He says no one else makes work like his. The gallery owner says, "One day you will stop, and people will want your pieces because there will be no more." Peter wishes he started earlier. He says he could have made even better things. Now, he is older and it is harder for him. But his work is still very special. He makes boxes with tiny shells and flowers that look real. Peter has his own way of working. He uses cardboard from shirts, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea, and it just happens." But his work is very detailed and beautiful. Peter looks for shells in many places like France, Thailand, and Mexico. He only takes shells that are empty. He does not take shells with living creatures. He says, "People walk on shells and break them. The sea also breaks them. I only take shells that are empty." His work is very beautiful and special.'

Text: 'The Schoolgirl Model Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw talks to her. 'Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said. I was worried because I thought models were difficult and not very nice. And now she was late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. But when Kira came in, she was smiling and said sorry. She was with her mother. Kira was wearing a simple black dress and trainers. She was very friendly, very tall, and very pretty. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum and was proud of Kira. Kira is surprised by her fame. It was not planned. Her older sister wanted her to join a model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should go in for it,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway.' When Kira was at school, she got a call. She was a finalist. This made Kira feel confident. She won the competition. The Select model agency in London gave her work. Kira now has two lives: school and modelling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school are not nice. 'They say I think too much of myself.' Kira says, 'They think I have changed, but I am just more confident now.' As a model, her social life is different. The agency can call her anytime for a job. 'If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. But my friends are good about it.' Kira has a great future. Not many people can say that before they finish school. I ask Kira what she would like to do if she was not a model. She thinks and says, 'I'd like to do what you're doing.'

Text: 'Father and son look for gold Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold. After ten years of digging, they believe they are close to finding gold worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, says, 'We are finding some gold; we just need to dig a little more.' They started looking for gold after reading about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' in Wales. They read old mining books and newspapers to find the best place to dig. They spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and cleaning the area. They dug a tunnel and a 10-meter hole. Now, they need more money to keep digging. They hope someone will give them PS50,000 to help. Chris says, 'It is hard to find someone to help, but we have some people to ask.' People in the area are interested in the gold search. Dolgellau is a town that needs tourists. Peter Woolven, who works at a hotel, says, 'If they find gold, more people might come here, but I hope not too many.' The Welsh gold industry was big in the 1880s, but now it is small. One of the last mines closed a month ago. But some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig on the other side of the hill. Hall, who is 70 years old, says, 'Looking for gold is exciting. Maybe I will find treasure this time.'

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies the sea's chemicals. She teaches at Southampton University. When not teaching, she goes in a small underwater vehicle. It is like a small car. She dives 3 kilometers down to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, space is very small. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand or move much. They stay inside until someone opens the door. A dive lasts 16 hours. It takes 3 hours to go down, 10 hours to collect rock and water, and 3 hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. A small escape vessel goes quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet.

Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the vehicle. She was with an instructor. He showed her what to do in an emergency. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was putting equipment there to study a volcano.

When not at sea, Rachel is at her office. She loves teaching, but she also loves her research. She studies "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes. Water comes out and looks like black smoke. It is very hot, 350 degrees.

Rachel was scared once. She was with an American team. There was a big explosion. She thought she would die. But nothing happened, and they were safe.

Rachel loves diving. She feels wonder when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them for real was amazing.

Text: "I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired. My mind was tired of foreign timetables, money, and languages. 'Never again,' I said, as I came home. I said the same thing the next year. And the next. I just needed to buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train rocks you to sleep. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply. You might even burn socks that smell bad or throw away books when you finish them. This is the Inter-Rail spirit. You can forget about common sense. All you need is a ticket. This ticket lets young people travel to many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I thought the ticket was just a cheap way to get to our camp in France. But we wanted to travel more because there was always another country to see. And it cost us nothing extra. We were not very interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and only saw the easy sights. We wanted to escape the guided tour and do something different. I liked that sometimes I only saw the view from the station. We were there to have fun. We were like other Inter-Railers. We shared train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel is seeing a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city is real when the train arrives, and you see it with your own eyes. You can only understand Europe by seeing it yourself. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it. This is why other people's holiday photos are boring. The train trip won't show you new things in the world, but it is a good personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this, even if it takes time."

Text: 'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your bags are not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and have the wrong clothes. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and they cannot promise that your bags will always be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes. 

Airlines ask you to check in early so there is enough time for your bags to go through the airport and onto the plane. The time needed to change planes is also longer to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause the baggage system to fail. Sometimes, human error or a torn label can also cause problems. These issues are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, and nine million of them changed planes. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. 

The chance of losing bags is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers connect to flights to Latin America. To avoid losing your bags, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline and allow more time between flights. Label your bags inside and out with your home and holiday addresses and include flight numbers. If your bags still go missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

Text: 'The Kingfisher

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer. He knows a lot about the kingfisher. This bird is blue and green. It lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. 

Old trees hang over the stream. The water is shallow. The colours are soft greens, browns, and yellows. The kingfisher flies fast and straight. It is like a flash of light. You see it for a second, but you remember it.

Charlie loved kingfishers when he was young. He does not know why he loves them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. One story says a kingfisher flew high and got the blue of the sky on its back. Its belly got burnt by the sun. 

Kingfishers have no blue colour in their feathers. The feathers reflect light and look blue. Sometimes they look green when the light changes.

Charlie likes to watch kingfishers. They are shy, but you can see them from a hideout. His first hideout was an old blanket. He waited near a kingfisher's spot. The bird came back and sat close to him. It took him four years to take a good picture.

Charlie spent a lot of time by the stream. He missed school to watch the birds. He did not do well in school. But people noticed his interest in kingfishers. At 16, he worked for a nature magazine. Later, he became a wildlife film cameraman.

Charlie wants to make a film about kingfishers. He wants to show beautiful images without words. He loves the colours of the kingfisher's wings. His photos show his feelings, but there is more to his love for kingfishers than his work can show.'

Text: 'Conducting an Orchestra Conducting an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work. A. ANNE MANSON Anne Manson is 30 years old. She went to Vienna to watch conductor Claudio Abbado. She helped him when his assistant was not there. She was not nervous. Anne works with an opera company in London. She also works in other countries in Europe. B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He won a big competition in 1991. He tried two times before but did not win. The competition helped him get more work. He wants people to know him for his work, not just the competition. C. WASFI KANI Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She likes the long practice time for opera. She started conducting in her late twenties. She learned a lot from Sian Edwards. Wasfi likes the challenges of opera. D. ROGER VIGNOLES Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He started as a musician in an opera house. Last year, he conducted Handel's Agrippina. He found it easier than he thought. Roger wants to try different things in music. E. WAYNE MARSHALL Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. Simon Rattle noticed him in 1986. Wayne had to conduct a musical in London quickly. He was strong with the musicians. Wayne did not study conducting formally, but he knows what he likes.'

Text: 'Theme Parks in Britain If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. We asked five families to try the best ones. Fun Island - The Burns family Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island might be boring, but we liked it. The park is good for young children, so our three-year-old had fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was great. For older children, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the children wanted to stay. The park is clean and safe, but the scenery is not very nice. The staff are very helpful. Wonderland - The McMillan family We never went to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He liked the Mountain Train and Little Land, with small famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We stayed for six hours and liked the places to rest. The park is beautiful and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults. Adventure World - The Jeffree family After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with a trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and the girls were scared but liked it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for younger children. The children saw the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small for it. The park is clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, a staff member helped us by sitting with one of the girls. The Great Park - The Langridge family We arrived at one o'clock and were sad the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is good for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am scared easily, but I had fun. We loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then is very fun. We waited for Lightning River for half an hour, and it was over fast! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun. If the children were older, they might find it boring, but they loved it. Fantasy World - The Break-all family The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down, was worse! There are many rides, and the older children went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides, but liked the Long Slide. The staff were sometimes nice, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We didn't want to leave early.'

Text: 'Running a business in the countryside Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside. A. 'My customers are friends,' says CHRISTINE HOGAN. She has a computer design business. It makes over £200,000 a year and has four workers. 'My husband and I moved from London to the country when our children were small. I wanted a job I could do at home. I worked with computers before I got married, so my husband said I should start a computer design business. It needed a lot of money and was hard at first. But I was careful with money and told the bank if I spent too much. Working at home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It is a small business. We do not deliver work - people come to us to get it.' B. 'I enjoy being independent,' says MAGGY SASANOW. She designs greeting cards at home. 'I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, and there were no museum jobs. So I started my own business. I make 50 different greeting cards and sell them to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The bad thing about working at home is there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I get business by word of mouth - I don't advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper. Working alone, I don't share ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad.' C. 'It has been hard at times,' says DELIA TURNER. She makes curtains. 'I started my business eight years ago. It grew fast, and in two years, my earnings went from £24,000 to £80,000. I had six full-time workers. But I had to let them go because the economy got worse. It was hard because there are not many jobs here. Now, I make curtains at home with my husband's help and other women who work from their homes. I have to lower my prices sometimes and look for new chances.' D. TESSA STRICKLAND works on children's books from her farmhouse. 'I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. London was too expensive, and I love the country. I like working when I want. Most of my money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I take calls at odd hours. The bad thing is I need discipline to stop working. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. I used to feel alone because all my work experience was in London.' E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business and a shop. It makes £250,000 a year and has six workers, some part-time. 'I started ten years ago at home. I like health, so I made fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon I sent cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building. We have a baker, an assistant, and a cake decorator. I don't cook now; I manage the business. My biggest problem was money because we didn't have much to start with.'

Text: 'Meet the Watkins Family The sons are musicians, and Dad makes the instruments. Matthew Rye reports. Families with musicians are not rare. But it is special to find a family with music writers, performers, and an instrument maker. John and Hetty Watkins are teachers in South Wales. They needed a cello for their son, Paul, who was ten years old. Cellos were very expensive. John thought, "Can I make one?" He found a school for making instruments near his home. He went to classes once a week for three years. After making some violins and violas, he made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It was really good. He made me another one later. I used it until a few months ago." John stopped teaching to make instruments full-time. He makes about twelve violins a year. He sold one to a famous American player, Jaime Laredo. Paul and his brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano. Then he wanted to play the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin, but he liked the cello player in his dad's group. He started cello lessons. Huw did not want to play the violin. Huw says, "My parents were supportive. I wanted to be like Paul." Huw is now 22 and is a pianist and composer. John's cello helped Paul win a big music competition. At 20, Paul became the main cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played his dad's cello until last year. Now he has a new cello from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul says, "Dad's cello is good, but my new one is better for big concerts." Paul will play on TV soon. He will play Elgar's Cello Concerto. Paul says, "I play it my way." Paul cannot watch himself on TV because he has a concert. Huw also has a concert in London. John and Hetty will be busy keeping up with their sons' music.'

Text: 'Taking Care of the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is a group that helps protect the countryside in Britain. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, who works for the Trust. Gareth is a warden. He says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people. Gareth talks to farmers, visitors, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm. Many people wanted the warden job, but Gareth got it because he knows the area well and has farming experience. He still helps on his parents' farm, so he understands farmers' problems. Gareth's farm work helps him do his job, like building fences and planting trees. Gareth has learned more about nature. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child. He now sees how farming has changed the countryside. Farmers were just following government rules. At first, farmers and nature lovers did not agree. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's job is to make sure work is done well and cheaply. He likes finishing projects, but he also spends time on paperwork. Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He likes talking to people, but some visitors are rude. They act like they own the place. Gareth says common sense is important. If you like being outside and have common sense, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But there might not be a job on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!'

Text: 'The Netball Captain Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slowinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is getting ready for the World Championships next month. She teaches at a school and then trains in a supermarket car park. 'Don't people look at you?' Suzie asked. 'I am too focused on my training to notice,' Kendra said. 'I want to be my best for the Championships.' This is her fourth World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing. 'We will have support from people at home,' Kendra said. 'It is important for netball in our country.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always won against them, but they are good,' Kendra said. England is ranked fourth in the world. The World Championships are hard. 'You play every day, no rest,' Kendra said. 'You have only one chance to win.' Kendra has played for 15 years. The game is faster now. 'We train to win,' she said. 'But after the game, we are friendly.' Netball uses science for fitness. 'We must think and train like top players,' Kendra said. 'As captain, I must be strong and help my team.' Kendra planned her netball career carefully. She decided this will be her last competition. She might coach young players later. But now, she is focused on her last big event. At the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

**Specialist Music Schools**

What can you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents do not see their child's talent until the child becomes upset or difficult. Regular schools are good for children who are smart in subjects like math or English. But children who are very good at music need special help. Regular schools may not have this help, especially if music is not important there.

Specialist music schools can help these children. In Britain, there are five music schools. These schools are for children aged seven to eighteen. They help children become better at music with the help of professional musicians. Children at these schools spend a lot of time on music. They have lessons, play in groups, and learn about music theory. They also practice a lot. The rest of the time, they study important subjects like English and math.

These schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school. This means they spend a lot of time with other children who love music too.

There are some problems. The schools are expensive, but they try to help parents with scholarships. Also, not all parents want their children to live away from home at a young age. Some school directors think it might not be good for very young children to be in such a strict environment. They want to make sure children grow up happy and balanced.

Being in a music school can be stressful. Some children lose interest in music as they grow older. The pressure to be the best can make them feel like they failed. But the schools watch the children closely and help them if needed.

Some children are also very smart in other subjects. They might feel unhappy if they cannot study these subjects enough. For these children, it might be better to wait until they are older to decide about a music school. They can also go to a regular school with a good music program or take music lessons on weekends at a music college. But this is hard for families who do not live near big cities.

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She paints flowers. Her garden has many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden looks nice because the people who lived there before liked gardening. They left plants that Susan likes. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." They work well together. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but he understood when she said she wanted to paint them.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She picks a flower and takes it to her studio. She paints it for a few days. Then she picks another flower and paints it. Sometimes, it takes her a long time to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are busy times for her because many flowers bloom then. She likes to watch how flowers change. For example, tulips change shape when they are in water.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied plants in school. She used to collect wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers before. She thought they looked fake. Now, her garden has plants from other countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan lets the garden grow freely. She is busy with two art shows, so she does not have much time for the garden. She has another gardener to help. But she knows she must work in the garden to stay connected to her flowers.

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She works in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. She helps visitors who come to ski. She cooks and cleans in the wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is fun for a year or two. Sarah meets many people. She does not live in the chalet. She walks to work at 7 a.m. The chalet can have up to 18 guests. Sarah eats her breakfast first. Then she makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans the rooms or makes afternoon tea. She finishes by 11 a.m. and goes skiing. She skis until 4.30 p.m. Sarah comes back to make dinner. Dinner is at 8 p.m. and has three courses. She cleans the kitchen after dinner. Sometimes she talks with the guests. Sarah meets her friends at 11 p.m. They go out but she does not stay out late on Saturday. Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work early. Breakfast is at 7 a.m. After guests leave, she cleans everything. She also shops for the week. New guests arrive at 4.30 p.m. Sarah helps them with questions and takes them to get skis. Then she makes dinner again. Sometimes she is very tired and goes to bed early.'

Text: 'Changing Jobs for a Day

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. She usually wears a uniform, but she had to choose clothes for this day. She visited a photo studio and press previews before lunch. The zoo is quiet, but the magazine office was busy. She saw how magazines work but likes her zoo job more.

Alice Cutler works at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. She wore leather boots and blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green shirt. She got dirty but had a great day. She liked the elephants and thought about working with them in Africa one day.

Karen Hodson is a nurse. She worked with the TV gardening show Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team. She liked being outside because she often works inside. The work was hard, but she had fun. She learned that gardening is not easy, so she will stay a nurse.

Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on Ground Force. She worked at a hospital. She made beds and gave out medicine. She thought she might faint, but she was okay. She liked the friendship among the nurses. She felt her job was not as important as nursing.

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She worked with Ryanair as cabin crew. She wore a uniform and felt different. She learned about safety and gave out magazines on a flight to Paris. She felt nervous with many people looking at her. On the way back, there were many children, and she missed her gym.

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer. She was worried because she doesn't exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. She saw that trainers don't always eat healthy but drink a lot of water. She doesn't want to change jobs but wants to be healthier.'

Text: 'On the Train Five famous people tell Andrew Morgan their best train memories. A Andrea Thompson - Newsreader I love the south of France and go there often. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast to Italy. You can see beautiful sea views. It is always nice, no matter the weather or time of year. You can also see lovely gardens and houses. The people on the train are fun because there are tourists and locals. They all enjoy the beautiful trip. Raj Patel - Explorer I have taken many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park. I was too young and stayed with my aunt. When I moved to England, I had not been on a train. London Waterloo was the first big station I saw, and it amazed me. Betty Cooper - Novelist I love one train: the Blue Train. My husband and I took it on our honeymoon across France to a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress. I loved it. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I wear it a lot now. The trip was lovely, going through France and then by boat on the Nile. It was perfect after the wedding. Martin Brown - Journalist We were writing articles on a world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not fixed. The driver waited for people to arrive. When the train came, many people got on, even on the roof for free. At night, the train went through beautiful places. It was like a dream. Arisu Mezuki - Actress Most people like trains from when they are kids, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus and saw few trains. As a teenager, I made a film with a railway in Yorkshire. It was an old train line kept by volunteers. I loved steam trains then. When not filming, we rode the train. I went back last year, and it was the same, even the gas lights!'

Text: 'Do you want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice writing. To sell your writing, you need to know about the 'writing world'. No matter what you write, you should know the market you want to reach. The best way to learn is by reading a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading will show you what publishers want. Remember, things change. New magazines come out, and editors change jobs. Publishers always want new writers, so give them what they want. If you want to write short love stories, find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and see what kind of stories they like. Know who the readers are because the editor wants to please them. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' I never discourage anyone, but the work might not be ready to publish. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you have only written one story, it is not likely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Each story will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. Don't throw any stories away; improve them. I suggest not showing your work to others at first. Remember, every successful writer has faced rejection. Do everything you can to become a writer. Look for a creative writing course or join a local writers' group. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I thought. The station did not feel clean and nice like usual. Old couples with matching bags sat on benches. Many college students sat on the floor with their bags. A man with grey hair was talking to strangers. He looked rich: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question. Then he talked to a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I thought I might like to talk to her too. The man asked, 'Are you going to Philadelphia?' 'Well, I am going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, and moved on. Now I was interested. 'Ma'am,' he asked an old lady, 'are you going to Philadelphia?' She said, 'Wilmington,' and he walked away to another couple. I stood up and moved closer, looking at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. But I knew why he didn't. I looked unreliable. He glanced at me and walked away. He looked worried. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Are you going to Philadelphia?' She put down her book. She was about thirty-five, older than me. She looked like a teacher. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Can I ask you a favor?' I stopped and looked at my wrist. (I don't have a watch.) I could tell she was careful. The man noticed too and said, 'It's not hard, I promise!' They announced my train. People moved to Gate E, pulling their bags. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying today for a study year abroad, from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning. Then I went home and found my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn't know what to do.' The woman made a sympathetic sound. I would have stayed quiet. 'I told her to stay there. I would find someone to take her passport.' Why didn't he go himself if it was so important? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a bad excuse. It was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man had a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one like a small book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel what was inside! And it looked stapled shut. Be careful, lady, I thought.'

Text: 'Gary and Me John Moore is a restaurant owner. He talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I found the restaurant, it was in bad shape, but it was perfect for me. This business made me remember my childhood. My mother worked in a factory, and I was sad because I was alone. So, I wanted time for family. My wife took care of the children and did my accounts, while I ran the restaurant. We lived above the restaurant, and we always ate meals together. This was good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they talked to our customers. This helped them a lot. Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into a bath like a swimming pool and hurt himself. When he was older, he worked for pocket money. He did small jobs and by ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend. He had discipline. He woke up early. It was nice to see him helping. Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the men working there. He made over a hundred meals. I knew he would work in catering. When he needed work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary now plays the drums and has a band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if his music becomes popular. I told Gary, 'If you want to succeed, do it by 30. After that, it's too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he finished his work quickly and helped others. That's my son! We can't believe how successful Gary's TV show is. I'm very proud of him. I always told him to work hard because no one gives you anything. He saw his chance and took it. You talk to your children, and if they listen to even a little, you should be happy. Gary listened sometimes.'

Text: 'Finding a Flat in Dublin Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way is to know someone who knows someone leaving a flat. But if you are new, like Jo, you don't know anyone. Jo had just arrived in Dublin, so she stayed in a hostel and looked for a flat. Dublin was a big unknown place for Jo. She felt like she was going somewhere new when she took the train to work there. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick. But Jo was the only one going to Dublin. Jo's mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel because it was safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know they were talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, 'Own room, own TV, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked. Jo hoped it was nice and not too expensive. There was no line for this flat because it was more like 'Third Girl Wanted.' The 'own TV' part made Jo think it might be too fancy, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf was leaving and said, 'Desperate place. They're both awful.' Jo kept going up. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that girl leaving? I don't like her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'She just looked around, made a face, and said, "Is this all?" in a fancy voice. We wouldn't have her here, right, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was surprised because Pauline was a punk. Jo had seen punks on the street but never talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work at the post office,' she said. Nessa said they were about to have tea. She had three mugs: one for 'Nessa,' one for 'Pauline,' and one with 'Other' on it. 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' Nessa said kindly.

Text: 'Dolphins and Their Problems People love dolphins. We like to see them at the beach, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins have big problems. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are in danger. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart and can feel human emotions. They make us think of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face. The seas are dirty and have too many fishers. One type of dolphin, the North Sea harbour porpoise, has lost many of its kind. You might think dolphins are safe and protected, but they are not. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, we see striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. Striped and common dolphins live far in the sea. We do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be near European coasts. Now, they are only in a few places in Scotland and Wales. They have skin injuries, which show they are stressed. It is hard to know why there are fewer dolphins. Overfishing is a big problem. Fish are disappearing, and dolphins cannot find food. Dolphins can also get caught in fishing nets. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. They had marks from nets. Pollution is another problem. Waste in the sea can make dolphins sick. Pesticides can build up in their bodies. A young dolphin died from its mother's milk because of this. Noise is also a problem for dolphins. They live in groups and use sound to understand their world. Noise from ships and oil wells can disturb them. We do not know how much this affects them.'

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is very important for your body and mind. It helps you feel better when life is busy and stressful. Exercise is good for you, and there are many reasons to do it. Exercise makes your muscles strong and changes your body shape. It helps you stand or sit correctly. It also helps your heart and lungs work better. Exercise can make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep well and feel less stressed. Exercise can also help with some health problems. There are many types of exercise like jogging, aerobics, and lifting weights. But be careful not to train too hard, as it can cause injury. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are unsure. Good posture is important too. Stand tall and imagine a balloon pulling your head up. This helps you breathe better and look slimmer. Stretching your muscles makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine. Do it four or five times a week. A good exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, a workout, and a cool down.'

Text: 'IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home for many months? They want to find the perfect picture. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is hard to find Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are now in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained a lot for six months. This rain causes problems. Newman said they bought an expensive tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda can then pull him out. Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films for TV, like their film about leopards. While people watched this film, Amanda and Owen were already looking for another shy animal, the jackal. Many film-makers travel the world to film wild animals. I talked to Newman at a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue but solve it quickly. They do not have a leader. They both see animals in the same way. They set up tents every night, but now they have a fixed camp. They start at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before. They eat pre-packed meals. They can be away for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem. But being alone in remote places helps them get close to animals. Newman remembers filming lions. One lioness greeted their car like it was part of her family. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift'. Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes. They spend four months filming for each half-hour film. They need to get a script approved before filming. Newman says they work well together because they share the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals and touch people's hearts. Newman believes it is better to make people feel something than just think about it.'

Text: 'The Netball Captain Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is getting ready for the World Championships next month. She teaches at a school and then trains in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people look at her strangely. She said she is too focused on her training to notice. Kendra wants to be her best for the Championships. This is her fourth time at the World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing. England will have support from people at home. Their first game is against Barbados. England usually wins against them, but it will be a fun game. England is ranked fourth in the world. The World Championships are hard because there is only one chance to win. Kendra says players are more aggressive now. After the game, everyone is friendly. Netball is more scientific now, with fitness tests. Kendra thinks it's important to have a strong mind and help her team. She planned her netball career carefully. This will be her last competition as a player. She might coach young players in the future. At the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional. Her supporters will be with her.'

Text: 'Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. Rachel studies the sea and teaches about it. She goes to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean in a small submarine. The submarine is the size of a small car. Inside, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move much. They stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive lasts 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel go up quickly to the surface. No one has used it yet. Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the submarine. She learned what to do in an emergency. Now, she has made six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team to study underwater volcanoes near the Canary Islands. These volcanoes blow out black smoke. Rachel loves teaching, but she also loves her research. She studies "black smokers," which are underwater volcanoes. The water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It is very hot. Rachel was scared once when there was a loud bang. She thought she might die, but she was okay. Diving is an adventure for Rachel. She feels amazed when she sees the underwater volcanoes. She studied them for three years, and seeing them was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are important. People decide what they think about us in the first few minutes. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement, and how we talk. Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard for my degree. When I graduated, I was confident." She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview. "I saw a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I wanted to change, but I didn't want to be late. Being on time is important." Mary did not get the job. Her friend at the school said the Head Teacher thought, "If she doesn't care about her image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. In an interview, you should look your best." Many people forget to look professional. Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant. She wanted a promotion but did not get an interview. She asked why and was told she did not look like a manager. She was surprised. "I do a good job. How I dress should not matter."

How we move and our gestures also matter. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message is words, 38% is voice, and 55% is facial expressions. If our face and words say different things, people believe the face. Make sure your words and body language match. Do not look too desperate for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, got a job offer right away. "I was happy," she says. "But I showed too much excitement. The boss knew I would not say no, so he offered me less money."

What we say and how we say it is important. David Artesio, a manager, says to learn about the company before the interview. "Talk about something that interests you. This shows you care about the company." Marian Woodall, a business consultant, says to have questions ready and speak clearly. "Good communicators use short sentences," she says.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly. He used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel. The chef liked his meat, and now Matt sells meat by mail too. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works a lot.

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor who was surprised because Ron did not want to go back to his old job. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They left their friends, but many friends visit them now.

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats in her London home. She liked her job, but the hours were long. She did not want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she is busy with her hat business. She likes being in charge of her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being responsible for her product.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned massage. He now works part-time as a masseur and feels happy and in control of his life.

Text: 'Young Sports Stars Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried to join a professional football club, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. I hoped for more attention and sponsorship, but it did not happen. I train at home in winter and go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun, but I must be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out before training, I say no. My main goal is to go to the next Olympics. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. I do not go to late-night parties. I like to sleep in, but I give it up for surfing. It is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate, especially if I win money. Winning the championship helped me get a TV show about surfing. I am a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) There are five of us on the boat, and we have fun. We celebrate wins in style. Sometimes people say we act like children, but we do not look for media attention. I am away for eight months a year, so I enjoy going out with friends when I am home. I do not want to be a celebrity. I get letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them. D Tomas (tennis player) It is great to play tennis with the crowd cheering. At the last tournament, it was a bit crazy with fans. I like being noticed by fans, but my last girlfriend did not like it. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you must be serious in sports. I focus on my game now and will enjoy other things after I retire.'

Text: 'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very hard. One mother says, 'They want everything they see. They ask for sweet cereals, Disney videos, and comics. I can't buy all these things. I feel bad if I say yes, and I feel bad if I say no. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to choose things.' Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, mostly on TV. These ads make children want to buy things. Parents find it hard to explain why they can't buy everything. Ads make things look very nice, and children don't understand why they can't have them. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, 'Parents care about what their children eat, but ads give children a one-sided view.' TV ads can't tell children to ask their parents to buy things, but they still make children want to buy them. Shopping with children can be stressful for parents. They have to decide what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says she talks to her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They talk about products and look at labels. Now, her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair. Mike, a father, says, 'We say no to sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and children want that too. But I still get annoyed when they ask for things. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I might say yes. It's hard to always say the same thing.' Supermarkets can help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might buy less, but they would enjoy shopping more without their children's demands.'

**The Merrion Hotel: A Mix of Luxury and Technology**

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests.

The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps give special service to guests who come back. It cost a lot of money, but MacCann says it will be worth it. For example, if a guest likes certain music, the hotel will have it ready for their next visit.

Guests often complain about room temperature. At the Merrion, guests can change the temperature a little in their rooms. The front desk can also change it more if needed.

Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. TVs and DVD players can be updated easily.

Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large rooms, a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, restaurants, and a garden.

The food at the hotel is excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a great place to eat without financial risk.

With technology and a great staff, the Merrion Hotel is ready to succeed.

Text: 'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I get energy from excitement. I like doing new and challenging things. Learning new things gives me energy. I am learning flamenco dancing now. Dance is fun and gives me energy. If you are bored, you can feel tired. Doing something useful gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I like being at work. If you like something, it doesn't make you feel bad, even if you are tired. I need a lot of sleep. When I sleep well, I feel good. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week and try to exercise at home. After exercise, I feel happy. I feel tired in the office in the afternoon, so I eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthy food for energy. I think being happy and positive gives me energy. I don't like negative people. I think we should enjoy life. I like my job. The last two years were exciting. I work with young people, and they give me energy. I like taking photos and writing songs for fun. It helps me relax when I travel.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from things I like. I believe in my work and my family. Being positive helps. I love working with kids. They have a lot of energy. Smiling at people gives you energy. I try to eat healthy and don't smoke or drink. I don't have an exercise plan. I play with kids for exercise.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'I love making a garden from nothing. I did it once. The garden was concrete, and I changed it to soil. It was better than exercise. I get energy when people read my writing. I like walking in nature. If someone sees me, I say I didn't know it was private. It's fun and feels like being a child.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'You must like and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored fast. Doing things you don't like makes you tired. I used to be on committees, but they took my time. You have limited energy, so use it for important things.'

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating is very old. People have skated for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. Later, around 200 AD, people in Scandinavia started using iron skates. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was important. 

In the early 1900s, skating was calm and stylish. But in 1924, at the Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie made skating more athletic. This made skating more popular. Today, skating is both beautiful and hard work.

When you start skating, balance and control are important. You get faster as you get better. To balance, keep your legs slightly bent and lean a little forward. Relaxing is very important in skating. 

To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with one foot and make a small move with the other foot. It is not too hard. As you practice, you can make bigger movements.

Learning how to fall is important. Even the best skaters fall. To fall safely, stay relaxed. This helps you not get hurt. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand.

Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, or speed skating. It is best to learn figure skating first. Most ice rinks have teachers to help you learn. 

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, do exercises often. Warm up your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees before skating. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.

Skating helps with balance, coordination, and relaxation. It is good for your heart and lungs and makes your body strong. Skating with swimming or jogging is great for health and fitness.

**Young Stars and Their Lives**

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is hard now. I have no time to watch TV or go out with friends. I just do gym and school. I try to take training day by day. When I am very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but not often. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great talent from a young age. Some parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we gave up a lot, but they don't see what the sport gave us. We love it and what it did for Annika. Before gym, she was shy and sucked her thumb. Now, she has met people from all over the world and is confident."

**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last one to five days. I never get tired of it. I love show-jumping; it's exciting and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I am determined. My goal is to join the British young riders team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To join big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is happy on a horse and knows what she's doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not scared of being proud. I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like embarrassment."

**F. Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves. By 6, she was beating adults. When she wins, I'm happy, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down because she is special. If she has a gift, let her use it."

Text: "We are all getting taller. Chris Greener was 14 years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every ten years, people in Europe get one centimeter taller. More tall people are born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. We are becoming like our ancestors from 40,000 years ago. Back then, people ate many different foods. Women collected herbs, fruits, and berries, and men hunted animals. They ate 85 different wild plants. 

About 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Farmers grew wheat, rice, and maize. These three plants now give us more than half of our food. This diet was not good for us. People became less healthy. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. 

Farming spread because it could feed more people. But many people were not well-fed. Only recently have diets improved in Europe, the US, and Japan. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. 

This is good, but there are problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less leg-room in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their sizes. We cannot grow forever. Scientists think we might reach 193 cm this century. 

But, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, people were bigger to stay warm. Now, as the planet gets warmer, we might get smaller again. Global warming could make us shrink."

Text: 'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a normal part of TV, but many people don't know much about them. We see them happy on game shows and wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. Even people who work in TV sometimes don't respect them. I thought studio audiences were just people who wanted to be on TV for a short time. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of backgrounds. TV tries to get different people for different shows. Some people like to watch TV at home and don't understand why others go to a studio. Why do people get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch something they can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She came because she wanted to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But many people say they came because a friend gave them a ticket. Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This is true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager says, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? Claire thinks sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte likes being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was fun and a free night out.'

Text: 'Favourite places

Bruce
I like places with people. I don't like empty places. When I travel, I like villages with old buildings. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to a village called Lastingham. I liked the hills and valleys. I am from Scotland, so the place felt familiar. I wrote about my adventures in a diary. This was my first travel writing.

Sophia
There is a small train from Hythe to Dungeness. I like to travel first class. The view is simple, with fields and sheep. The train goes through gardens. I like to see people doing everyday things, like making tea. The simple landscape makes me look closely.

Matthew
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches have rocks and are hard to reach. Few people come here. Some people surf, but most enjoy the sea view. There are walks by the coast and in valleys with trees and flowers. We stay in a small house in a village called Southole.

Annette
My favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is good for hiking. Not many people live or visit there. I found it when I was a student. I visit every year with my family. It has not changed much. I like the space and quiet.

James
I bought my favourite house, Glenthorne, in England. I wanted peace and to feel at home. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around. We had a story about Glenthorne: if you went there, you would not come back. It is a quiet and special house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.'

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We love animals and have many at home. One day, my daughter called me at work. She found a pine snake and asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We have a special tank for animals we find. 

I came home late and started cooking. Suddenly, I heard my children shouting, "Oh, Mother! Help!" I ran to their room. Our cat, Domino, had caught Bianca, a white mouse. Domino ran around the room with the mouse in his mouth. I tried to catch Domino but tripped and fell. 

Then, I saw the snake escaping from its tank. The room was full of noise: the cat, the mouse, the kids, and our dog barking. I turned off the stove and caught Domino. I saved the mouse, which was not hurt. This mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life.

Next, I had to catch the snake. I sat on the floor and waited. Slowly, the snake calmed down. I picked it up and took it to the garden. I wanted it to go to a tree, but the snake wrapped around my shoulders. My eldest child, DJ, said, "Mum, you're warm, and the shed isn't." 

The children helped move the snake to the tree. It climbed up and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Write me a letter! Today, we use phones, fax machines, and computers a lot. Because of this, writing letters is disappearing. But I think getting a letter is special. It is exciting to see a letter arrive, to see who sent it, and to read it. I have written letters all my life. I started with small notes to my mother. She always told me to write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study in London, I wrote a letter every week to my mother, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote too, and his letters were funny and long. The letters from home talked about everyday things. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters more. I also got letters from boyfriends. Many of them were far away, so we wrote letters to stay in touch. Writing letters made our relationships better. I could say things in writing that were hard to say in person. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but a long letter with news is better! I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, a friend I trained with 20 years ago. I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. I also write to a lady in France. We met in a restaurant, and my husband took her photo. I asked for her address, and she wrote back. Now we write to each other often. I practice my French, and we have visited each other. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer. My family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We wrote letters for 29 years but never met. People were surprised our letters lasted so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it. I am happy my children write letters too. Like my mother, I tell them to write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. I hope people keep writing letters and do not let it disappear.'

**Title: Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art in France**

In the French Alps, there are very old pictures on rocks. These pictures are 4,000 years old and show cows, fields, and gods. The place is called Mont Bego. It was once a place for prayer. 

Many people visit Mont Bego. But some visitors are not careful. They write on the rocks and damage the pictures. Some people even take pieces of the rock home. Others rub the pictures to see them better. This is bad for the pictures.

Jean Clottes is an expert on rock art. He says if the damage continues, the pictures will be gone in 50 years. 

Experts have different ideas on how to protect the pictures. Henry de Lumley thinks the mountain should be closed to visitors. Only guided tours should be allowed. But Jean Clottes and David Lavergne do not agree. They want people to see the pictures. But they say it is hard to stop the damage because the area is big and there is not enough money for guards.

Annie Echassoux is worried because more tourists can now reach the mountain easily. She thinks the area should be closed off with ropes and guides should help visitors. She says money must be found to protect the pictures for future generations.

Text: 'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very hard. One mother says, 'They want everything they see. They ask for sweet cereals, Disney videos, and comics. I can't buy all these things. I feel bad if I say yes, and I feel bad if I say no. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to choose things.' Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, mostly on TV. These ads make children want to buy things. Parents find it hard to explain why they can't buy everything. Ads make things look very nice, and children don't understand why they can't have them. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, 'Parents care about what their children eat, but ads give children a one-sided view.' TV ads can't tell children to ask their parents to buy things, but they still make children want to buy them. Shopping with children can be stressful for parents. They have to decide what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says she talks to her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They talk about products and look at labels. Now, her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair. Mike, a father, says, 'We say no to sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and children want that too. But I still get annoyed when they ask for things. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I might say yes. It's hard to be fair all the time.' Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might buy less, but they would enjoy shopping more without their children's demands.'

Text: 'Climbing Walls Long ago, climbers went to mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. He is hanging upside down by two fingers. The National Indoor Arena, where the event is happening, is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both events have a wall. This is possible because of new technology.
