Drive so you do not spill it. Rule Number Two is to watch what might happen. The more ice there is, the further you need to look down the road. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Text: 'Craigie Aitchison Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He went to London to study law, but he chose to go to art school instead. He found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. In his late twenties, he got money from the Italian government to study art. He liked early Italian artists, and this shows in his work. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the clear light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted colors in thin layers, from light to dark. He says he never knows what the final painting will look like. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself.' Aitchison makes painting sound easy. 'Anyone can use colors - you can buy them. I just notice what colors go next to each other.' He does not draw before he paints because he might get bored and not finish the painting. He changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes models who do not ask to see the painting while he works. 'If they want to look, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he does not feel part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he just paints the way he can. But his work still influences young British painters.'

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for drums for his birthday. At first, we said no because of the noise. 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games,' Ben said, 'and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we said yes. 'Okay,' we said, 'but you must think about the family and the neighbours when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are hard to move, Ben's band friends came to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for a few hours a week, the house is loud with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby is good for our health: when the band plays, my husband and I go for a long walk. And I must say, even if their music sounds strange, they are nice and polite boys. I cannot say if they are good at music - my parents didn't like my music when I was young - but they play in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't study enough because of the band, but this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important school is. But one thing is sure - Ben was right: it keeps him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Text: 'Atlantic College Last week I visited Atlantic College, a private school in Wales. It is special because it gives young people experience outside the classroom and helps them study for exams. The students are 16 to 18 years old and come from all over the world. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution. Students at Atlantic College come from different countries and backgrounds. Not many can pay the PS20,000 fees for two years, so there are grants. A quarter of the students are British, and many get help from the government. "I admire the college for encouraging international understanding," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer, my mother saw I argued less with my sister." In short, Atlantic College gives students a great education with methods that work.'

Text: 'Being an older student I am 32 years old and I just finished my first year at university. I go to classes, read books, and write long essays. I decided to go to university after 14 years away from school. I worked as a secretary and made good money, but I was bored. I wanted to think more and learn new things. I saw students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to be like them. Now, I am a student, but it is hard to make friends with younger students. They think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because they know more than me. But I am happy to study because I need a qualification to get a good job. I like reading books on the weekend more than going to parties. I also enjoy student discounts for movies and theatre. Sometimes, I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope going back to school was a good choice.'

Text: 'Henry Ford Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cheap cars for people. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T'. It cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap. But, there was not much choice. 'You can have any color you like,' said Henry Ford of the Model T, 'as long as it's black.' '

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I want more information. How much does a course cost? How long is each course? When does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course is 6 weeks long and costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course for 10 weeks. It costs £200. I hope this helps. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain in the world, she was a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and her family and went to Asia with some other climbers. She found that life on Everest is hard. 'You must carry everything on your back,' she said, 'so you can only take things that you need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now she has written a book about the trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job too, on a science show on TV. Rebecca is well known today and she has more money, but she still lives in the little apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!'

Text: 'Dear Mike, I am sorry you could not come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and you stayed in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a very good party; the best I have ever had! Many of my friends were there and they gave me nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are big blue and white birds. When autumn comes, they fly south to warmer places. It is too cold in Canada in winter, and they can die if they stay. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in autumn.' Bill had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When it got cold in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They didn't come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for them for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends went to college, but Esther used the money to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon doubled the £500. At first, her parents wanted her to study and become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther kept making jam. After a few months, she sold it at the local market. Then she made orange juice and sold it to a school. After two years, her business was big, and her parents were happy. She made many kinds of food for shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she needed people to help her.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Do you want to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The movie starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I am sorry, but I can't go to the cinema tonight. My mother has work, and I will cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go? I hope you like the movie. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline '

Text: 'Corryvale Farm Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens. They sell milk and eggs. But they make most of their money from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep. Each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they do not get too hot. Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool. She tried to sell them at markets, but it was summer and too hot. People did not want to buy sweaters. Then, she made socks. People loved the socks because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business started. At first, she made the socks at home. But soon, she had many customers. She had to send the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are made by machines. There are six colours, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walking, sports, and skiing. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a favourite gift. In Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.'

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I came here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students are from many countries, and I have many new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS LIKE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave a door or a window open. Night-time burglaries are not common because families are usually at home. Winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark, and they can't be seen easily. Many houses are empty then because people are still at work. Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This will help keep burglars away. He also asked neighbours to watch other houses in the street when people are not at home. They should call the police if they see anything strange. 'We will also tell you how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This help is free.''

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, Thank you for letting me stay in your nice home for two nights. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They are good photos, right? I hope you like them. I really like my new camera. I will visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I have not seen my sister for a long time. Thanks again. Love, Roy'

Text: 'The History of Farming Before people started farming, they went to the forest to find plants or fruit to eat. This meant people moved all the time to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow food. These people were the first farmers. Farming let people stay in one place, and their villages got bigger. Some people in the villages could do other work, like making clothes, because farmers grew food for everyone. But farming was hard when the weather was bad, and some people did not have enough food. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels very far to our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen. She went to college and then worked at a small airport. After nine months, she worked for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Then she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she got her job now as a manager. This is what she said about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach air hostesses and help them with problems. I also go to many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check plane times on my computer. Then I talk with some of the air hostesses. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I like office work, too. Traveling can be hard work. When I come back from a long trip, I eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn much money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, I am happy to be back home, but I still think about my friends from our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8.30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a big blue bag and my name is on it. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms Johnson, I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6.30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson '

Text: 'People are interested in the weather for many reasons. The weather is important for many jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. A long time ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to know about the weather. Now, we use computers to learn about the weather. People can also see the weather on their phones. Today, some people still believe old ideas about the weather. They say if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They are friends and go to the same school. They like fishing and swimming on weekends. But for the last few months, they have been in Peter's room working on his laptop. They made a new computer word game. The idea came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin. Kevin has problems with reading. He learns words better with pictures and sounds. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked for over 200 hours to make the game. Now it is ready. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, if you see the word 'hat', there is a picture of a hat and you hear Peter say 'Hat! Hat!'. The boys have won many prizes for their game. It will soon be sold around the world. Many schools want to buy it.'

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' STAY HEALTHY? Sleeping well is very important. When I go to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. After a concert, it is hard to sleep because I think about music. Sport is important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports centre for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. Now, I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well. I drink a lot of water because it's good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always do it. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but I like other things too. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's good to do nothing sometimes. I don't get tired now because the doctor told me to eat better. I eat carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

Text: 'Bollywood' Bollywood is the name of the movie industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 movies every year. Since its first movie in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 movies. This is more than the USA, so it is the biggest movie industry in the world. Most people in India like watching movies more than any other free-time activity. Ten million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood movies are about love stories, and singing and dancing are important in every movie. People outside India also like Indian movies. Last year, Bollywood made over $500 million by selling movies to other countries. Indian actors make more movies each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they do not get paid as much. This is why most Bollywood movies only cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood movie never costs less than $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is different. Some people say he is India's greatest actor. He has been in more than 140 movies in almost 40 years of acting.

Text: 'Bill Bryson I was born in the United States. I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. Now, we live in the United States. We have been here for three years. Our children are learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happy because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and I want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon. So, we will stay for four more years. I just went to England for six weeks. I worked on a radio show about the English language and talked about my new book. Many writers don't like to travel and sell their books. I don't mind. I like to visit new places and meet people. It is very different from my life in the United States when I am writing. In England, people drove me in big cars and I stayed in nice hotels. It was good because I did not have to pay. Everyone was nice to me and it was fun.'

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago. The Giant Schnauzer came later. The name Giant is good because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, which needs to be cut often. Most small Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers are from Germany. Farmers use them to help with sheep, and the police use them because they are very smart. A Schnauzer is a nice family dog. It is friendly and good with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year she had a very interesting summer holiday. She went with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help make a road through a forest between two big towns. 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She wants to go back next year to do more work there.'

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. I had my first day at my new school today. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me the classrooms. She is very nice, and I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths. I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time. I really liked it. Most of the teachers are friendly, but I am scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I must go now because I have to do my homework. Hester'

Text: 'New books this month The Long Night This is David Reilly's first book. David was a teacher before he became a writer. Maha is a nurse in Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day a baby is very sick. Maha has to drive all night to a big city. They have many problems on the way and ... Hard Work This is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat. Sombat works with his father in Thailand. They make tables and chairs, but they have no money. One day a man in black buys a beautiful table from them ... Hospital or Cinema? Marcie Jacome wrote this story. She studies English in London. Tina is a young woman from Brazil. She wants to be a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. One day she meets a man. He asks her to go to the USA to be a film star ... What will Tina do?'

Text: 'The history of horse racing Horse racing is a very old sport. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago. People in Greece and Rome also liked it. Modern horse racing began when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. At first, races were long and had only two horses. In the 18th century, races became shorter and had more horses. Today, many people in the USA watch horse racing. It is also popular in other countries.'

Text: Nick Barlow is a British actor. He loves his job. He travels around the world to make TV shows. People are nice to him everywhere he goes. When he comes home, he remembers all the good things from each country. Nick has been to many places, but he wants to visit South America and go back to Australia. Nick travels with a team. They bring cameras and other things to make the show. Nick only takes a few shirts and trousers, but he always takes some books. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him traveling. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick comes home, she likes to hear his travel stories. But sometimes there are problems. Once, when Nick was in the Malaysian rain forest, he heard Helen was sick in the hospital. He felt bad because he couldn't help, but she didn't want him to come home. He was very happy when she got better.

Text: 'Parrots Maybe you have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in places like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in big groups. Parrots like to eat fruit, so sometimes they cause problems for farmers. There are many kinds of parrots, but all of them have strong beaks and feet. They use these for climbing and holding food. The biggest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds. It is easy to teach them to talk. Some zoos have parrot shows, where you can see the birds doing tricks they have learned.'

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a pretty village about fifty kilometres west of London. A young man from England named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr Bonnier's name yet, but he is already famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about many of the best restaurants in France. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He liked this so much that he decided not to buy many clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought a lot of French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! Why did he open a restaurant? Because he loves cooking. Was it easy? He says it is expensive to start your own restaurant and it is much harder to cook for fifty people than to cook for your family, but he is sure he did the right thing.'

Text: 'John Pickering John Pickering works in a park in a small town in England. He cuts the grass and waters the flowers. Last week, he was in Tokyo. Many people in Japan watched him on TV because he is a famous singer there. John went to Japan to sing in clubs. A radio DJ heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people liked his songs and called the radio. In Japan, John uses the name Jon Otis. But he will still work in the park in England. He does not know how much money he will make from singing. He says, 'I need to keep my job in the park. I have to pay my bills!' The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, works in a hospital. She says, 'This will not change our life. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!''

Text: 'Memo To: All staff Subject: Holidays From: D Brown Date: 22.2.02 I am planning the holidays for next year. Please tell me when you want to take your holiday. Can you give me two dates? Please tell me by the end of the month. Thank you. D Brown Memo To: D Brown Subject: Holidays From: J Green Date: 23.2.02 Can I take two weeks' holiday in July? I want the first two weeks, but if not, the last two weeks are OK. Also, can I take three extra days in the first week of December? John'

Text: 'Line dancing Many people in Britain have a new hobby -- line dancing. In almost every town, there are clubs and classes for this activity. 'Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, then you can do it!' says Fiona Lever, a teacher. 'You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a good way to make new friends. In my classes, there are young and old people. Boys like it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet!' When did line dancing start? Most people think it started about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino There are five kinds of rhinos in the world. The Black and White Rhinos live in Africa. The other rhinos live in Asia. All rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is very hard and they have little hair. Rhinos have four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They walk slowly, but they can run fast, at 50 kilometres an hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm. They eat grass and plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live to be 50 years old.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, there are police everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police. A few old men watched the streets at night, and they did not get much money. About 300 years ago, London started to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who took money in the streets, so people stayed at home. In 1750, Henry Fielding paid some people to stop thieves. They were like police and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London was very big and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force started with 3000 officers. Most of them walked, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police get good money, and the few police who ride horses get even more money.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Do you want to go on a camping trip this weekend? We will go to the forest in the school bus and stay at a camp-site from Friday to Sunday. The camp-site has hot showers and a small shop. You can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It is very cold at night, so bring warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, tell me today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, for the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from all over the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets have music and dance from morning until night. You can see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students do comedy shows in small places. Many tourists come to see new films and plays and hear music by famous musicians. This year, you can see over five hundred shows with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets are not expensive, and it is usually easier to see your favourite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so book your hotel now!'

Text: 'ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will find Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake turns to ice, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice. Bob Marvisch has come here every year for twenty-five years. 'You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy,' he says. 'First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport and you can meet some nice people here!''

Text: 'From: Greg To: Anna Hi Anna, I'm not having a good week! Yesterday my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team played better than us! Then my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. We can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister got up late and took my bike to school! She didn't tell me she needed it. I'm really angry with her. I hope you have some good news! Write back today if you can. Greg '

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's A very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. People can see figures of famous people made of wax there. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor and made wax figures of people. He opened a museum of these figures in Paris. Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie went to prison. She had to make wax heads of famous people who had died, like Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she came to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

Text: 'BICYCLES A bicycle is a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive. Only rich people could buy one. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have today. Later, bicycles became cheaper, and many people bought one. People started riding bicycles to work and in their free time. Today, people use cars more than bicycles. Cars are much faster, and you don't get wet when it rains! But some people still like to cycle to work. They say there are too many cars in town centers, and you can't find anywhere to park!'

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had pretty flower gardens, but we wanted to see the elephant show. We went to a big square with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of a big white card. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started to paint on its card. Sometimes, the keepers gave a new brush with paint to each elephant and took the old one away. Slowly, the elephants drew pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe it! One picture showed a river, one a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there, but the smartest elephants live in special places where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big cats There are many kinds of big cats. They are different in size and do not look or act the same. Tigers are the biggest cats. From head to tail, they can be 3.7 meters long. Most cats don't like water, but tigers like to lie in water when it is hot! Lions are the only cats that live in big family groups. Many lions work together to get food for the group. They live in flat, open places where they can see far and follow other animals. All cats need good eyes because they catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Text: 'Dear Mrs Brian, I am sorry but I can't come to your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister will get married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will make a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I'm sorry I will leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you again. Best wishes, Soraya'

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please tell me when you are free and where I can meet you. Hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I got it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant near there. Do you like Italian food? I have to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I'm happy because last month I got a new job in the city centre. I work in a Tourist Information Office. It is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I like telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me. I'm wearing my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world. An adult ostrich can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. Ostriches can run very fast, from 65 to 90 kilometres an hour. This makes it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens. They take about 3 years to grow up. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without water.'

Text: Victoria Jamieson is from Britain. She started snowboarding at 20 years old. Now, she is 23 and has won many competitions. We talked to her last week in Switzerland at a snowboarding competition. We asked her why she started snowboarding. She said, "I like all sports, especially skiing. Snowboarding was natural for me. It is easy to learn, and you can be good in a few months." We asked if she practices a lot. She said, "In winter, I snowboard every day in the mountains from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love it all! I like competitions and being in the mountains. It is very beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding for fun, is the best for me." We asked what is important when learning. She said, "You can learn fast, but you need lessons. It is important to have the right clothes so you do not get wet because you fall a lot at first!"

Text: '23 Oak Avenue Manchester Dear Sir or Madam, I want a room at your hotel for three nights from September 15th to 17th. I want a single room with a shower. I also need a phone in my room. Can I have a quiet room on the ground floor? I will drive to the hotel. Is there a car park at the hotel? I will arrive at about 10.30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to eat when I arrive. Thank you for your help. Yours sincerely, Mark Jones'

Text: 'Mount Kilimanjaro Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed Kilimanjaro, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to the top. People say the Marangu path is the easiest. It is five kilometers long. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. Only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro reach the top. This is because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and it can be very cold. Climbers need to bring sunglasses and warm clothes!'

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. Otters live near rivers and make their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can swim more than 10 kilometres an hour. They have thick brown hair to keep them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, so it can stay under water for a few minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, and many fish and insects died. The otters had no food. But today, the rivers are clean again, and there is lots of food for otters.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, I am happy you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom. I am 15 years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write to me about your life in India. I want to visit India one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school? I am sending you some photos of my family. I will send more next time. I hope you write to me soon. Tom'

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a very good teacher. I liked my time in Cambridge. Now I am at my brother's flat. He is learning to be a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go home to Greece. I like London a lot. We went to Regents Park by bus yesterday. It was very sunny and we had a good time. Tonight, I am going to see a movie with my brother and some of his friends. I'll write again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I will visit your country next month. I will travel with two friends. We don't know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We want to stay in the centre. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the centre are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you. She says you can all stay at her house. Her house has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People always make buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to keep beautiful things. Many people work on a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures. Engineers make sure the building is strong and safe. Then, the workers build it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous building with a nice roof. The building is beautiful from every side. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This building looks like a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will be 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown a lot, and all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England. They are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very big man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. Nobody knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to see the picture. If you go on the first of May at sunrise, you will see people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Text: 'Gail Rollins Gail Rollins is a very good runner from Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run 10,000 meters and maybe 5,000 meters at the European Championships. Before, Gail was famous for coming second in big races. But she always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for this. In 2004, everything changed when she ran her first half-marathon, a very long race. She won with the fastest time of the year for a British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also ran when he was younger, but he stopped because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes runs with Gail. But it's not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him. Gail trains hard. She runs long in the morning and fast in the afternoon. But she always rests on Sundays. 'I am with her all the time,' says Mike. 'Sometimes I say, "Are you sure you should eat that?" It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost everything.'

Text: 'Piano players - when they were young Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he wanted to write music and soon made his first song. Oleg Gagarin Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father taught him traditional Russian music on the piano. At six, he started lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg soon won prizes for playing the piano. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Later, he went back to Russia. Josef Heptmann Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two. A year later, he started playing the piano. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he played fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef liked music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is busy now but wants to write his own music one day.'

Text: 'Bill Prince-Smith Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he started writing children's books at 60 years old. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' says Bill. 'My ten grandchildren don't live close, but they also read my stories and say if they are good or bad.' This helps Bill know what young children like to read. Bill writes about life in his village and the farms nearby. His fifth book is his favorite: The Sheepdog is about a farmer and his dog. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are very smart, they learn fast.' Last year, the book became a film with real animals and actors. The film-makers used new computer technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes film-makers change books, but they didn't change mine and I love the film.''

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people like to send postcards to their friends and family. Postcards often have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles. You can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday. Postcards are cheap, and the pictures are often better than people's own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards had pictures of news events, like an accident or an important person's visit. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures then.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur. Dinosaurs died about 60 million years ago, before people lived on Earth. We do not know why they died. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5000 kinds. Some were very small, but others were very big. The biggest were larger than any other animals on land. The Brontosaurus was 20 meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast with its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can hurt people. Bears can climb trees and run fast. But they cannot see well. They use their noses to find food. There are seven kinds of bears. The biggest is the white polar bear. It is almost three meters tall. There are two kinds of black bears. One lives in North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black. They can be dark brown or reddish brown. Many people love the black and white panda bear from China. Not many pandas live in the forest now because it is hard to find food.'

Text: 'CROCODILES We can find crocodiles in warm places in the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They spend most of their time in slow water, but they can move fast in water and on land. You often see many crocodiles together. They eat everything they catch, like fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes they eat big animals or even people. There are more than ten kinds of crocodiles. They all have very sharp teeth. They often lose these teeth, but they grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some are much bigger. Crocodiles live for a long time. The oldest one in a zoo was 66 years old.'

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon to carry people in the air. In 1903, 120 years later, the Wright brothers made the first plane with an engine and flew it. This happened in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, aeroplanes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour. The trip from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by aeroplane, and it is hard to think of a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet if it rained. The queen liked going to the Globe Theatre by the River Thames to see plays by William Shakespeare. All the actors were men. People ate, talked, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Text: 'Dear Jeff, I'm having a good holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home! See you at the end of September. Sue'
